definition.definition: the first letter of the English alphabet
a note in Western music
definition.example: This concerto is in the key of A major.

definition.definition: a mark in an exam or for a piece of work that shows that your work is considered excellent
definition.example:
Sophie got an A for English.
She got straight As (= all her marks were As) in her final exams.
Jim is a straight-A student (= all his marks are A).

definition.definition: used before a noun to refer to a single thing or person that has not been mentioned before, especially when you are not referring to a particular thing or person
definition.example:
I've bought a car.
She's got a boyfriend.
There was a sudden loud noise.
What a shame that you couldn't go to the party.
I heard a child crying.
Is he a friend of yours (= one of your friends)?

definition.definition: used to say what type of thing or person something or someone is
definition.example:
She wants to be a doctor when she grows up.
This is a very mild cheese.
Experts think the painting may be a Picasso (= one done by Picasso).

definition.definition: used to mean any or every thing or person of the type you are referring to
definition.example:
Can you ride a bike?
A cheetah can run faster than a lion.
A teacher needs to have a lot of patience.

definition.definition: used before some uncountable nouns when you want to limit their meaning in some way, such as when describing them more completely or referring to one example of them
definition.example:
I only have a limited knowledge of Spanish.
He has a great love of music.
There was a fierceness in her voice.

definition.definition: used before some nouns of action when referring to one example of the action
definition.example:
Take a look at this, Jez.
I'm just going to have a snack.
There was a knocking at the door.

definition.definition: used when referring to a unit or container of something, especially something you eat or drink
definition.example:
I'd love a coffee.
All I had for lunch was a yogurt.

definition.definition: used before the first but not the second of two nouns that are referred to as one unit
definition.example:
a cup and saucer
a knife and fork

definition.definition: used before some words that express a number or amount
definition.example:
a few days
a bit of wool
a lot of money

definition.definition: used in front of a person's name when referring to someone who you do not know
definition.example: There's a Ms Evans to see you.

definition.definition: used in front of someone's family name when they are a member of that family
definition.example: Is that a Wilson over there?

definition.definition: used before the name of a day or month to refer to one example of it
definition.example:
My birthday is on a Friday this year.
It's been a very wet June.

definition.definition: one
definition.example:
a hundred
a thousand
a dozen
There were three men and a woman.

definition.definition: used between a fraction and a unit of measurement
definition.example:
half a mile
a quarter of a kilo
three quarters of an hour
six tenths of a second

definition.definition: used when saying how often something happens in a certain period
definition.example:
Take one tablet three times a day.
I swim once a week.

definition.definition: used when saying how much someone earns or how much something costs in a certain period
definition.example:
She earns $100,000 a year.
My plumber charges £30 an hour.
I pay £25 a week for my parking permit.

definition.definition: written abbreviation for amp
in or for each or every; per
definition.example:
Take one tablet three times a day.
These shoes cost $30 a pair.

definition.definition: the first letter of the English alphabet
in Western music, the sixth note in the scale (= series of notes) that begins on the note C, or a set of notes based on this note
a mark that means excellent, given to something of the highest quality, esp. school work
definition.example: The teacher gave me an A for my essay.

definition.definition: a small piece or amount of something
definition.example:
Would you like a bit of chocolate?
The glass smashed into little bits.
There were bits of paper all over the floor.
She tries to do a bit of exercise every day.
I don't understand this bit.

definition.definition: a short distance or period of time
definition.example: I'm just going out for a bit. See you later.

definition.definition: a slight but not serious amount or type of something
definition.example: Maria's put on a bit of weight, hasn't she?

definition.definition: slightly
definition.example: The dress is a bit too big for me.

definition.definition: very
definition.example: Blimey, it's a bit cold!

definition.definition: gradually
definition.example: I saved up the money bit by bit.

definition.definition: not in any way
definition.example: She wasn't a bit worried about the test.

definition.definition: a lot
definition.example: They have quite a bit of money.

definition.definition: into small pieces
definition.example: The car was blown to bits.

definition.definition: very much
definition.example: I love my son to bits.

definition.definition: a piece of metal put in a horse's mouth to allow the person riding it to control its movements
a unit of information in a computer that must be either 0 or 1
definition.example: a 32-bit computer (= a computer that processes 32 bits of information at a time)

definition.definition: a coin representing a small amount of money
definition.example: a threepenny/sixpenny bit

definition.definition: an amount of money that is equal to 12 1/2 cents, usually used in the expression "two bits," or 25 cents
the part of a tool used for cutting or drilling (= making holes)
past simple of bite
a small piece or a small amount of something
definition.example:
little bits of paper
We need every bit of evidence we can find.
We showed a little bit on videotape.
Could you talk a bit (= for a short period) about your childhood experiences?

definition.definition: A bit or a little bit can mean slightly or to some degree
definition.example: We found the dinner a little bit of a disappointment.

definition.definition: a piece of metal put in a horse’s mouth to allow the person riding it to control its movements
the smallest unit of information in a computer, represented by either 0 or 1
the part of a tool used to cut or drill (= make holes)
past simple of bite
the smallest unit of information in a computer's memory
definition.example: Can I run 32-bit programs on a 64-bit computer?

definition.definition: a short distance
definition.example:
The museum is just a few steps from the hotel.
A couple of steps in any direction is green, open land.
There is a good primary school just a step down the road from where they live.

definition.definition: some, or a small number of something
definition.example: I need to get a few things in town.

definition.definition: used in expressions such as "quite a few" to mean "quite a large number"
definition.example:
I know quite a few people who have had the same problem.
Lots of people at the club are under 20, but there are quite a few who aren't.
I've been to Paris quite a few times.
She was quite few years older than her husband.
I spent a good few minutes just staring at the scene, unable to speak.

definition.definition: a small number or not many
definition.example:
It was embarrassing how few people attended the party.
He is among the few people I can trust.
Very few people can afford to pay those prices.
Few of the children can read or write yet.
Few things in this world give me more pleasure than a long bath.
We get few complaints.
as few as According to the survey, as few as ten percent of us are happy with our jobs.
The benefits of the planned changes are few.
Fewer people smoke these days than used to.
We received far fewer complaints than expected.
Fewer than 3,500 tigers are left in the wild today.
They set a new record for the fewest points scored in a season.
Which picture got the fewest votes?

definition.definition: not happening or existing very often
definition.example: Apartments that are both comfortable and reasonably priced are few and far between.

definition.definition: a small number, not many, or not enough (of something)
definition.example: He is one of the few (people) I can trust to keep a secret.

definition.definition: A few means a small number of
definition.example:
I’m going to the supermarket to get a few things.
We’ve been having a few problems with the new computer.
"How many tomatoes do we need?" "Just a few."

definition.definition: the best performance that someone is able to produce
definition.example:
No one in the team, including myself, brought their A game to any of the matches.
I needed to have my A game today but it wasn't even close.
Federer was on his A game and Murray did well to handle him.

definition.definition: a large amount
definition.example:
She spends a good deal of her time in China.
A great deal of effort has gone into making the software reliable.
They still need a great deal more money to finish the project.
It doesn't make a great deal of difference.
A great deal of my time is spent preparing students for exams.
To be honest, a good deal of what she says is just plain common sense.

definition.definition: a large amount
definition.example:
She spends a good deal of her time in China.
A great deal of effort has gone into making the software reliable.
They still need a great deal more money to finish the project.
It doesn't make a great deal of difference.
A great deal of my time is spent preparing students for exams.
To be honest, a good deal of what she says is just plain common sense.

definition.definition: a public exam taken in England and Wales by children aged 17 or 18. Students take AS level exams then A2s, usually a year later, which together make a full A level qualification
definition.example:
You usually need three A levels to get into university.
I failed my History A level.
Do you have an A level in maths?
This problem should be easy enough for someone who's done physics at A level.

definition.definition: slightly
definition.example:
I was a little bit worried by what she said.
We'll wait a little longer and then I'll phone them.
There's only a little further to go.

definition.definition: to expect or demand more than is usual, reasonable, or fair
definition.example:
It's asking a lot when your boss wants you to work weekends as well as evenings.
It is asking a lot to rely on one player to transform the club's fortunes.

definition.definition: relating to an argument that suggests the probable effects of a known cause, or using general principles to suggest likely effects
definition.example: "It's freezing outside; you must be cold" is an example of a priori reasoning.

definition.definition: I form of be
definition.example: Am I included?

definition.definition: used when referring to a time between twelve o'clock at night and twelve o'clock in the middle of the day
definition.example: The first election results are expected around 1 a.m.

definition.definition: abbreviation for amplitude modulation: a type of radio broadcasting in which the strength of the signal changes, producing sound of a lower quality than FM:
definition.example: You're listening to Radio Gold, broadcasting 24 hours a day on 909 AM.

definition.definition: abbreviation for Assembly Member: a person who has been elected to the Welsh Assembly
(used with I) be
definition.example: I am getting ready now.

definition.definition: used when referring to a time between twelve o’clock at night and twelve o’clock in the middle of the day; past the middle of the night, or in the morning
definition.example: We fly out of New York late in the evening and arrive in London at 7 a.m. the next morning.

definition.definition: abbreviation for amplitude modulation (= one of two main types of radio waves used to broadcast in the US)
definition.example: Most of the talk radio programs can be found on AM stations.

definition.definition: abbreviation for America or American
definition.example: Pan Am Airlines finally went out of business in 1991.

definition.definition: used by ratings agencies (= organizations that calculate the level of risk of investments) to describe bonds, etc. with a very low risk of not being paid back
definition.example: Allied Bank's long-term foreign currency deposit has been rated A1 by Weston Investment Service.

definition.definition: very good or in the best possible condition
definition.example: The trucks are second-hand but in A1 condition.

definition.definition: abbreviation for Associate in Arts: a degree given by an American college to someone after they have finished a two-year course, or a person who has this degree
abbreviation for Alcoholics Anonymous: an organization for people who drink too much alcohol and want to cure themselves of this habit:
definition.example: an AA meeting

definition.definition: abbreviation for the Automobile Association: an organization in the UK that gives help and information to drivers who are members of it
used by ratings agencies (= organizations that calculate the level of risk of investments) to describe bonds, etc. with a low risk of not being paid back
definition.example: We recommend only those funds with the high ratings of AA or AAA.

definition.definition: → the Advertising Association
abbreviation for American Association of Retired Persons: an organization in the US that provides support and advice to people aged 50 and over:
definition.example: AARP members

definition.definition: → BA
abbreviation for Aktiebolaget: a legal form of company in Sweden that is similar to a limited company in other countries
abbreviation for American Bankers Association: a professional organization that represents the US banking industry:
definition.example: The ABA report said that consumer borrowing is likely to slow down because of higher interest rates.

definition.definition: to be very shocked or surprised
definition.example: I was somewhat taken aback by her honesty.

definition.definition: a square or rectangular frame holding an arrangement of small balls on metal rods or wires, used for counting or for doing calculations
a flat slab (= piece of stone, etc.) at the top of a column
a frame that holds thin metal rods with balls that slide on them, used for counting, adding, and subtracting
to leave a place, thing, or person, usually for ever
definition.example:
We had to abandon the car.
By the time the rebel troops arrived, the village had already been abandoned.
As a baby he was abandoned by his mother.
abandon ship We were sinking fast, and the captain gave the order to abandon ship.

definition.definition: to stop doing an activity before you have finished it
definition.example:
The game was abandoned at half-time because of the poor weather conditions.
They had to abandon their attempt to climb the mountain.
The party has now abandoned its policy of unilateral disarmament.

definition.definition: to allow yourself to be controlled completely by a feeling or way of living
definition.example: He abandoned himself to his emotions.

definition.definition: in a completely uncontrolled way
definition.example: We danced with wild abandon.

definition.definition: to leave behind or run away from someone or something, or to give up something
definition.example:
Air attacks forced the villagers to abandon their homes.
The weather was so bad, we abandoned our plans for a picnic.
Archeologists don’t know what could have caused a mass abandonment of the area.

definition.definition: to stop an activity before it is finished, usually because you think you cannot succeed
definition.example:
abandon a project/plan/an idea The car maker has abandoned its plans to build a giant new plant.
abandon a lawsuit/case/claim The high cost of legal representation can influence a person's decision about whether to abandon a claim.

definition.definition: to leave a person, place, or thing that needs you to care for them
definition.example:
He kept the company going because he didn't want to abandon his staff.
A vehicle had been abandoned on the side of the road.

definition.definition: to allow an insurance company to keep property that has been lost or damaged, in exchange for an insurance payment

definition.example: High winds forced the abandonment of efforts to erect the structure.

definition.definition: left in a particular place or condition, usually forever
definition.example:
An abandoned baby was found in a box on the hospital steps.
The world is full of abandoned mines.
People feel abandoned by the government.

definition.definition: left behind, or left without care and protection
definition.example:
Shelters are full of abandoned pets.
The fire started in an abandoned warehouse.

definition.definition: an abandoned place or vehicle is no longer being used or cared for because its owner does not want it any more
definition.example: The planned site for the development is an abandoned quarry.

definition.definition: the act of leaving someone or something or of ending or stopping something, usually forever
definition.example:
The abandonment of the island followed nuclear tests in the area.
His abandonment by his mother when he was a baby affected him all his life.

definition.definition: to make yourself seem to be less important or to not deserve respect
the act of causing someone to seem as if they deserve no respect and have no power or importance
definition.example:
These children were abandoned to a life of degradation and abasement.
He is obsessed with the abasement of those he perceives as his enemies.

definition.definition: to embarrass someone or make them feel uncomfortable
definition.example:
Her elder cousins abashed her by commenting on her shyness.
They tried not to be abashed by the unfamiliar luxury.

definition.definition: to become less strong
definition.example:
The storm/wind/rain has started to abate.
The fighting in the area shows no sign of abating.

definition.definition: to become less strong, or to make something less strong
definition.example: Our desire for consumer goods has not abated.

definition.definition: if something such as a price or level abates, it goes up more slowly than before, or it goes down
definition.example: Gains in oil prices are unlikely to abate within the next few months.

definition.definition: to become or make something become weaker, lower, less serious, etc.
definition.example:
Inflation is finally showing signs of abating.
The mayor plans to abate air pollution in the city by limiting traffic.

definition.definition: a reduction in the amount or degree of something
definition.example:
The tax abatement will save the business thousands of pounds.
We need some noise abatement.

definition.definition: a situation in which a rate, price, etc. goes down, or goes up more slowly than before
definition.example: We have requested an abatement of interest on our late tax payment, as we received the tax bill late.

definition.definition: a reduction in level, especially of something that is harmful
definition.example:
Industries have been set targets for the abatement of carbon emissions.
noise abatement

definition.definition: a woman who is in charge of a convent
a building where monks or nuns live or used to live. Some abbeys are now used as churches
definition.example: Westminster Abbey

definition.definition: a building for monks (= religious men) or nuns (= religious women) to live in
a man who is in charge of a monastery
to make a word or phrase shorter by using only the first letters of each word
definition.example:
abbreviate something as "Chief Executive Officer" is abbreviated as "CEO".
abbreviate something to "Daniel" is often abbreviated to "Dan".

definition.definition: to shorten a word or words, or to make something shorter
definition.example: We had to abbreviate the names of the states.
An abbreviated version was published last year.

definition.definition: shorter than usual or shorter than expected
definition.example:
in abbreviated form The show was broadcast in abbreviated form the next day.
They exchanged a passionate, but abbreviated, kiss.
The students were given an abbreviated intelligence test.

definition.definition: (of a word or phrase) made shorter by using only the first letters of each word
definition.example:
abbreviated form "Di" is the abbreviated form of "Diane".
The bacon, lettuce, and tomato sandwich is more commonly referred to by its abbreviated name, BLT.

definition.definition: a short form of a word or phrase
definition.example: "ITV" is the abbreviation for "Independent Television".

definition.definition: a shortened form esp. of a word or phrase
definition.example:
UN is the abbreviation for the United Nations.
The letters i.e. are an abbreviation of a Latin phrase that means "that is."

definition.definition: the alphabet
definition.example: He's learning his ABC at school.

definition.definition: basic information about a subject
definition.example: What I need is a book that contains the ABC of carpentry.

definition.definition: abbreviation for American Broadcasting Company: an organization that broadcasts on television in the US
abbreviation for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation: an organization that broadcasts on radio and television in Australia and is paid for by the government
abbreviation for the Audit Bureau of Circulations
If a king or queen abdicates, he or she makes a formal statement that he or she no longer wants to be king or queen
definition.example: King Edward VIII abdicated (the British throne) in 1936.

definition.definition: to stop controlling or managing something that you are in charge of
definition.example: She abdicated all responsibility for the project.

definition.definition: to give up a position as king, or to fail to take responsibility for something
definition.example:
[T] Edward VIII abdicated the British throne in 1936.
The administration has abdicated its leadership on this critical issue.
[U] I think it’s an abdication of your responsibility if you don’t vote.

definition.definition: the fact of no longer controlling or managing something that you are in charge of
definition.example:
The council denied that their decision represented any abdication of responsibility.
It is difficult to imagine a more flagrant abdication of duty.

definition.definition: an occasion when a king or queen makes a formal statement that he or she no longer wants to be king or queen
definition.example:
The romance between King Edward VIII and Wallis Simpson resulted in Edward's abdication from the throne.
His abdication speech was broadcast on the radio.

definition.definition: the lower part of a person's or animal's body, containing the stomach, bowels, and other organs, or the end of an insect's body
the part of the body that contains stomach, bowels, and other organs in a person or animal

definition.example: This virus causes terrible abdominal pain.

definition.definition: in, forming, or relating to the abdomen
definition.example:
abdominal pains
A membrane covers the abdominal cavity.
This exercise works your abdominal muscles.

definition.definition: to force someone to go somewhere with you, often using threats or violence
definition.example: The company director was abducted from his car by terrorists.

definition.definition: to move a part of the body away from the central part of the body or away from another body part
definition.example: Listen for a clicking sound as the child's hips are abducted.

definition.definition: to take a person away by force
definition.example: Kidnappers abducted the child from the playground.
[C] The abduction took place in front of several helpless witnesses.

definition.definition: the act of making a person go somewhere with you, especially using threats or violence
definition.example:
There has been a series of abductions of young children from schools in the area.
He was charged with abduction.

definition.definition: the movement of a part of the body away from the central part of the body or from another body part
definition.example: hip abduction exercises

definition.definition: different from what is typical or usual, especially in an unacceptable way
definition.example: aberrant behaviour/sexuality

definition.definition: a temporary change from the typical or usual way of behaving
definition.example:
mental aberration I'm sorry I'm late - I had a mental aberration and forgot we had a meeting today.
In a moment of aberration, she agreed to go with him.
The misconduct was an aberration from the norm for him.

definition.definition: a change from what is typical or usual, esp. a temporary change
definition.example: The drop in our school’s test scores was dismissed as an aberration.

definition.definition: to help or encourage someone to do something wrong or illegal
definition.example: His accountant had aided and abetted him in the fraud.

definition.definition: to help or encourage a person or thing to do something, esp. something wrong or illegal
definition.example: Shady lawyers abetted the company’s officers in stealing the funds.

definition.definition: a state of not happening or being used at present
definition.example:
Any proposed abeyance of the bylaws must be approved by the entire committee.
in abeyance Hostilities between the two groups have been in abeyance since last June.
be held in abeyance The project is being held in abeyance until agreement is reached on funding it.

definition.definition: to hate a way of behaving or thinking, often because you think it is not moral
definition.example: I abhor all forms of racism.

definition.definition: to hate something or someone
definition.example: His opponent abhors the death penalty.
She has an abhorrence of violence.
His attitude of superiority is abhorrent.

definition.definition: a feeling of hating something or someone
definition.example:
She looked at him in/with abhorrence.
She has an abhorrence of change.

definition.definition: If you can't abide someone or something, you dislike them very much
definition.example: I can't abide her.

definition.definition: to live or stay somewhere
definition.example: He abided in the wilderness for forty days.

d_list: 20000+; ACT; GRE; IELTS; SAT; TOEFL; TOEIC

definition.definition: to accept or obey an agreement, decision, or rule
definition.example: Competitors must abide by the judge's decision.

definition.definition: to accept or obey an agreement, decision, rule, etc.
definition.example: Competitors must abide by the judges’ decision.

definition.definition: An abiding feeling or memory is one that you have had for a long time
definition.example:
abiding memory My abiding memory is of him in the garden.
She holds an abiding affection for her old school.

definition.definition: lasting for a long time
definition.example: Muir had an abiding interest in dogs.

definition.definition: the physical or mental power or skill needed to do something
definition.example:
There's no doubting her ability.
[+ to infinitive] She had the ability to explain things clearly and concisely.
She's a woman of considerable abilities.
I have children in my class of very mixed abilities (= different levels of skill or intelligence).
a mixed-ability class

definition.definition: used to form nouns from adjectives ending in "-able" to mean the quality of being the stated adjective
definition.example:
suitability
vulnerability

definition.definition: the mental or physical power or skill needed to do something
definition.example:
[U] They should not be taking in somebody they don't have the ability to care for.
[C] Her teammates respect her abilities.

definition.definition: the power or skill needed to do something, or the fact that someone is able to do something
definition.example:
There's no doubting her ability.
the ability to do sth A good leader has the ability to motivate people.
We like our employees to have a broad range of abilities, not just good qualifications.

definition.definition: the state of being extremely unhappy, poor, unsuccessful, etc.
definition.example: They live in abject poverty.

definition.definition: showing no pride or respect for yourself
definition.example:
an abject apology
He is almost abject in his respect for his boss.

definition.definition: extreme and without hope
definition.example:
They live in abject poverty.
My experiment was an abject failure.

definition.definition: to say formally or publicly that you no longer agree with a belief or way of behaving
definition.example: He abjured his religion/his life of dissipation.

definition.definition: burning very strongly
definition.example: The house was ablaze, and the flames and smoke could be seen for miles around.

definition.definition: brightly lit or brightly coloured
definition.example:
The ballroom was ablaze with lights.
The field was ablaze with wild flowers.

definition.definition: full of energy, interest, or emotion
definition.example: Her eyes were ablaze with excitement.

definition.definition: burning or very bright
definition.example:
Fire spread quickly until the whole building was ablaze.
The ballroom was ablaze with lights.

definition.definition: to have the necessary physical strength, mental power, skill, time, money, or opportunity to do something
definition.example: Will she be able to cope with the work?

definition.definition: to find it easier to do something
definition.example: Get a good night's sleep and you'll feel better able to cope.

definition.definition: intelligent or good at what you do
definition.example:
an able child/student/secretary
This problem is now being looked at by some of the ablest minds/scientists in the country.

definition.definition: added to verbs to form adjectives that mean able to receive the action of the stated verb
definition.example:
breakable
washable
movable

definition.definition: added to verbs to form adjectives that mean worth receiving the action of the stated verb
definition.example:
an admirable person
an acceptable answer

definition.definition: having what is needed to do something, esp. the physical or mental power, skill, time, money, or opportunity
definition.example:
I lost my job and wasn’t able to afford my old apartment.
We won’t be able to keep up this kind of effort much longer.

definition.definition: good at what you do
definition.example: He is an able student.
He does his job very ably.

definition.definition: people who are healthy and have no illness, injury, or condition that makes it difficult to do the things that other people do
definition.example: It is hard for the able-bodied to understand the difficulties that disabled people encounter in their daily lives.

definition.definition: used to refer to someone who is healthy and has no illness, injury, or condition that makes it difficult to do the things that other people do
definition.example: All able-bodied young men were forced to join the army.

definition.definition: the act of washing yourself
definition.example: Ablution is part of some religious ceremonies.

definition.definition: Your ablutions are the things you do when you wash yourself
definition.example: perform your ablutions He went off to the baths to perform his ablutions.

definition.definition: to not allow yourself to have something, especially something you like or want
to not accept something, or to say that you do not have something
definition.example: to abnegate responsibility/guilt

definition.definition: the act of not allowing yourself to have something, especially something you like or want
definition.example:
They believe it is the duty of women to live for others in complete abnegation of themselves.
It is a heart-warming tale of courage and abnegation.

definition.definition: the act of not accepting something, or of saying that you do not have something
definition.example:
To ignore these issues would be a serious abnegation of responsibility.
This abnegation of customer care really annoys me.

definition.definition: different from what is usual or average, especially in a way that is bad
definition.example:
abnormal behaviour/weather/conditions
Tests revealed some abnormal skin cells.

definition.definition: not usual or average
definition.example:
We had an abnormal amount of snow.
He has an abnormal heartbeat.
[C] No abnormalities showed up in the blood tests.
It was abnormally hot this summer.

definition.definition: on or onto a ship, aircraft, bus, or train
definition.example:
The flight attendant welcomed us aboard.
Welcome aboard flight BA345 to Tokyo.
The train's about to leave. All aboard!
We spent two months aboard ship (= on the ship).

definition.definition: on or onto a ship, aircraft, bus, or train
definition.example: We finally went aboard the plane three hours later.

definition.definition: the place where someone lives
definition.example:
humble abode humorous Welcome to my humble abode!
no fixed abode UK formal The defendant is of no fixed abode (= has no permanent home).
Please list your permanent address or, if you are a citizen of another county, the address of your habitual abode in this country.
Despite being called The Cottage, their estate was the largest abode in the county.
I bought you some nice candlesticks for your new abode.

definition.definition: the place where someone lives
definition.example: [C] He was a wanderer with no permanent abode.

definition.definition: a home or permanent place to live
definition.example: He voted to allow 50,000 Hong Kong families the right of abode in Britain.

definition.definition: used in legal cases to say that someone does not have a permanent address
definition.example: Three men, all of no fixed abode, appeared in court charged with violent disorder.

definition.definition: to end an activity or custom officially
definition.example:
I think bullfighting should be abolished.
National Service was abolished in the UK in 1962.

definition.definition: to put an end to something, such as an organization, rule, or custom
definition.example: Massachusetts voters abolished rent control.

definition.definition: to end an activity, custom, etc. completely or by law or official action
definition.example:
Educationalists have called on the government to abolish tax on computers.
The government has pledged to abolish child poverty by 2020.

definition.definition: the act of ending an activity or custom officially
definition.example:
He fought for abolition of the death penalty in Britain.
the abolition of slavery

definition.definition: the official ending of an activity or custom
Abolition also means the official end to slavery in the US, which took place in 1863.
the complete ending of an activity or custom by law or official action
definition.example: The party supports the abolition of tax relief on pension funds.

definition.definition: a person who supports the abolition of something
a person who supported an end to slavery
very bad or unpleasant
definition.example:
The prisoners are forced to live in abominable conditions.
The weather's been abominable all week.

definition.definition: very bad or unpleasant
definition.example: The abominable working conditions made many workers sick.

definition.definition: to hate something very much
definition.example: He abominates cruelty of all kinds.

definition.definition: something that you dislike and disapprove of
definition.example: Cruelty to animals is an abomination.

definition.definition: a member of a race of people who were the first people to live in a country, before any colonists arrived
definition.example:
The river was once a trade route for aboriginals and fur traders who built communities along its bank.
What does it mean to be an Native American or indigenous aboriginal today?

definition.definition: consisting of or relating to a race of people who lived in a country before any colonists arrived
definition.example:
The Arunta are an aboriginal tribe from central Australia.
North American Aboriginal peoples have differing views concerning burial excavation.
Aboriginal art/traditions

definition.definition: having lived or existed in a place since the earliest known time
definition.example: The exhibit was of aboriginal plants of this area.

definition.definition: a word for a member of one of the groups of people who were the first people to live in Australia, which was used officially in the past, but is now offensive
a word for a member of any of the groups of people who first lived in Australia, which was used officially in the past, but is now offensive
to cause something to stop or fail before it begins or before it is complete
definition.example:
The mission had to be aborted at the last minute.
If something goes wrong during the launch sequence the system will automatically abort.

definition.definition: to stop the development of a baby that has not been born, usually by having a medical operation
definition.example:
He declared that women have a right to abort a nonviable fetus.
The decision to abort may be based on many factors.

definition.definition: to have a miscarriage (= an early, unintentional end to a pregnancy)
definition.example: The bacterial infection can cause animals to abort.

definition.definition: to stop something before it has begun or to cause something to fail before it is complete
definition.example: Engineers aborted the test flight at the last minute.

definition.definition: to end a pregnancy before a baby is fully developed

definition.example: An abortive uprising led to his exile.

definition.definition: to stop an activity before it begins or before it is complete
definition.example:
abort a test/trial/plan We were forced to abort the test as a result of technical problems.
abort a launch/merger/deal Money has been wasted on aborted deals.

definition.definition: to stop a computer process before it is complete
definition.example:
abort a program/command/operation This command tells the server to abort the previous FTP service command.
If the file is not present, the script will abort.

definition.definition: the intentional ending of a pregnancy
definition.example:
Abortion is illegal in some countries.
get an abortion She decided to get an abortion.
have an abortion She had an abortion when she was a teenager.

definition.definition: the early, unintentional ending of a pregnancy when a baby or young animal is born too early and dies before it is fully developed
definition.example:
The virus can cause abortion in cattle.
We expect to see late abortions and birth abnormalities as a result of the radiation leak.

definition.definition: something considered to be a complete failure or to be extremely bad or ugly
definition.example:
This is an abortion of truth.
One local man described the new building as "an abortion".

definition.definition: An abortive attempt or plan has to be stopped because it has failed
definition.example: He made two abortive attempts on the French throne.

definition.definition: to exist in large numbers
definition.example: Theories abound about how the universe began.

definition.definition: to exist in large numbers
definition.example: The streams and rivers abound in fish.

definition.definition: on the subject of, or connected with
definition.example:
go on about He's always going on about what a great job he's got.
there's something about There's something about her attitude that worries me.
what about it "Is that your car?" "Yes, what about it?"
while someone is about it UK informal Could you make me a coffee too while you're about it (= while you are making one for yourself)?
What's that book about?
a film about the Spanish Civil War
We were talking/laughing about Sophie.
I'm worried about David.
I really don't know what all the fuss is about.
What didn't you like about the play?
There's something special/strange/unique about him (= in his character).

definition.definition: to take action to solve a problem
definition.example: I wish you'd do something about your bedroom - it's a real mess.

definition.definition: positioned around a place, often without a clear purpose or order
definition.example: Their belongings were flung about the room.

definition.definition: in a particular place
definition.example:
Do you have such a thing as a pen about you/your person? (= Do you have a pen?)
She was puttering about the kitchen.

definition.definition: a little more or less than the stated number or amount
definition.example:
about six feet tall
about two months ago
"What time are you leaving work today?" "About five."

definition.definition: almost
definition.example:
We're about ready to leave.
Well, I think that's about it for now (= we have almost finished what we are doing for the present).

definition.definition: in many different directions
definition.example:
They heard someone moving about outside.
I've been running about all morning trying to find you.

definition.definition: positioned around a place, often without a clear purpose or order
definition.example: She always leaves her clothes lying about on the floor.

definition.definition: in or near a place
definition.example:
Is John about (= somewhere near)?
There's a lot of flu about (= many people have the flu) at the moment.

definition.definition: to be going to do something very soon
definition.example: I was about to leave when Mark arrived.

definition.definition: on the subject of; connected with
definition.example:
"What’s that book about?" "It’s about the Civil War."
I don’t know what all the fuss is about.
There’s something about her attitude that worries me.

definition.definition: a little more or less than a specific number; approximately
definition.example:
He’s about six feet tall.
It happened about two months ago.
I’ve had just about enough of your complaining (= I do not want to hear any more).

definition.definition: almost ready to do something, or intending to do something soon
definition.example:
He looked as if he was about to burst into tears.
I’m not about to apologize to him.

definition.definition: positioned or moving in or near a place
definition.example: Reporters stood about, waiting for more news.

definition.definition: in or to a higher position than something else
definition.example:
There's a mirror above the sink.
He waved the letter excitedly above his head.
She's rented a room above a shop.
Her name comes above mine on the list.
The helicopter was hovering above the building.
It's on the shelf just above your head.
A crack had started to appear just above the light on the ceiling.

definition.definition: more than an amount or level
definition.example:
above average Rates of pay are above average (= greater than average).
It says on the box it's for children aged three and above.
Temperatures rarely rise above zero in winter.
She values her job above her family.
They value their freedom above all else.

definition.definition: most importantly
definition.example: Above all, I'd like to thank my family.

definition.definition: in a more important or advanced position than someone else
definition.example: Sally's a grade above me.

definition.definition: too good or important for something
definition.example: No one is above suspicion in this matter.

definition.definition: When used in a piece of writing, "above" means higher on the page, or on a previous page
definition.example:
Please send the articles to the address given above.
The letter was sent to the above address.

definition.definition: all the people or things listed earlier
definition.example:
All of the above (= everyone listed earlier) should be invited.
Once we've finished all of the above we can start on the next project.

definition.definition: higher than, more than, or at a level greater than
definition.example:
The helicopter was hovering above the building.
Temperatures here rarely rise above freezing in winter.
Our wages are above average.
I could hardly hear him above the blare of the music.

definition.definition: In writing, above can mean as stated higher up on this page or on a previous page
definition.example: Refer to the diagram shown above.

definition.definition: To be above doing something is to consider yourself too important or too moral to do it
definition.example: He’s not above lying to protect himself.

definition.definition: those mentioned earlier
definition.example: All of the above are to be included.

definition.definition: most importantly
definition.example:
Above all, I'd like to thank my family.
Above all, I'd say I value kindness.
This book is above all a story of a mother's love.
Any furniture you buy must be cheap, attractive and, above all, practical.
His goal, above all, was to prevent another war.

definition.definition: most importantly
definition.example: Above all, don’t forget to call when you get there.

definition.definition: If a plan or business agreement is above board, it is honest and not trying to deceive anyone
definition.example: The discussions were completely open and aboveboard.

definition.definition: easily seen, honest, not trying to deceive
definition.example: The discussions were completely open and aboveboard.

definition.definition: said by someone who is performing a magic trick, in order to help perform it successfully
to remove part of the surface of something by rubbing
past simple and past participle of abrade
to remove part of the surface of something by rubbing
the process of rubbing away the surface of something
definition.example: There seems to have been some abrasion of the surface.

definition.definition: a place where the surface of something, such as skin, has been rubbed away
definition.example: She had a small abrasion on her knee.

definition.definition: the gradual rubbing away of the surface of rock, for example, by other rock, water, or a glacier (= large moving mass of ice)
rude and unfriendly
definition.example:
She has a rather abrasive manner.
He can sometimes be abrasive in meetings.

definition.definition: An abrasive substance is slightly rough, and often used for cleaning surfaces
definition.example: an abrasive cleaner/powder/liquid

definition.definition: a substance used for rubbing away the surface of something, usually to clean it or make it shiny
definition.example: You'll need a strong abrasive for cleaning this sink.

definition.definition: having a rough surface that will rub off a thin layer of another surface
definition.example: The paint comes off with an abrasive steel-wool pad.

definition.definition: rude and unkind
definition.example: His abrasive style puts people off.

definition.definition: used to say that two or more people are next to each other and moving in the same direction
definition.example:
We were running/swimming two abreast.
The motorcyclist came abreast of her car and shouted abuse at her.

definition.definition: to make sure you know all the most recent facts about a subject or situation
definition.example: I try to keep abreast of any developments.

definition.definition: next to another person and facing in the same direction
definition.example: We were running two abreast around the track.

definition.definition: If you keep abreast of a subject, you stay informed about new developments in it
definition.example: Staying abreast of new software releases takes lots of time.

definition.definition: to make a book, play, or piece of writing shorter by removing details and information that is not important
definition.example: The book was abridged for children.

definition.definition: to reduce someone's freedom, rights, etc.
definition.example:
He said that Congress would make no law abridging the freedom of speech.
Had the state abridged his rights?

definition.definition: to make a written text shorter

definition.example: They listened to an abridged version on tape.

definition.definition: a book, play, or piece of writing that has been made shorter by removing some details or less important information
definition.example:
The books are abridgments of well-known classics.
In 1676 Bauthumley published an abridgement of Foxe's Book of Martyrs.

definition.definition: the act of making a book, play, or piece of writing shorter by removing some details or information
definition.example:
Drastic abridgment makes this story even more difficult to understand.
This version of the play is marred only by some awkward abridgement.

definition.definition: the act of reducing someone's freedom, rights, etc., or an instance of this
definition.example:
He says there are laws which are completely unethical and an abridgment of freedom.
The measure establishes a dangerous precedent in the abridgement of human liberty.

definition.definition: in or to a foreign country or countries
definition.example:
go abroad We always go abroad in the summer.
He's currently abroad on business.

definition.definition: outside, or not at home
definition.example: Not a soul was abroad that morning.

definition.definition: used to say that ideas, feelings, and opinions are shared by many people
definition.example: There's a rumour abroad that she intends to leave the company.

definition.definition: in or to a foreign country or countries
definition.example: They used to go abroad every summer.

definition.definition: to end a law, agreement, or custom formally
definition.example: The treaty was abrogated in 1929.

definition.definition: to avoid something that you should do
definition.example:
Companies are really abrogating responsibility for safety.
He seemed to abrogate his duty to withhold law and order.

definition.definition: to officially end a law, agreement, or custom
definition.example: The opposition party pledged to abrogate the law if they won the election.

definition.definition: sudden and unexpected, and often unpleasant
definition.example:
abrupt end Our conversation came to an abrupt end when George burst into the room.
abrupt change There was an abrupt change in her attitude towards me when she heard that I was Alan's girlfriend
abrupt halt The car juddered and came to an abrupt halt in the middle of the road.
The road ended in an abrupt (= sudden and very steep) slope down to the sea.

definition.definition: using too few words when talking, in a way that seems rude and unfriendly
definition.example:
He is sometimes very abrupt with clients.
an abrupt manner/reply

definition.definition: sudden and not expected, often with unpleasant results
definition.example:
There was an abrupt change in her mood.
We came to an abrupt curve in the road.

definition.definition: not friendly or polite; showing little interest in talking to other people
definition.example: His abrupt manner makes me uncomfortable.
They abruptly left the party.

definition.definition: in a sudden, unexpected, and sometimes unpleasant way
definition.example:
He stood up abruptly and went outside.
The talks ended abruptly when one of the delegations walked out in protest.

definition.definition: in a way that seems rude and unfriendly, especially by using very few words when talking
definition.example:
"I don't care what you think," Audrey said abruptly.
I know I sometimes speak and act abruptly.

definition.definition: → abdominals
definition.example: exercises to tone/build up your abs

definition.definition: abbreviation for anti-lock braking system: a brake fitted to some road vehicles that prevents skidding (= uncontrolled sliding) by reducing the effects of stopping suddenly
abbreviation for American Bureau of Shipping: an organization that sets standards for the building of ships and for safety in the shipping industry:
definition.example: The ABS must approve every stage of a new vessel's life, from design to sea trials.

definition.definition: a painful swollen area on or in the body that contains pus (= thick, yellow liquid)
definition.example: She had an abscess on her gum.

definition.definition: a painful, swollen area in the body that contains pus (= a thick, yellow liquid)
the separation or falling off of part of a plant
definition.example: The flower buds and immature fruit frequently drop off; researchers have tried to determine the role growth hormones play in this abscission.

definition.definition: to go away suddenly and secretly in order to escape from somewhere
definition.example:
abscond from She absconded from boarding school and hitchhiked to the city.
Two prisoners absconded last night.

definition.definition: to go away suddenly and secretly because you have stolen something, usually money
definition.example:
abscond with They think they know who absconded with the funds from the bake sale.
abscond with humorous Someone absconded with my pen.

definition.definition: to escape and hide somewhere, esp. because you have stolen something
definition.example: They absconded with $100,000 of the company’s money.

definition.definition: the fact of not being where you are usually expected to be
definition.example:
during someone's absence A new manager was appointed during her absence.
in someone's absence I'll be gone for two weeks, with Chris handling the deliveries in my absence.
She has had repeated absences from work this year.

definition.definition: the fact of not existing
definition.example:
in the absence of In the absence of (= because there were not) more suitable candidates, we decided to offer the job to Mr Conway.
He drew attention to the absence of concrete evidence against the defendant.

definition.definition: the state of not being somewhere, or a period in which you are not somewhere
definition.example: [C] She has had repeated absences from school this year.

definition.definition: An absence can also be a lack of existence
definition.example: [U] He drew attention to the absence of any solid evidence against the defendant.
If Callie is absent from school, she should bring a note from home.
He stared out the window, absently rubbing his cheek.

definition.definition: a time when someone is not at work or at the place they are expected to be
definition.example:
absence from sth Her absence from the meeting was noted.
in sb's absence His fellow directors voted in his absence to fire him.
The worst day for workplace absences is Monday.

definition.definition: the fact that something is not where it is needed or expected
definition.example:
The business was suffering from an absence of an overall plan for moving forward.
in the absence of sth In the absence of any alternative, we'll continue in the same way as before.

definition.definition: not in the place where you are expected to be, especially at school or work
definition.example:
John has been absent from school/work for three days now.
We drank a toast to absent friends.

definition.definition: not existing
definition.example: Any sign of remorse was completely absent from her face.

definition.definition: used to describe a person or the expression on a person's face when they are thinking about other things and are not paying attention to what is happening near them
without
definition.example: Absent a detailed plan, the project was doomed from the start.

definition.definition: to not go to a place where you are expected to be, especially a school or place of work
definition.example:
You cannot choose to absent yourself (from work/school) on a whim.
With a brief apology, he absented himself from the table.
I took the opportunity to absent myself from the room.
She made a habit of absenting herself from the family.
The school is not responsible - these pupils chose to absent themselves.

definition.definition: not at work or at the place where you are expected to be
definition.example: absent from sth Anna's been absent from work for four days with flu.

definition.definition: not existing in a particular place
definition.example: absent from sth Any mention of prices is conspicuously absent from the ad, which makes me think they are high.

definition.definition: someone who is not at school or work when they should be
definition.example: There are several absentees from school this week, because a lot of people have flu.

definition.definition: to send your vote by post or by using the internet when you cannot be present to vote at an election
definition.example: We are working to make it easier for military members to vote absentee when they are deployed overseas.

definition.definition: someone who is absent
someone who is not at work or at the place where they are supposed to be
definition.example:
There are lots of absentees at the moment because of illness.
The CEO was a notable absentee from the meeting.

definition.definition: a situation in which people are not at school or work when they should be
definition.example:
The high rate of absenteeism is costing the company a lot of money.
Students with chronic absenteeism can pull down the school's performance.

definition.definition: the fact of staying away from work, especially without a good reason
definition.example:
The high levels of absenteeism at the company were caused by poor management.
work/staff absenteeism Studies show that staff absenteeism is higher on certain days of the week.

definition.definition: as if you are not paying attention to what is happening near you, and are thinking about other things
definition.example: He stared absently at his food.

definition.definition: very great or to the largest degree possible
definition.example:
a man of absolute integrity/discretion
I have absolute faith in her judgment.
There was no absolute proof of fraud.

definition.definition: used when expressing a strong opinion
definition.example:
He's an absolute idiot!
That's absolute rubbish!

definition.definition: true, right, or the same in all situations and not depending on anything else
definition.example:
an absolute law/principle/doctrine
Do you think there's such a thing as absolute truth/beauty?
in absolute terms Her contribution was better than most, but in absolute terms (= without comparing it with anything else) it was not very good.

definition.definition: An absolute ruler has unlimited power
definition.example: an absolute monarch

definition.definition: without limit, very great, or to the largest degree possible
definition.example:
She demanded absolute silence.
The day was an absolute (= complete) disaster.

definition.definition: certain; not to be doubted
definition.example: Health insurance is an absolute necessity.

definition.definition: very great or to the largest degree possible
definition.example: The board said they had absolute confidence in the CEO, despite the company's difficulties.

definition.definition: used when expressing a strong opinion
definition.example: It's an absolute disgrace!

definition.definition: the distance from zero of a number on a number line
the distance from zero of a number on a number line
completely
definition.example:
I believed/trusted him absolutely.
You must be absolutely silent or the birds won't appear.
We've achieved absolutely nothing today.

definition.definition: used for adding force to a strong adjective that is not usually used with "very" or to a verb expressing strong emotion
definition.example:
It's absolutely impossible to work with all this noise.
The food was absolutely disgusting/delicious.
I absolutely loathe/adore jazz.

definition.definition: used as a strong way of saying "yes"
definition.example: "It was an excellent film, though." "Absolutely!"

definition.definition: used as a strong way of saying "no"
definition.example: "Are you too tired to continue?" "Absolutely not!"

definition.definition: completely; beyond any doubt
definition.example:
You are absolutely right.
Are you absolutely sure that you locked the front door?

definition.definition: Absolutely is also used in conversation to show emphasis in agreeing to something
definition.example: "Can you lend me $10 till tomorrow?" "Absolutely, it’s no problem."

definition.definition: If you say absolutely not, you are showing emphasis in not agreeing to something
definition.example: "You mean you won’t sign this?" "No, absolutely not."

definition.definition: the act of forgiving someone, especially in the Christian religion, for something bad that they have done or thought
definition.example: She was granted/given absolution.

definition.definition: (especially in religion or law) to free someone from guilt, blame, or responsibility for something
definition.example:
The report absolved her from/of all blame for the accident.
The priest absolved him (of all his sins).

definition.definition: to officially remove guilt or responsibility for something wrong that someone has done or might have done
definition.example: He was absolved of all wrongdoing.

definition.definition: to take something in, especially gradually
definition.example:
Plants absorb carbon dioxide.
In cold climates, houses need to have walls that will absorb heat.
Towels absorb moisture.
The drug is quickly absorbed into the bloodstream.
Our countryside is increasingly being absorbed by/into the large cities.

definition.definition: to reduce the effect of a physical force, shock, or change
definition.example: The barrier absorbed the main impact of the crash.

definition.definition: to understand facts or ideas completely and remember them
definition.example: It's hard to absorb so much information.

definition.definition: to take up someone's attention completely
definition.example: The project has absorbed her for several years.

definition.definition: if a business absorbs the cost of something, it pays that cost easily
definition.example: The school has absorbed most of the expenses so far, but it may have to offer fewer places next year to reduce costs.

definition.definition: if one company absorbs another company, it takes control of it and they become one company
definition.example: Telecorp Holdings absorbed its Spanish subsidiary into its British headquarters.

definition.definition: to take in a liquid, gas, or chemical
definition.example:
The black clay soil around here doesn’t absorb water very well.
fig. The country has absorbed millions of immigrants over the years.

definition.definition: to completely take the attention of someone
definition.example: She was absorbed in listening to music.

definition.definition: To absorb knowledge, ideas, or information is to understand them completely and store them in your memory
definition.example: It was difficult to absorb so much information.

definition.definition: if an organization absorbs the cost of something, it pays that cost
definition.example: The law school has absorbed most of the expenses so far, but it may have to offer fewer places next year to reduce costs.

definition.definition: if one company absorbs another company in a takeover, they become one company
definition.example: Telecorp Holdings absorbed its Spanish subsidiary, Digital Corporation, into its British headquarters.

definition.definition: very interested in something and not paying attention to anything else
definition.example: Simon was so absorbed in his book that he didn't even notice me come in.

definition.definition: Something that is absorbing is very interesting and keeps your attention
definition.example: I read her last novel and found it very absorbing.

definition.definition: the process of taking something into another substance
definition.example: Some poisonous gases can enter the body by absorption through the skin.

definition.definition: complete interest in something
definition.example: Her absorption in her work is so great that she thinks about nothing else.

definition.definition: the situation in which a company pays the cost of something easily
definition.example: We can justify the company's absorption of higher manufacturing costs.

definition.definition: the situation in which one company takes control of another so that they become one company
definition.example: Reports confirmed the absorption of Kode's operations into DCM's offices.

definition.definition: the process by which a substance or object takes in a liquid, gas, waves, or chemical and makes it a part of itself
definition.example: Using a special numerical procedure, they calculated the absorption spectrum (= the range of light waves that are left when some have been absorbed by something that they passed through).

definition.definition: the condition of giving your complete attention to something
a situation in which an organization pays the cost of something
definition.example: We can justify the company's absorption of higher manufacturing costs.

definition.definition: a situation in which one company gets control of another so that they become one company
definition.example: Reports confirmed the absorption of Kode's operations into DCM 's offices.

definition.definition: to not do something, especially something enjoyable that you think might be bad
definition.example: abstain from He took a vow to abstain from alcohol/smoking/sex.

definition.definition: to decide not to use your vote
definition.example: 63 members voted in favour, 39 opposed, and 15 abstained.

definition.definition: to stay away from work
definition.example: During a recent general strike, employees of all major trade unions abstained.

definition.definition: to not do something you could do, esp. something that is unhealthy or gives you pleasure
definition.example: Some families abstain from eating fried food.

definition.definition: If you abstain from voting, you do not vote although you are permitted to vote.
not doing things that give you pleasure, especially not eating good food or drinking alcohol
the fact of not doing something, usually something that is considered harmful such as drinking alcohol or using a drug
definition.example:
We found that with abstinence from smoking, the severity of symptoms decreased.
Alcohol abstinence is recommended for breast-feeding mothers.

definition.definition: the fact of not having sex, or not having sex outside of marriage
definition.example:
Sexual health leaflets promoted the benefits of abstinence, faithfulness, and condom use.
They preach complete abstinence from premarital sex.

definition.definition: the act of not doing something, esp. something that gives you pleasure
existing as an idea, feeling, or quality, not as a material object
definition.example: Truth and beauty are abstract concepts.

definition.definition: An abstract argument or discussion is general and not based on particular examples
definition.example: This debate is becoming too abstract - let's have some hard facts!

definition.definition: general ideas
definition.example:
in the abstract So far we've only discussed the question in the abstract (= without referring to any real examples).
I have difficulty dealing with the abstract - let's discuss particular cases.

definition.definition: used to refer to a type of painting, drawing, or sculpture that uses shapes, lines, and colour in a way that does not try to represent the appearance of people or things
definition.example:
abstract art
an abstract painter

definition.definition: a short form of a speech, article, book, etc., giving only the most important facts or ideas
definition.example: There is a section at the end of the magazine that includes abstracts of recent articles/books.

definition.definition: a painting that uses shapes, lines, and colour in a way that does not try to represent the appearance of people or things
to consider something in a general way or make a general judgment after looking at particular details
definition.example:
Most interviewees focus on their own experience and do not generalize or abstract the situation.
A general rule is arrived at by abstracting from the data.

definition.definition: to remove or separate someone or something from a place or context (= the situation, facts, words, etc. that exist around something)
definition.example:
abstract someone from something It was impossible to abstract children from their social environment with all its dangers.
abstract something from something Relevant information was abstracted from the database or from medical records.

definition.definition: to give a summary or abstract (= a short description giving the most important ideas) of something
definition.example: If you find an article you think should be abstracted in our journal, submit it for consideration.

definition.definition: existing as an idea, feeling, or quality, not as a material object
definition.example: "Humanity" is an abstract idea.

definition.definition: If a statement, argument, or discussion is abstract, it is general and not based on particular examples.
A painting, drawing, or sculpture is described as abstract if it tries to represent the qualities of objects or people but does not show their outer appearance
definition.example: abstract art

definition.definition: a few sentences that give the main ideas in an article or a scientific paper
existing as an idea, feeling, or quality, not as a material object
definition.example: "Satisfaction" is difficult to measure as it is an abstract concept.

definition.definition: a shortened form of a speech, article, book, etc., giving the most important facts or ideas
definition.example: There is a section at the end of the magazine which includes abstracts of recent articles.

definition.definition: the quality of existing as or representing an idea, a feeling, etc. and not a material object, or something that has this quality
definition.example:
They discuss the issue of realism versus abstraction in sculpture.
Actual black holes have been found: they are no longer mathematical abstractions.

definition.definition: the quality of being very general and not based on real examples, or something that has this quality
definition.example:
She's always talking in abstractions.
He has a tendency towards abstraction and pretentiousness which weakens his argument.

definition.definition: the action of removing or separating something from a place or context (= the situation, facts, words, etc. that exist around something), or something that is removed like this
definition.example:
Water abstraction from rivers is increasing, due to the rise in demand and increasing population density in the region.
The quality rating is a statistical abstraction from various data sources.

definition.definition: an idea that develops by looking at or thinking about a number of different things
not known or understood by many people
definition.example: an abstruse philosophical essay

definition.definition: stupid and unreasonable, or silly in a humorous way
definition.example:
What an absurd thing to say!
Don't be so absurd! Of course I want you to come.
It's an absurd situation - neither of them will talk to the other.
Do I look absurd in this hat?

definition.definition: things that happen that are stupid or unreasonable
definition.example:
The whole situation borders on the absurd.
She has a keen sense of the absurd.

definition.definition: ridiculous or completely unreasonable
definition.example: [+ to infinitive] It is absurd for the council to cut taxes without proposing another way to raise money.
It's a serious situation but with some absurdity, and managing the balance between serious and funny is a delicate matter.

definition.definition: the quality of being stupid and unreasonable, or silly in a humorous way
definition.example:
Standing there naked, I was suddenly struck by the absurdity of the situation.
We laughed about the absurdity of the idea.

definition.definition: something that is stupid or unreasonable
definition.example:
There are all sorts of absurdities in the proposal.
The play pokes fun at the absurdities of life.

definition.definition: the situation in which there is more than enough of something
definition.example:
an abundance of There was an abundance of food at the wedding.
in abundance This team has talent in abundance.
The area has an abundance of lakes, rivers, and streams to fish in.

definition.definition: an amount that is more than enough
definition.example:
[C] We all seem to have an abundance of those plastic grocery bags.
[U] Grapes and olives grow in abundance in the valley.

definition.definition: the level of a particular element in the outer layer of the earth
more than enough
definition.example:
an abundant supply of food
There is abundant evidence that cars have a harmful effect on the environment.
Cheap consumer goods are abundant (= exist in large amounts) in this part of the world.

definition.definition: more than enough; a lot of
definition.example: It is a region with abundant natural resources.

definition.definition: in large quantities or amounts
definition.example:
The plant grows abundantly in woodland.
We all ate abundantly.

definition.definition: extremely
definition.example:
You've made your feelings abundantly clear .
Liam Brown is an abundantly talented writer.

definition.definition: very
definition.example: The solution to the problem seemed abundantly clear.

definition.definition: to use something for the wrong purpose in a way that is harmful or morally wrong
definition.example:
She is continually abusing her position/authority by getting other people to do things for her.
I never expected that he would abuse the trust I placed in him.
He fears that his brother may be abusing alcohol.

definition.definition: to treat someone cruelly or violently
definition.example:
sexually abuse The therapist works with children who have been sexually abused.
physically abuse The dog showed signs of being physically abused.
Men who abuse their partners are good at portraying themselves as the real victims.

definition.definition: to speak to someone rudely or cruelly
definition.example:
verbally abuse The athlete was being verbally abused by a drunk fan in the crowd.
The crowd started abusing him after he failed to save a goal.

definition.definition: the use of something in a way that is harmful or morally wrong
definition.example:
abuse of power The investigation revealed abuses of power committed by the governor's office.
alcohol abuse The actress disclosed that she was seeking treatment for alcohol abuse.
drug abuse Chronic drug abuse can lead to gradual brain damage.
substance abuse He had struggled with substance abuse for much of his life.
It was an abuse of her kindness to keep asking Ms Lawson for favours.

definition.definition: cruel, violent, or unfair treatment of someone
definition.example:
child abuse She claimed to have been a victim of child abuse.
physical abuse She endured physical abuse (= bad treatment) from her stepfather.
sexual abuse He was arrested for the sexual abuse of a minor.
The nasty way he treats his colleagues borders on abuse.

definition.definition: rude and offensive words said to another person
definition.example:
verbal abuse He had apparently experienced a lot of verbal abuse from his co-workers.
torrent of abuse They hurled/unleashed a torrent of abuse at the actors (= they said a lot of rude and offensive things to the actors).
term of abuse "Idiot!" is a term of abuse (= an insulting expression).
I was astonished at the stream of abuse coming from his lips.

definition.definition: bad or cruel treatment of a person or animal, or the use of something in an unsuitable or wrong way
definition.example: [U] The rescued dogs had been victims of physical abuse.

definition.definition: to treat a person or animal badly or cruelly, or to use something in the wrong way
definition.example: He was always welcome but he never abused the privilege by visiting us too often.
Providing an alcohol or drug abuser with the right treatment can cost more than $20,000.

definition.definition: a situation in which a person uses something in a bad or wrong way, especially for their own advantage or pleasure
definition.example:
The former president has been accused of corruption and abuse of power.
The politician employs his two sons to work in his office at taxpayers' expense, which critics say is an abuse of his position.
The CEO was fined for market abuse after encouraging his friends to buy shares before the takeover was announced publicly.
Employees are routinely tested for drug and alcohol abuse.

definition.definition: rude and offensive words said to another person
definition.example: He claimed he had received verbal abuse from his co-workers.

definition.definition: to use something in a bad or wrong way, especially for your own advantage or pleasure
definition.example:
The Chief Executive is accused of abusing his position by advising family members when to buy and sell shares.
Workers found to be abusing drugs or alcohol will be offered help.

definition.definition: to use rude and offensive words to another person
definition.example: Striking workers abused colleagues who continued to go into work.

definition.definition: past simple and past participle of abuse
to use something for the wrong purpose in a way that is harmful or morally wrong
definition.example:
She is continually abusing her position/authority by getting other people to do things for her.
I never expected that he would abuse the trust I placed in him.
to abuse alcohol

definition.definition: to treat someone cruelly or violently
definition.example: Several of the children had been sexually/physically/emotionally abused.

definition.definition: to speak to someone rudely or cruelly
definition.example: The crowd started abusing him after he failed to save a goal.

definition.definition: someone who treats another person in a cruel, violent, or unfair way
definition.example:
a child abuser
Both women testified against their alleged abuser.
They have begun to track down human rights abusers.

definition.definition: someone who uses something in a way that is harmful or morally wrong
definition.example:
a drug/solvent abuser
He is a reformed cocaine abuser.

definition.definition: using rude and offensive words
definition.example:
an abusive letter/phone call
He was apparently abusive to the flight attendants.

definition.definition: using physical violence or emotional cruelty
definition.example:
After many years in an abusive relationship, she left her husband.
The coach was found guilty of being abusive to young children in his care.

definition.definition: treating someone badly or cruelly, esp. physically
definition.example: He was a very strict parent, but never abusive.

definition.definition: using rude and offensive words
definition.example:
She was sacked for sending an abusive email to a colleague.
abusive calls/comments/language

definition.definition: involving bad or wrong use of something or treatment of someone, especially for your own advantage
definition.example:
The former chairman was found guilty of abusive practices and banned from buying or selling shares.
Workers complained of abusive conditions, where they were forced to work 18 hours a day.

definition.definition: If a building or area of land abuts something or on something, it is next to it or touches it on one side
definition.example:
Mexico abuts (on) some of the richest parts of the United States.
Their house abutted (onto) the police station.

definition.definition: very bad
definition.example:
abysmal working conditions
The food was abysmal.
The standard of the students' work is abysmal.

definition.definition: very deep
definition.example: titanic heights and abysmal depths

definition.definition: very bad
definition.example: This experiment could help a lot of people, or it could be an abysmal failure.

definition.definition: a very deep hole that seems to have no bottom
a difficult situation that brings trouble or destruction
definition.example:
The country is sinking/plunging into an abyss of violence and lawlessness.
