She found herself on the edge of an abyss.

definition.definition: abbreviation for alternating current: electrical current that regularly changes the direction in which it flows
abbreviation for air conditioner or air conditioning
abbreviation for academic institution: used in internet addresses that belong to academic institutions such as universities:
definition.example: www.cam.ac.uk

definition.definition: the part of society, especially universities, that is connected with studying and thinking, or the activity or job of studying
definition.example: A graduate of law, he had spent his life in academia.

definition.definition: the teaching, studying, and scientific work that happens in colleges and universities
definition.example: experts from industry, academia, and the government

definition.definition: relating to schools, colleges, and universities, or connected with studying and thinking, not with practical skills
definition.example:
academic subjects/qualifications/books
an academic institution
academic standards

definition.definition: used to describe someone who is clever and enjoys studying
definition.example: I was never a particularly academic child.

definition.definition: based on ideas and theories and not related to practical effects in real life
definition.example: a purely academic argument/question

definition.definition: someone who teaches at a college, or who studies as part of their job
the subjects that you study in high school or college
definition.example: Her son seems to prefer sports over academics.

definition.definition: relating to schools, esp. colleges and universities, or connected with studying and thinking and not with useful skills
not important because it is based only on possibilities
definition.example: Which diamond ring you like more is purely academic, because I can’t afford either one.

definition.definition: a person who teaches in a college or university
relating to schools, colleges, and universities, or connected with studying and thinking rather than practical skills
definition.example:
Employers nowadays are more interested in candidates' abilities and personality rather than just academic qualifications.
Some complain that the poor writing skills of younger staff shows a fall in academic standards.

definition.definition: interested in studying and successful at school work
definition.example: Like many entrepreneurs, he was not particularly academic at school.

definition.definition: a person who teaches at a college, or who studies as part of their job
definition.example: The research company was founded by a group of academics from Stockholm University.

definition.definition: the period of time each year when people attend school, college, or university, usually starting in September
definition.example:
He will be transferring to a new school for the next academic year.
In the academic year 2019-2020, 140,000 students were enrolled at the college.

definition.definition: a member of an academy
definition.example: In 1823 he became professor and academician at Munich.

definition.definition: an academic
an organization intended to protect and develop an art, science, language, etc., or a school that teaches a particular subject or trains people for a particular job
definition.example:
a military/police academy
the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art

definition.definition: the part of a sports club that trains young players who might one day become part of the first team (= a sports club's best team)
definition.example:
youth academy The youth academy starts training talented young players from the age of eight.
The club's academy offered players from disadvantaged backgrounds discounts on new equipment.

definition.definition: a school in the UK that is not controlled by the local authority and receives its money directly from the central government
a school that teaches a particular subject or trains people for a particular job, or an organization that supports art, literature, or science
definition.example: a military/police academy

definition.definition: one of a set of American prizes given each year to the best film, the best male or female actor in any film, and to other people involved in the production of films
one of a set of prizes given each year by a US film organization to recognize the best movie and the people involved in the best movies
to agree to do what people have asked you to do
definition.example:
He graciously acceded to our request.
It is doubtful whether the government will ever accede to the nationalists' demands for independence.

definition.definition: to become king or queen, or to take a position of power
definition.example: The diaries were written in 1837, when Queen Victoria acceded to the throne.

definition.definition: When a vehicle or its driver accelerates, the speed of the vehicle increases
definition.example: I accelerated to overtake the bus.

definition.definition: If a person or object accelerates, he, she, or it goes faster.
to happen or make something happen sooner or faster
definition.example:
Inflation is likely to accelerate this year, adding further upward pressure on interest rates.
They use special chemicals to accelerate the growth of crops.

definition.definition: to move more quickly, or to make something happen faster or sooner
definition.example: [I] He stepped on the gas and accelerated rapidly to pass a car.

definition.definition: to make something, esp. a process or a very small piece of matter, move faster
to go faster or make something go faster
definition.example:
The car can accelerate to 60 miles per hour in just 6 seconds.
Inflation is likely to accelerate this year, adding further upward pressure on interest rates.
They use chemical treatments to accelerate the growth of crops.

d_list: 20000+; GMAT; GRE; IELTS; LSAT; SAT; TOEFL

definition.definition: faster than usual
definition.example:
We need to start moving at an accelerated pace if we are going to hit the deadline.
accelerated change/development/growth

definition.definition: becoming faster
definition.example:
Arctic Ocean ice is shrinking at an accelerating rate.
With greater global mobility of people and trade goods, the spread of disease is an accelerating process.

definition.definition: the increase in something's speed, or its ability to go faster
definition.example:
An older car will have poor acceleration.
High winds significantly hampered the plane's acceleration.

definition.definition: the increase in the speed at which something happens
definition.example: The acceleration in the decline of manufacturing industry began several years ago.

definition.definition: the rate of change in the speed of something over time
the rate at which something moves more quickly or happens faster or sooner
definition.example: The car has good acceleration.

definition.definition: an increase in the speed or rate of something
definition.example:
an acceleration in sth There has been a rapid acceleration in the rate of growth of new orders.
a rapid/sharp/steady acceleration The sharp acceleration of inflation is hitting consumers hard.

definition.definition: the pedal (= a part that you push with your foot) in a vehicle that makes it go faster
in physics, a machine that makes particles (= small pieces of matter) move very fast
a company or plan that helps new companies or organizations to grow quickly and become successful
definition.example:
Start-up accelerators have become increasingly popular elements of the regional growth infrastructure.
Accelerator programmes are a relatively new way of supporting start-ups.

definition.definition: a substance that is added to other substances to speed up a chemical reaction
a device used to accelerate very small pieces of nuclear material for scientific experiments
a pedal (= part worked with the foot) in a car that makes the car go faster when pressed
something that makes a process happen or makes something progress more quickly
definition.example:
Good companies use technology as an accelerator of momentum.
In the postwar period, governments saw co-operatives as an economic accelerator.
Accelerators offer you a way to pay off your mortgage sooner by increasing the number or amount of payments.

definition.definition: the principle that investment increases as demand increases, but by greater amounts
to make something happen or progress more quickly
definition.example: This company needs someone who can put their foot on the accelerator with our excellent new products.

definition.definition: to make something happen or progress more slowly
definition.example: Insurers are taking their foot off the accelerator in anticipation of a softer market.

definition.definition: the way in which people in a particular area, country, or social group pronounce words
definition.example:
He's got a strong southern/Boston accent.
She's French but she speaks with an impeccable English accent.
He speaks with a broad/heavy/strong/thick Yorkshire accent.
I thought I could detect a slight Canadian accent.

definition.definition: a mark written or printed over a letter to show you how to pronounce it
definition.example:
a grave accent
There's an acute accent on the e of "café".

definition.definition: a special emphasis given to a particular syllable in a word, word in a sentence, or note in a set of musical notes
definition.example: The accent falls on the final syllable.

definition.definition: great importance is given to a particular thing or quality
definition.example: This season the accent is definitely on long, flowing, romantic clothes.

definition.definition: to emphasize something
definition.example:
In any advertising campaign, you must accent the areas where your product is better than the competition.
specialized Accent the first note of every bar.

definition.definition: the way in which people in a particular area or country pronounce words
definition.example: She spoke with a slight southern accent.

definition.definition: An accent is also a mark written or printed over a letter to show how to pronounce it.
a special emphasis given to a syllable in a word or to a word in a sentence
definition.example: In the word "government," the accent is on the first syllable.

definition.definition: to give special emphasis to a syllable in a word or to a word in a sentence
definition.example: In Spanish, you usually accent the next-to-last syllable.

definition.definition: influenced by the pronunciation used in a different language
definition.example:
heavily accented He spoke in heavily accented French.
Her lightly accented English is almost perfect.

definition.definition: to emphasize a particular feature of something or to make something more noticeable
definition.example:
Her dress was tightly belted, accentuating the slimness of her waist.
The new policy only serves to accentuate the inadequacy of help for the homeless.

definition.definition: to emphasize a particular feature of something or to make something more noticeable
definition.example: The short black dress accentuated her slenderness.

definition.definition: to agree to take something
definition.example:
Do you accept credit cards?
She was in Mumbai to accept an award for her latest novel.
I offered her an apology, but she wouldn't accept it.
I accept full responsibility for the failure of the plan.
The new coffee machines will accept coins of any denomination.

definition.definition: to say yes to an offer or invitation
definition.example:
We've offered her the job, but I don't know whether she'll accept it.
I've just accepted an invitation to the opening-night party.
I've been invited to their wedding but I haven't decided whether to accept.

definition.definition: to consider something or someone as satisfactory
definition.example:
The manuscript was accepted for publication last week.
She was accepted as a full member of the society.
His fellow workers refused to accept him (= to include him as one of their group).

definition.definition: to believe that something is true
definition.example:
The police refused to accept her version of the story.
He still hasn't accepted the situation (= realized that he cannot change it).
[+ that] I can't accept that there's nothing we can do.

definition.definition: to agree to take something, or to consider something as satisfactory, reasonable, or true
definition.example:
She accepted the job offer.
He was accused of accepting bribes.
Do you accept credit cards?
He refuses to accept the fact that he could be wrong.

definition.definition: If you accept an offer or an invitation, you say yes to it
definition.example: We accepted an invitation to visit China.

definition.definition: To accept is also to allow someone to become a member of an organization or group
definition.example: He was accepted by three colleges.

definition.definition: To accept is also to consider someone as now belonging to your group as an equal
definition.example: She never felt accepted by the other girls in her sorority.

definition.definition: to agree to take something
definition.example:
accept a cheque/credit card/cash Do you accept credit cards?
accept a booking/order Your order has been accepted and will be processed within 48 hours.
The buyer may refuse to accept the goods if they do not comply with the contract.
Please accept my apology for our mistake.
I accept full responsibility for the failure of the project.

definition.definition: to say yes to an offer or invitation
definition.example:
accept an offer/job/position We've offered her the job, but I don't know whether she'll accept.
Almost 80% of policyholders voted to accept the deal.
I've accepted an invitation to speak at the conference.

definition.definition: to consider something or someone as satisfactory
definition.example:
accept sb/sth as sth We are pleased to announce that we have been accepted as a full member of the Association of Consultant Engineers.
accept sth for sth The design has been accepted for production.

definition.definition: to agree to provide insurance for something or someone
definition.example: The decision by insurance underwriters to accept the risk demonstrates the strength of his case.

definition.definition: to agree to pay a bill of exchange
the quality of being satisfactory and able to be agreed to or approved of
definition.example:
There have been debates about the acceptability of genetically modified foods.
The correct accent can be a mark of social acceptability.

definition.definition: satisfactory and able to be agreed to or approved of
definition.example:
Clearly we need to come to an arrangement that is acceptable to both parties.
So what is an acceptable level of radiation?
This kind of attitude is simply not acceptable.

definition.definition: just good enough, but not very good
definition.example: Her performance was acceptable, but not stunning.

definition.definition: satisfactory; good enough
definition.example: An offer that is acceptable to the union leaders might still be voted down by the union members.

definition.definition: If behavior is acceptable, it is considered to be within the range of behavior that is permitted and is not disapproved
definition.example: In those days, it was not acceptable for men to wear shirts without ties.

definition.definition: general agreement that something is satisfactory or right, or that someone should be included in a group
definition.example:
gain acceptance The idea rapidly gained acceptance (= became approved of) in political circles.
The party marked his acceptance into the community.

definition.definition: the act of agreeing to an offer, plan, or invitation
definition.example:
Her acceptance of the award was very controversial.
an acceptance speech

definition.definition: the fact of accepting a difficult or unpleasant situation
definition.example: His attitude to his children's behaviour is one of resigned acceptance.

definition.definition: Acceptance of an offer or an invitation means that you say yes to it
definition.example: The White House indicated its acceptance of the offer to visit Russia.

definition.definition: Acceptance of a person is the act of agreeing to that person’s becoming a member of an organization or group, or to that person’s belonging to your group as an equal.
the act of agreeing to something such as an offer or invitation
definition.example:
The board has recommended acceptance of the offer.
On acceptance of the proposal, a draft agreement will be sent to both parties.

definition.definition: the act of formally agreeing to buy or sell goods at a particular price or to use something in a particular way
definition.example:
We will confirm acceptance of your order by email.
A formal letter of acceptance is sent to the successful supplier.
Placing of an order constitutes acceptance of our terms and conditions.

definition.definition: willingness of people to use a new product or service or to believe a new idea
definition.example:
gain/find/win acceptance These devices are gaining acceptance within the marketplace.
consumer/customer/public acceptance The project aims to assess consumer acceptance of GM foods.

definition.definition: an agreement by a shareholder to sell their shares to another company during a takeover
definition.example: The bidding company has received acceptances in respect of 73.27% of the issued shares.

definition.definition: an act of agreeing to pay a bill of exchange (= a written order to pay someone a particular amount of money) by writing your name on the document, or the document itself
definition.example: In essence, an acceptance is a promise to pay.

definition.definition: an agreement or contract between an insurance company and a customer to provide insurance
definition.example: This life insurance plan offers guaranteed acceptance for the over 50s.

definition.definition: approval of a new machine, computer system, etc. after testing it to check that it works correctly
definition.example: A number of acceptance tests were performed.

definition.definition: the method or possibility of getting near to a place or person
definition.example:
The only access to the village is by boat.
The main access to (= entrance to) the building is at the side.
The children's father was refused access to them at any time (= refused official permission to see them).

definition.definition: the right or opportunity to use or look at something
definition.example:
The system has been designed to give the user quick and easy access to the required information.
gain access to We were able to gain access to the safe.
have access to Hackers had complete access to the company files.

definition.definition: to be able to get to or get inside a place
definition.example:
It is too difficult for anyone using a wheelchair to access the building.
Students need a card to access restricted areas such as residences and labs.
The basement room is accessed from outside.

definition.definition: to be able to use or obtain something such as a service
definition.example:
Older people may have difficulty accessing medical services.
It needs to be easier for small businesses to access government resources and advice.

definition.definition: to open a computer file, a website, etc. in order to look at or change information in it
definition.example:
Most people use their phones to access the internet.
You have to enter a password to access the database.
A hacker remotely accessed the company's servers (= was able to look at information stored on the company's servers using a computer located in a different place).

definition.definition: the method or way of approaching a place or person, or the right to use or look at something
definition.example: Without an official pass, the guards will deny you access to (= will not let you enter) the courthouse.

definition.definition: Access to something can also mean the opportunity or ability to use it
definition.example: Many of the families do not have access to health care.

definition.definition: to get information, esp. when using a computer
definition.example: People now can access information from the Internet as never before.

definition.definition: the right or opportunity to use or receive something
definition.example:
get/have/provide access to sth Community radio stations have access to public funding.
Everyone is entitled to fair access to employment.

definition.definition: the right or ability to look at documents and information
definition.example:
allow/grant/give sb access to sth She was granted access to the official archives.
gain access to sth You can gain access to your records via this website.
deny/restrict access to sth They planned to restrict access to their website content with the use of a subscription system.
Merchants have online access to their product data.
Auditors have unrestricted access to all records.

definition.definition: the ability to use a system such as the internet, or the way in which you can do this
definition.example:
access to sth Do you have access to the internet?
Business travellers expect free internet access.
broadband/wireless access

definition.definition: the method or possibility of getting to or entering a place
definition.example:
access to sth The site has easy access to the motorway.
The premises are equipped for disabled access.

definition.definition: the right or ability to buy and sell goods in a particular country or market
definition.example: access to sth Our website gives us access to global markets.

definition.definition: the right to use a bank account, or to remove money from a bank account or an investment
definition.example: access to sth Some accounts allow instant access to your savings.

definition.definition: the legal right to see your child or children, or other family member, especially after a divorce
definition.example: access to sb Many fathers go to court to seek access to their children.

definition.definition: to open a computer file or to use a computer system such as the internet
definition.example:
Many users now access the internet via their mobile phones.
I can access my email remotely.

definition.definition: to look at a bank account, and be able to move money into or out of it
definition.example: You can access your account online or by phone.

definition.definition: to be able to get or use something, especially a service
definition.example: We advise staff on how to access appropriate training.

definition.definition: the fact of being able to be reached or obtained easily
definition.example:
Two new roads are being built to increase accessibility to the town centre.
The accessibility of online information is an important consideration.

definition.definition: the quality of being able to be entered or used by everyone, including people who have a disability
definition.example:
The theater offers full wheelchair accessibility.
We carried out a full audit of the office building's accessibility.

definition.definition: the quality of being easy to understand or enjoy
definition.example:
The accessibility of her plays means that she is able to reach a wide audience.
The quality and accessibility of materials have to be high if there are to be no barriers to learning.

definition.definition: the quality or characteristic of something that makes it possible to approach, enter, or use it
definition.example:
Touch-screen voting machines meet the requirements for accessibility to people with disabilities.
Accessibility is one of the most important aspects of textual analysis.

definition.definition: the ability to get something easily
definition.example:
We aim to improve the accessibility of our service to young people.
Features have been added to enhance the accessibility of the website.

definition.definition: the ability to reach or enter a place or building
definition.example: The new offices provide better accessibility for wheelchairs.

definition.definition: the fact of a person being willing to see people and of being friendly and easy to talk to
definition.example: He is known for his accessibility and personal involvement in the day-to-day running of the business.

definition.definition: able to be reached or easily obtained
definition.example:
The resort is easily accessible by road, rail, and air.
The building has fast internet accessible to subscribers.
The problem with some of these drugs is that they are so very accessible.

definition.definition: able to be entered or used by everyone, including people who use a wheelchair, people who are blind, etc.
definition.example:
They agreed to build more affordable and accessible housing.
All the toilets are fully accessible.

definition.definition: easy to understand or enjoy
definition.example:

definition.definition: an abbreviation consisting of the first letters of each word in the name of something, pronounced as a word

definition.definition: a word created from the first letters of each word in a series of words
definition.example: NASA is an acronym for National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

definition.definition: an abbreviation consisting of the first letters of each word in the name of something, pronounced as a word
definition.example: an acronym for sth PIPE is an acronym for private-investment, public-equity.

definition.definition: fear of heights
from one side to the other of something with clear limits, such as an area of land, a road, or a river
definition.example:
She walked across the field/road.
They're building a new bridge across the river.
When I reached the river, I simply swam across.

definition.definition: on the opposite side of
definition.example: The library is just across the road.

definition.definition: in every part of a particular place or country
definition.example: Voting took place peacefully across most of the country.

definition.definition: from one side to the other side of, or at the other side of
definition.example:
We walked across the bridge.
She was sitting across the aisle.
He opened a store across the street from the theater.
Over 300,000 refugees fled across the border.

definition.definition: If something is happening across the country, it is happening in all parts of the country.
affecting everyone or everything within an organization, system, or society
definition.example: The proposed across-the-board cuts for all state agencies will total $84 million.

definition.definition: having an effect on everyone or everything of a particular type
definition.example: The mayor threatened across-the-board spending cuts.

definition.definition: involving everyone or everything in a company, situation, group, etc.
definition.example:
an across-the-board cut/decline/reduction This economic plan calls for a 15% across-the-board cut in personal income tax rates
an across-the-board increase/raise/rise

definition.definition: in a way that involves everyone or everything in a company, situation, group etc.
definition.example:
be/apply across the board These sales increases are across the board in most of our important product areas and in all four business segments.
rise/fall across the board

definition.definition: a type of cloth or plastic produced by chemical processes
a type of paint
made of a substance or cloth produced by chemical processes from a type of acid
definition.example:
an acrylic scarf/sweater
acrylic paint

definition.definition: of or made from a type of acid or a resin (= chemically produced sticky substance) which is used in making plastic, cloth, and paint
definition.example:
acrylic paint
They used acrylic yarn for the sweaters.

He paints with acrylics.
Synthetic materials like nylon, acrylic, and polyester can retain heat.

definition.definition: to behave in the stated way
definition.example:
act like Don't be so silly - you're acting like a child!
He acted as if he'd never met me before.

definition.definition: to do something for a particular purpose or to solve a problem
definition.example:
[+ to infinitive] Engineers acted quickly to repair the damaged pipes.
act for Who is acting for the defendant?
act on behalf of The agent was acting on behalf of (= representing) her client, a Broadway actress.
She acted without thinking.

definition.definition: to have an effect
definition.example: The anaesthetic acted quickly.

definition.definition: to perform a part in a film, play, etc.
definition.example:
Ellis Pike was chosen to act the part of the lawyer in the film.
Have you ever acted in a play before?

definition.definition: to behave in a particular, usually bad, way
definition.example: Why are you always acting the fool?

definition.definition: something that you do
definition.example:
an act of aggression/bravery/madness/terrorism
simple act The simple act of telling someone about a problem can help.
a kind/thoughtless/selfish act
artistic representations of the sexual act

definition.definition: behaviour that hides your real feelings or intentions
definition.example: Was she really upset or was that just an act?

definition.definition: a person or group that performs a short piece in a show, or the piece that they perform
definition.example:
a comedy/juggling/trapeze act
Our next act is a very talented young musician.

definition.definition: a part of a play or opera
definition.example:
Shakespeare's plays were written in five acts.
The hero does not enter until the second act/Act Two.

definition.definition: a law or formal decision made by a parliament or other group of people who make the laws for their country
definition.example:
an Act of Parliament
the Betting and Gaming Act
Almost two hundred suspects were detained in the UK last year under the Prevention of Terrorism Act.
The state legislature passed an act banning the sale of automatic weapons.

definition.definition: to do something for a particular purpose or in a particular way
definition.example:
[+ to infinitive] The president acted quickly to bring federal aid to areas damaged by flooding.
She acted responsibly.
He acted as if he’d never seen me before.
She acted as (= performed in the position of) a tour guide for the group.
He said he was acting on (= doing something as a result of) the advice of his lawyer.

definition.definition: to perform in a movie, play, or television show
definition.example:
[T] He acts the part of a small-town lawyer.
[I] She has acted in lots of television sitcoms.

definition.definition: a law made by Congress or another legislature
definition.example: an act of Congress

definition.definition: one of a set of short performances that are parts of a show, or the person or group who performs one of these parts
definition.example:
a circus act
fig. His story is just an act (= is pretended and not sincere).

definition.definition: An act is also one of the main parts of a play or opera
definition.example: The play is presented in three acts.

definition.definition: something that someone does
definition.example:
A partner may be held responsible for the acts of his co-partners committed in the name of the firm.
He has led an investigation into stock market manipulation and various illegal acts and swindles.

definition.definition: a law or formal decision made by a parliament or other group of elected law-makers
definition.example: The 2010 act, with its requirement for a review of financial controls, has helped drive up the cost of corporate audits by as much as 50%.

definition.definition: to be so good that it is unlikely that anyone or anything that comes after will be as good
definition.example: The company could lose momentum without its chief executive, who will be a hard act to follow.

definition.definition: to take advantage of or become involved with something that someone else started
definition.example: There's always a debate in the machine room about the product, long before the marketing men and editors get in on the act.

definition.definition: to organize yourself so that you do things in an effective way
definition.example: Mr Dinsdale said it was crucial that the Department of Trade & Industry got its act together.

definition.definition: to do something with the intention of achieving a particular result
definition.example:
act to do sth Engineers will need to act quickly to repair the damaged pipes.
act quickly/swiftly/now Anyone who wants a fixed-rate deal should act now.
act decisively/improperly/responsibly It is now time for management to act decisively.
act against/in sb's interests There were claims that the management was acting against shareholders' interests.
Members should act in the best interests of the company.

definition.definition: to do something believing that it is the right thing to do
definition.example: Although errors of judgement were made, at all times the company's staff acted in good faith.

definition.definition: to do a particular job, especially one that you do not normally do
definition.example: He was asked to act as an adviser on the project.

definition.definition: to have a particular effect
definition.example: Some people say that capital punishment acts as a deterrent.

definition.definition: to do a particular job, especially one that you do not normally do
definition.example: She has been asked to act as a negotiator on behalf of the factory.

definition.definition: to have a particular effect
definition.example: The launch of the new investment trust will act as a support for this market.

definition.definition: to do something as a reaction to a particular thing such as an instruction, a feeling, or some information
definition.example:
There is no point soliciting feedback if you never act on it.
Acting on a tip-off, police carried out a search of the premises.
Share prices rose as investors acted on the news.
Unless he starts acting on these fantasies they remain harmless.
act on impulse Acting on impulse (= without thinking first) can get you into a lot of trouble.

definition.definition: to do something because you have been advised or told to do it
definition.example:
There have been concerns as to why the Board didn't act on a recommended pay raise.
act on findings/information/advice The board of directors will act on the findings in the report.

definition.definition: to be a better actor than someone else; to give a better performance in a film, play, etc. than other people
definition.example:
It is embarrassing that the non-human performers in this film out-act the human stars.
Supporting actors need to be careful not to out-act the stars.

definition.definition: the job of performing in films or plays
definition.example: He wants to get into acting.

definition.definition: someone who does a job for a short time while the person who usually does that job is not there
definition.example: He'll be the acting director until they can appoint a permanent one.

definition.definition: temporarily performing someone else's duties
definition.example: Ms. Lopez-Smith will be the acting treasurer.

definition.definition: doing a job for a short time while the person who usually does that job is not there
definition.example: acting chairman/director/president Fisher will serve as acting director while a search is under way to name a permanent director

definition.definition: the process of doing something, especially when dealing with a problem or difficulty
definition.example:
This problem calls for swift/prompt action from the government.
[+ to infinitive] Action to prevent the spread of the disease is high on the government's agenda.
plan of action So what's the plan of action? (= What are we going to do?)
swing into action The complaints system swings into action (= starts to work) as soon as a claim is made.
take action We must take action (= do something) to deal with the problem before it spreads to other areas.
The committee was spurred into action (= encouraged to do something) by the threat of government cuts.

definition.definition: something that you do
definition.example:
She has to accept the consequences of her actions.
I asked him to explain his actions.

definition.definition: a physical movement
definition.example:
I'll say the words and you can mime the actions.
It only needs a small wrist action (= movement of the wrist) to start the process.

definition.definition: things that are happening, especially exciting or important things
definition.example:
I like movies with a lot of action.
In her last novel, the action (= the main events) moves between Greece and southern Spain.

definition.definition: a style of film in which a lot of exciting and often violent things happen
definition.example:
His filmmaking style blends action, horror, and comedy.
The action genre is often assumed to appeal more to men.

definition.definition: at the place where something important or interesting is happening
definition.example: A journalist has to be where the action is.

definition.definition: the effect something has on another thing
definition.example: They recorded the action of the drug on the nervous system.

definition.definition: fighting in a war
definition.example:
see action He saw action in the trenches.
Her younger son was killed in action.

definition.definition: A soldier or other member of the armed forces who is missing in action cannot be found after a battle or other military action, so it is not possible to say if they are dead or alive.
definition.example: He was reported missing in action.

definition.definition: the way something moves or works
definition.example:
We studied the action of the digestive system.
The car has a very smooth braking action.

definition.definition: a legal process that is decided in a law court
definition.example:
bring an action She brought an action (for negligence) against the hospital.
The book was halted in South Africa by a threat of legal action.
a libel action
A criminal action was brought against him.

definition.definition: to do something to deal with a particular problem or matter
definition.example: I'll just run through the minutes of the last meeting, raising those points that still have to be actioned.

definition.definition: the process of doing something, or something done, esp. for a particular purpose
definition.example:
[U] Quick action in calling the fire department saved many lives.
[C] It was a reckless action which he later came to regret.
[+ to infinitive] We want a leader who will take action to fix our problems.
[U] Financial advisers urged the city to take action (= do something) to deal with the fiscal crisis.

definition.definition: Action is also fighting in a war
definition.example: [U] Her younger son was killed in action.

definition.definition: In an action film/movie, there is usually a lot of violence and many exciting things happen.
the way something moves or works, or the effect it has on something else
definition.example: [C] The heart’s action in regulating blood flow is critically important.

definition.definition: a process in a court of law to correct a wrong by which a person or group claims to have been hurt
definition.example: [C] She brought an action against the hospital for negligence.

definition.definition: the process of doing something, especially in order to deal with a problem or difficult situation
definition.example:
take action (to do sth) The report urged industrialised nations to take further action to cut their budget deficits.
action on sth Campaigners say more action is needed on climate change.
call/press for action Unions are pressing for action on the pay dispute.
decisive/drastic/prompt action
The committee was spurred into action by the threat of government cuts.
You need to clearly outline a specific course of action in your business plan.

definition.definition: something that you do, especially in order to deal with a problem or difficult situation
definition.example:
Industry analysts said the company's actions cannot control market prices.
He said that employees must be held accountable for their actions.

definition.definition: important things that are happening in a market, etc.
definition.example: Fund managers let themselves be carried away by the favorable market action of the shares.

definition.definition: a legal process that is decided in a court of law
definition.example:
civil/court/legal action He threatened legal action to recover the property.
bring an action against sb/sth The purchaser could have brought an action against the vendor under section 12 of the Sale of Goods Act.

definition.definition: to begin working to make an idea or a plan happen or be successful
definition.example: We need to put these plans into action in measurable ways, so that employees regain a sense of control over their lives.

definition.definition: a way of dealing with a problem or difficult situation, or achieving something
definition.example: The Board will devise an action plan to address the problems at the plant.

definition.definition: involvement in something successful that someone else has started
definition.example: It's one thing to be a staff attorney and quite another to be an equity partner getting a piece of the action.

definition.definition: to do something to deal with a particular task, problem, or plan
definition.example: Some of the conclusions and recommendations of the report can be actioned straight away.

definition.definition: If something is actionable, it gives someone a good reason for accusing someone in a law court
definition.example: She denies that her company has been involved in any actionable activity.

definition.definition: giving someone a good reason for accusing someone else in a court of law
definition.example: actionable in/under sth His failure to deliver the work would surely be actionable under law as a breach of contract.

definition.definition: able to be used as a reason for doing something
definition.example: actionable information/intelligence

definition.definition: to cause something to start
definition.example: The alarm is activated by the lightest pressure.

definition.definition: to make a chemical reaction happen more quickly, especially by heating
to cause something to start working
definition.example: Something activated the car alarm.

definition.definition: In sports, to activate a player is to bring that player back to the regular team after an injury.
to make something start working or happening
definition.example:
New customers must call an automated line to activate their card.
The move will activate a clause in the contract which gives the company the option to sell or demand the outstanding £3.5m owed on the deal.

definition.definition: past simple and past participle of activate
to cause something to start
definition.example: The alarm is activated by the lightest pressure.

definition.definition: to make a chemical reaction happen more quickly, especially by heating
the act of making something start or making it start working
definition.example:
The false activation of an alarm is a serious matter.
You will be sent an account activation email.

definition.definition: busy with a particular activity
definition.example:
remain active He is 90 years old, but remains active in the local community.
stay active The goal of our organization is to make sure that people stay active.
keep active You have to try to keep active as you grow older.
physically/mentally active

definition.definition: involved in a particular activity
definition.example:
active in She's very active in (= involved in) local politics.
Enemy forces remain active in the mountainous areas around the city.
politically active Both of his parents were very politically active.
sexually active It is important to educate children before they become sexually active.
take an active role in He takes an active role in the team nowadays.
play an active role in The family plays an active role in the local community.
active member She's an active member of her trade union (= not only belongs to it, but does work to help it).

definition.definition: An active volcano is one that might erupt (= throw out hot liquid rock or other matter) at any time.
An active verb or sentence is one in which the subject is the person or thing that performs the stated action
definition.example: "Catrin told me" is an active sentence, and "I was told by Catrin" is passive.

definition.definition: → the active voice
doing something as you usually do, or being able to do something physically or mentally
definition.example:
He was still an active runner at 55.
She’s active in state politics (= involved in it).
She intends to remain politically active.
His National Guard unit was put on active duty (= made part of the regular fighting force).

definition.definition: An active volcano is one that might begin to throw out hot gases, liquid, or rocks at any time.
describing a verb or sentence in which the subject is the person or thing that does what is stated
definition.example: In "Alex gave me a gift," the verb "give" is active, and in "I was given a gift by Alex," "give" is passive.
He isn’t actively involved in the day-to-day management of the business anymore.

definition.definition: busy with or involved in a particular activity
definition.example:
active in sth He expects to remain active in commodity trading in London.
She claims to be active in almost every aspect of her business.

definition.definition: doing something practical rather than allowing a situation to develop by itself
definition.example:
an active member/participant He has been an active member of the Executive Committee since 2004.
an active part/role Employees who take an active part in the project feel more involved and more responsible about the results.
active participation/intervention
active in sth We would expect countries whose firms are highly globalized to be more active in adopting e-commerce.

definition.definition: involving a lot of buying and selling of shares, etc.
definition.example:
active buying/trading Trading was most active in five-year maturities.
The session was active early, but volume dropped off after midday.
This made Intel the second-most active stock in U.S. trading.

definition.definition: used to describe a company that is selling goods and services or doing business, especially in a particular place
definition.example:
Whitbread was especially active but several other brewers were also buying at the rate of 20 or 30 a year.
be active in sth The company is active in a wide range of businesses, including oil, chemicals, and construction.
Over the last ten years, the company has become active in Europe.

definition.definition: working or being used at a particular time
definition.example:
active accounts/cardholders/customers The company has more than one million active cardholders, with about 44% of all group sales being made through the card.
active employees/members
The organization releases a weekly survey of the number of active oil and gas drilling rigs in the U.S. and Canada.

definition.definition: relating to programs, etc. that are being used at a particular time
definition.example: Click the associated tab in a bar running across the screen, and the selected page opens in the active window.

definition.definition: in a way that involves positive action
definition.example:
He's very actively involved in (= does a lot of work for) the local party.
It's nice having a man who actively encourages me to spend money.
I've been actively looking for a job for six months.

definition.definition: the use of direct and noticeable action to achieve a result, usually a political or social one
definition.example:
black/student activism
The levels of political activism in this country have greatly declined.

definition.definition: the use of direct and public methods to try to bring about esp. social and political changes that you and others want
definition.example: political/social activism
a civil-rights activist

definition.definition: a person who believes strongly in political or social change and takes part in activities such as public protests to try to make this happen
definition.example:
He's been a trade union/party activist for many years.
an animal rights activist

definition.definition: the situation in which a lot of things are happening or people are moving around
definition.example:
economic activity Economists are concerned by the low level of economic activity.
business activity Experts predict that this could depress business activity for years.
flurry of activity There was a sudden flurry of activity when the director walked in.
There was a lot of activity in preparation for the Queen's visit.

definition.definition: the work of a group or organization to achieve an aim
definition.example:
He was found guilty of terrorist activity.
criminal activities

definition.definition: something that is done for enjoyment, especially an organized event
definition.example:
His spare-time activities include cooking, tennis, and windsurfing.
We offer our guests a wide range of outdoor/sporting activities.

definition.definition: the doing of something, or something that you are doing, have done, or could do
definition.example:
[C] There were lots of activities for children at the museum.
[C] Her favorite activity is visiting antique shops.
[U] Carbon dioxide is also produced by human activity.

definition.definition: a situation in which a lot of things are happening or being done
definition.example:
business/commercial/economic activity Any conflict has the potential to disrupt business activity.
manufacturing/marketing/trading activity
boost/increase activity This package of tax cuts and spending increases is designed to boost economic activity over the next year.
The increased level of activity in our principal markets flattened out during the first half of this year.

definition.definition: the work of a person, group, or organization to achieve something, especially to make money
definition.example:
The company's activities stretch from Australia to the US.
We invest primarily in companies which have their principal business activities in the Pacific Basin.
manufacturing/marketing/management activities

definition.definition: a woman who pretends to be someone else while performing in a film, play, or television programme
definition.example: She's the highest-paid actress in Hollywood.

definition.definition: to behave in the stated way
definition.example:
act like Don't be so silly - you're acting like a child!
He acted as if he'd never met me before.

[+ to infinitive] Engineers acted quickly to repair the damaged pipes.
act for Who is acting for the defendant?
act on behalf of The agent was acting on behalf of (= representing) her client, a Broadway actress.

definition.definition: to do something with the intention of achieving a particular result

act to do sth Engineers will need to act quickly to repair the damaged pipes.

act against/in sb's interests There were claims that the management was acting against shareholders' interests.

definition.definition: to do something believing that it is the right thing to do
definition.example: Although errors of judgement were made, at all times the company's staff acted in good faith.

definition.definition: existing in fact
definition.example:
We had estimated about 300 visitors, but the actual number was much higher.
The exams are in July, but the actual results (= the results themselves) don't appear until September.

definition.definition: really
definition.example: I thought she was Portuguese, but in actual fact she's Brazilian.

definition.definition: real; existing in fact
definition.example: We expected 50 people, but the actual number was a lot higher.

definition.definition: true or exact
definition.example:
actual amount/cost/figure Residents are paying electricity prices that are double the actual cost of generating electricity.
There is a gap between desired and actual performance.
actual sales/results

definition.definition: real, rather than part of an idea or plan
definition.example: He's had a lot of interviews, but never had an actual job.

definition.definition: real, not on the internet
definition.example: The actual stores offer local convenience while the virtual stores offer variety for shoppers.

definition.definition: an amount of money that a company really spends, rather than an amount of money that it plans or expects to spend
definition.example: We continuously compare budgeted amounts with actuals.

definition.definition: something that physically exists such as oil, metal, grain, or coffee that is traded on the stock market
definition.example: Transactions can be trade in actuals or by means of futures contracts.

definition.definition: a fact
definition.example: He's out of touch with the actualities of life in Africa.

definition.definition: really
definition.example: In actuality, there were few job losses last year.

definition.definition: in fact or really
definition.example:
I didn't actually see her - I just heard her voice.
So what actually happened?

definition.definition: used in sentences in which there is information that is in some way surprising or the opposite of what most people would expect
definition.example:
I didn't like him at first, but in the end I actually got quite fond of him.
I'm one of the few people who doesn't actually like champagne.
humorous Don't tell me he actually paid for you!

definition.definition: used as a way of making a sentence slightly more polite, for example when you are expressing an opposing opinion, correcting what someone else has said, or refusing an offer
definition.example:
"Alexander looks like he'd be good at sports." "Actually, he's not."
Actually, Gavin, it was Tuesday of last week, not Wednesday.
"Do you mind if I smoke?" "Well, actually, I'd rather you didn't."

definition.definition: used to say that something is true, esp. when the true situation may not be known
definition.example: We actually had a hard time moving the sofa.

definition.definition: Actually is often used when you want to emphasize that something is surprising or unusual
definition.example: He actually expected me to pay for his dinner.

definition.definition: relating to the work of an actuary, or to the job of being an actuary
definition.example:
These figures are based on actuarial calculations of the risks involved.
actuarial jobs

definition.definition: relating to calculations of risk for insurance companies and pension funds, especially calculations of the age to which people are expected to live. The companies and funds use the results to make certain that they always have enough money to make payments to the people who have a right to them
definition.example:
Companies currently use actuarial assumptions to determine whether their pension fund shows a surplus or a deficit.
an actuarial calculation/assessment/evaluation

definition.definition: relating to the job of being an actuary
definition.example:
The debate is dividing the actuarial profession.
an actuarial adviser/consultant
an actuarial firm/consultancy
actuarial work/advice/skills

definition.definition: a person who calculates how likely accidents, such as fire, flood, or loss of property, are to happen, and tells insurance companies how much they should charge their customers

a person whose job is to calculate risk for insurance companies and pension funds, especially the age to which people are expected to live. The companies and funds use the results to make certain that they always have enough money to make payments to the people who have a right to them
