adjudicate between sb and sb It is the duty of government to adjudicate between the conflicting demands of different sections of society.

definition.definition: to legally and officially state that a person, company, or organization cannot pay its debts
definition.example: The operator of the steel plant was adjudicated bankrupt by the regional court on July 7.

definition.definition: something added or connected to a larger or more important thing
definition.example: I hoped I would find the computer course a useful adjunct to my other studies.

definition.definition: In grammar, an adjunct is an adverb or phrase that gives extra information in a sentence.
something added or connected to something larger or more important
definition.example: Canada’s economy is not an adjunct to the US’s but rather is expanding on its own.

definition.definition: An adjunct is also a temporary teacher at a college or university
definition.example: adjunct professors/faculty

definition.definition: something that is added or connected to a larger or more important thing
definition.example: an adjunct to sth Green, socially conscious concepts are not an adjunct to its main business, but a philosophy that works its way into everything it does.

definition.definition: the act of asking or ordering someone to do something
definition.example:
The poem expresses the adjuration "Love one another."
His adjurations about what we should and should not eat can appear ridiculous.

definition.definition: to ask or order someone to do something
definition.example: The judge adjured him to answer truthfully.

definition.definition: to change something slightly, especially to make it more correct, effective, or suitable
definition.example:
If the chair is too high you can adjust it to suit you.
As a teacher you have to adjust your methods to suit the needs of slower children.

definition.definition: to arrange your clothing to make yourself look tidy
definition.example: She adjusted her skirt, took a deep breath, and walked into the room.

definition.definition: to become more familiar with a new situation
definition.example:
I can't adjust to living on my own.
Her eyes slowly adjusted to the dark.
The lifestyle is so very different - it takes a while to adjust.

definition.definition: to change something slightly to make it fit, work better, or be more suitable
definition.example:
[T] Adjust the angle of your monitor so you can easily read it.
[I] You need time to adjust to a new situation.
The height of the steering wheel is adjustable.
[C] Only a few adjustments were needed to make her dress fit perfectly.

definition.definition: to change something slightly to make it fit, work better, or be more suitable
definition.example:
You may need to adjust the image on your screen to keep it centered.
They fail to update information on an ongoing basis and adjust sales strategies accordingly.
Contractors have been slow to adjust their recruiting strategies to take account of these changes.

definition.definition: to change figures slightly according to inflation, the time of year, etc. so that they can be compared in a useful way with other figures
definition.example:
adjust sth for sth Payouts from the fund, when adjusted for inflation, are 20% less today than they were 10 years ago.
The region's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate was 8.9% this spring.

definition.definition: to become more familiar with a new situation
definition.example: adjust to sth Restaurant owners will get additional time to adjust to the new regulations.

definition.definition: to decide how much money will be paid to an insurance customer or to pay them the money
definition.example: adjust a claim We adjust flood-related claims according to general company and industry standards.

definition.definition: able to be changed to suit particular needs
definition.example:
The height of the steering wheel is adjustable.
Is the strap on this helmet adjustable?

definition.definition: something that is adjustable can be changed according to how something else changes or in order to make it more suitable
definition.example:
This office chair has an adjustable seat and back.
Homebuyers with risky credit ratings were able to get mortgages with adjustable interest rates offering low monthly payments to start with.

definition.definition: a small change
definition.example: She made a few minor adjustments to the focus of her camera.

definition.definition: the ability to become more familiar with a new situation
definition.example: He has so far failed to make the adjustment from school to work.

definition.definition: a slight change made to something to make it fit, work better, or be more suitable, or the act of making such a change
definition.example:
A small adjustment at the right place can make a significant difference.
If the colour does not appear quite right, check your monitor settings for adjustment.
adjustment to sth The final plan will serve as an adjustment to the two-year budget approved last year.

definition.definition: a slight change to figures according to inflation, the time of year, etc. so that they can be compared in a useful way with other figures, or the act of making such a change
definition.example:
adjustment to sth The finance minister will again delay the inflation adjustment to excise duty on petrol.
adjustment for sth The population has been split into 10 equal groups, ranked by income, after adjustment for family size.

definition.definition: the process of becoming more familiar with a new situation
definition.example: make an adjustment This is a very, very big adjustment for us to make.

definition.definition: the job of getting information about an accident, theft, etc. in order to decide how much money to pay an insurance customer
definition.example: There was a breach in the insurance companies' adjustment and payment.

definition.definition: the amount of money that an insurance company pays to a customer who has been involved in an accident, had something stolen, etc.
definition.example: After calculating what the adjustment should have been, they analyse how the insurance company adjustments deviated from reality.

definition.definition: a military officer who does office work and who is responsible for rules and punishment among the lower ranks
to control the operation or arrangement of something
definition.example:
The economy has been badly administered by the present government.
The local council employed five people to administer the programme.
The firm appointed to administrate the failed bank asked us to continue paying our mortgage.

definition.definition: to govern a country, region, etc.
definition.example:
This government will not content itself with administering and governing the people.
India has 28 states and seven federally administered territories.

definition.definition: to cause someone to receive something
definition.example:
be administered to Tests will be administered to schoolchildren at seven and twelve years.
administer something to someone Doctors must use care when administering the vaccine to elderly patients.
to administer medicine/punishment/relief
figurative The latest opinion polls have administered a severe blow to the party.

definition.definition: to be present while someone says an oath (= a formal promise) officially
definition.example: The Court will not administer an oath to a witness who is drunk.

definition.definition: to manage or control the operation of something; govern
definition.example: The British administered Hong Kong for 99 years.

definition.definition: to be responsible for giving something to someone
definition.example:
Two proctors administered the exam.
She administers medicines to patients.

definition.definition: to give something to someone
definition.example:
administer drugs/a test The medication was administered by someone in another room.
administer justice/a punishment It's up to the courts to administer justice.
administer advice/help Training and Enterprise Councils in the rest of Britain are administering a range of help such as youth training.
administer sth to sb This drug should not be administered to the very young.

definition.definition: to manage or deal with a business activity
definition.example:
The cost to administer the program was $70,000.
My job is to administer bookings.

definition.definition: the arrangements and tasks needed to control the operation of a plan or organization
definition.example: Teachers complain that more of their time is taken up with administration than with teaching.

definition.definition: the people in an organization who manage its business and operations
definition.example: The decision to cancel the trip was made by the school administration.

definition.definition: a period of government, or the people who are in government
definition.example: the Obama administration/the last Republican administration

definition.definition: the act of giving someone something
definition.example: There are strict controls on the administration of drugs.

definition.definition: the process that takes place when a company cannot pay its debts and is allowed to make changes to its organization to try to avoid going into liquidation (= when a business is closed and the things it owns are sold)
definition.example: go into administration The company has gone into administration, in order for money to be returned to creditors.

definition.definition: the management or control of an organization
definition.example: [U] He’s studying business administration.

definition.definition: An administration in the US is the period when a President is in office
definition.example: [C] The Clinton administration has been full of surprises.

definition.definition: An administration is also all of the officials working in a government's executivebranch .

definition.example: You will do mainly administrative work.
Matthews said charges against him should be handled administratively.
She works as a school administrator.

definition.definition: the activity of managing or dealing with a business activity
definition.example:
Administration of the scheme is costly in terms of time.
She studied business administration at New York University.

definition.definition: → admin
the people who manage and control a large organization
definition.example:
Some foreign postal administrations, including Britain's and France's, have embraced the concept.
Will medical school administrations and faculty be happy to adopt a large increase in class size?

definition.definition: the government of the United States or of some other countries
definition.example:
It seems like there's an effort to centralize authority in Washington more than there has been in prior administrations.
the Obama/Bush/Nixon Administration

definition.definition: a situation in which an independent administrator takes control of a company that cannot pay its debts in order to try to improve the company's financial situation and keep it operating
definition.example:
The company has gone into administration, which was required if any money was to be returned to creditors.
His business empire continues to trade and is not in administration.

definition.definition: relating to the arrangements and work that is needed to control the operation of a plan or organization
definition.example:
administrative work
an administrative problem
Your responsibilities will be mainly administrative.

definition.definition: relating to the organization and structure of local government
definition.example:
Brittany is a cultural and administrative region in the north-west of France.
The villages had been omitted because they fell outside the administrative boundary of the region.

definition.definition: relating to the laws that control local government
definition.example:
In several countries, administrative law is distinguished from constitutional law by being concerned purely with matters of public administration.
Review by an administrative tribunal is generally to determine whether a decision taken by an executive authority breaches procedural rules.

definition.definition: relating to the work of managing or organizing a business or business activity
definition.example:
Flexitime work can be an administrative nightmare for management.
The study looks at capital, maintenance, and administrative costs.
We will provide financial and administrative support to member companies.
administrative work/duties
administrative staff

definition.definition: someone whose job is to control the operation of a business, organization, or plan
definition.example:
From 1969 to 1971, he was administrator of the Illinois state drug abuse program.
She works as a school administrator.

definition.definition: a person who is in charge of the operation of a network of computers, a website, a group of computer users, etc., and is able to make changes to it
definition.example:
It is now possible for network administrators to download educational software to specific computers across the school's network.
To set up remote access you have to log on as the administrator.

definition.definition: someone whose job is to manage a business or business activity
definition.example:
A new administrator has taken over at the park, and more stringent business practices are in place.
She spent 10 years as a very capable administrator of New York City Opera.

definition.definition: a person chosen by a court to manage a company that cannot pay its debts in order to try to improve its financial situation and to keep it operating
definition.example: The court-appointed administrator asked a court to declare the firm bankrupt.

definition.definition: deserving respect or approval
definition.example:
I think you showed admirable tact/restraint/self-control in your answer.
The police did an admirable job in keeping the fans calm.

definition.definition: an officer of very high rank in the navy
definition.example:
Admiral Nelson/Horatio Nelson
[as form of address] Yes, Admiral.

definition.definition: a naval officer of the highest rank
the feeling of admiring someone or something
definition.example:
My admiration for that woman grows daily.
She gazed in admiration at his broad, muscular shoulders.

definition.definition: to find someone or something attractive and pleasant to look at
definition.example:
We stood for a few moments, admiring the view.
I was just admiring your jacket, Delia.

definition.definition: to respect and approve of someone or their behaviour
definition.example:
I admired him for his determination.
I really admire people who can work in such difficult conditions.

definition.definition: to respect and approve of someone or something
definition.example: I admire that music more than any other.
The police did an admirable job of calming down the crowd.
I think she coped admirably with a very difficult situation.
My admiration for her grows daily.
Many admirers waited in the rain just to see their hero.

definition.definition: someone who finds someone else sexually attractive, or someone who admires someone or something
definition.example:
She's got plenty of admirers.
She's got a secret admirer who keeps sending her gifts.
The policy has few admirers (= few people like it).

definition.definition: considered satisfactory and acceptable in a law court
definition.example: The judge ruled that new evidence was admissible.

definition.definition: able to be considered in a court of law
definition.example: The judge ruled that this new evidence was admissible.

definition.definition: allowed or able to be considered in a court of law
definition.example:
The board's findings would be admissible in criminal court.
It remains to be seen whether the report produces any admissible evidence.
There is some dispute about the admissibility of children's evidence.

definition.definition: the act of agreeing that something is true, especially unwillingly
definition.example:
admission of guilt Her silence was taken as an admission of guilt.
by your own admission By his own admission (= as he has said), he has achieved little since he took over the company.
[+ that] I felt he would see my giving up now as an admission that I was wrong.

definition.definition: the money that you pay to enter a place
definition.example:
How much do they charge for admission?
The admission charge/fee is €5.

definition.definition: permission to enter a place
definition.example:
Admission to the exhibition will be by invitation only.
There's a notice outside the building that says "No admission before twelve noon".

definition.definition: the act or process of accepting someone as a patient at a hospital or as a student at a school, college, etc.
definition.example:
hospital admission Nearly 15 percent of the patients were sick enough to require hospital admission.
She wanted to be a nurse, but was denied admission to nursing school.
This was my third admission to hospital in a year.
Admissions for respiratory diseases increased significantly.

definition.definition: the process of accepting people into a university, school, etc. as students, or the part of a university, school, etc. that deals with this
definition.example: We want to encourage greater age diversity in university admissions.

definition.definition: permission to study at a school or college, or permission to enter a theater or other building
definition.example:
[U] How many students will gain admission to Yale?
[U] The club refuses admission to those under 18.

definition.definition: Admission is also the price paid to enter a place
definition.example: [C] Museum admission is $5.

definition.definition: a statement accepting the truth about something
definition.example: [C] There was no admission of guilt from anyone.

definition.definition: something that you say or do that shows that you know you have done something dishonest or have not succeeded in doing something
definition.example:
admission that The chairman's statement is the first public admission that the board may be considering breaking up the company.
admission of guilt/responsibility/failure Many members of the public view the resignation of the authority's chief executive as an admission of guilt.
by sb's own admission By the CEO's own admission, the company's strategy of pursuing global growth has not been a success.

definition.definition: official permission that is given to a person, company, or country to join a large organization
definition.example:
The European Union promises admission to any country that meets the criteria for membership.
admission to sth Admission to the World Trade Organization should improve our economic prospects.
admission of sb We always welcome the admission of new members.
apply for/gain admission (to sth) Over 5,000 students apply for admission to our graduate business program each year.
deny/refuse admission (to sth) Despite existing shortages, the number denied admission to nursing schools is high.
admission process/requirement/standard Recent changes in the system have led to tougher admission standards.

definition.definition: the price that you pay to go to a public place such as a museum or theatre, or to attend a public event such as a concert or sports game
definition.example:
Tickets are $15 for general admission and $7 for students.
admission to sth The government is committed to extending the principle of free admission to our national museums and galleries.
admission charge/fee/price

definition.definition: official permission that is given to a company to sell its shares on a stock market
definition.example: admission to sth Shares were heavily traded before and after the company's admission to the index, arousing suspicions of insider dealing.

definition.definition: to agree that something is true, especially unwillingly
definition.example:
He admitted his guilt/mistake.
[+ (that)] She admitted (that) she had made a mistake.
[+ -ing verb] She admitted making a mistake.
At first he denied stealing the money but he later admitted (to) it.
I wasn't entirely honest with him, I admit.
[+ to infinitive] The new law was generally admitted to be difficult to enforce.

definition.definition: to accept that you have failed and give up
definition.example: After several attempts to untie the knot, I admitted defeat and cut through it with a knife.

definition.definition: to allow someone to enter a place
definition.example:
Each ticket admits one member and one guest.
Men will not be admitted to the restaurant without a tie.
literary A gap between the curtains admitted the faint glimmer of a street lamp.

definition.definition: to allow a person or country to join an organization
definition.example: Spain was admitted to the European Community in 1986.

definition.definition: to allow someone to enter a hospital because they need medical care
definition.example:
UK She was admitted to hospital suffering from shock.
US She was admitted to the hospital suffering from shock.

definition.definition: to recognize or accept something as true
definition.example:
[T] He admitted his guilt.
[+ (that) clause] She admitted (that) she had made a mistake.

definition.definition: to allow someone or something to enter
definition.example: Each ticket admits one member and a guest.
He was refused admittance to the club.

definition.definition: to say that you have done something dishonest or have not succeeded in doing something
definition.example:
"We need to do more to attract the younger end of the market," the Chairman admitted.
It can be difficult to admit mistakes in front of colleagues who may be competitors for the next promotion.
admit to sth Three suspects admitted to the fraud scheme during a series of interviews with federal agents.
admit (that) British Airways admitted last week that the credit market downturn was affecting business travel.
admit doing sth In court, she admitted receiving almost $1 million as "consulting fees".
admit guilt/failure/defeat The company received a discount on its fine because it admitted its guilt.
admit a charge/offence/allegation Several firms have been forced to admit charges of paying illegal bonuses to employees.

definition.definition: to admit that you are legally responsible for something that has harmed someone
definition.example: As part of the agreement, the chairman and his affiliates do not admit any liability or wrongdoing.

definition.definition: to officially give permission for a person, company, or country to join a large organization
definition.example: admit sb to sth Over the next five years, several new countries will be admitted to the EU.

definition.definition: to officially give permission for someone to attend a meeting or other event
definition.example: admit sb to sth Newspaper reporters will not be admitted to the hearing.

definition.definition: if a court of law admits evidence or admits something as evidence, it allows something to be used to decide whether someone is guilty of a crime
definition.example: Prosecutors asked the court to admit the recordings as evidence.

definition.definition: permission to enter a place
definition.example:
refuse admittance The club has the right to refuse admittance to anyone.
gain admittance The enquiry centred on how the assassin had gained admittance to (= succeeded in entering) the building.
The sign read "Private - no admittance".

definition.definition: used when you are agreeing that something is true, especially unwillingly
definition.example: Admittedly, I could have tried harder but I still don't think all this criticism is fair.

definition.definition: to tell someone that they have done something wrong
definition.example: His mother admonished him for eating too quickly.

definition.definition: to advise someone to do something
definition.example: Her teacher admonished her to work harder for her exams.

definition.definition: to warn someone not to do something, usually in a kind way, or to tell someone to do something
definition.example: His mother admonished him for eating too quickly.
As I left I heard my husband’s admonition – "Don’t be late."

definition.definition: a piece of advice that is also a warning to someone about their behaviour
definition.example: The most common parental admonition must surely be "Don't stay out late".

definition.definition: advising and warning someone about their behaviour
definition.example:
an admonitory remark
She raised an admonitory finger at me.

definition.definition: a lot of activity, worry, or excitement that is unnecessary or greater than the situation deserves
definition.example:
Most state flags were adopted with little ado many years ago.
Without ado, it became the most widely used system in the world.

definition.definition: much more activity, worry, or excitement than the situation deserves
definition.example: I had the feeling that the "3D experience" would be much ado about nothing.

definition.definition: delay or unnecessary activity
definition.example: Without further ado, I shall introduce tonight’s speaker.

definition.definition: a mixture of earth and straw made into bricks and dried in the sun, used to build houses in some parts of the world
definition.example: an adobe house

definition.definition: a mixture of wet earth and grass made into bricks and dried in the sun, used to build houses
definition.example: Adobe houses were common in the Southwest.

definition.definition: the period of time in a person's life when they are developing into an adult
definition.example:
She had a troubled adolescence.
yet another novel about the joys and sorrows of adolescence

definition.definition: a young person who is developing into an adult
being or relating to an adolescent
definition.example:
an adolescent boy
adolescent concerns/traumas/problems

definition.definition: used to describe an adult or an adult's behaviour that is silly and like a child's
definition.example: adolescent humour/behaviour

definition.definition: between the ages of a child and an adult
definition.example: The two adolescent boys made their mother very tired.

definition.definition: If you describe an adult as adolescent, you mean that the person is behaving in a silly way.

definition.example: [C] He had an unhappy adolescence.
I teach in a middle school, because I like young adolescents.

definition.definition: to legally take another person's child into your own family and take care of him or her as your own child
definition.example:
They've adopted a baby girl.
She had the child adopted (= she gave her baby to someone else to take care of).
They have no children of their own, but they're hoping to adopt.

definition.definition: to take an animal that has been left in a place such as a rescue centre, and keep it as your pet
definition.example:
Only about 20 percent of all dogs and cats that come into the rescue centre will be adopted.
She lives in a 3-bedroomed home with five dogs she adopted from an animal shelter.

definition.definition: to accept or start to use something new
definition.example:
I think it's time to adopt a different strategy in my dealings with him.
The new tax would force companies to adopt energy-saving measures.
He's adopted a remarkably light-hearted attitude towards the situation.

definition.definition: to choose someone or something or take something as your own
definition.example: Dr Kennedy has been adopted as the party's candidate for South Cambridge.

definition.definition: to start behaving in a particular way, especially by choice
definition.example: Roz has adopted one or two funny mannerisms since she's been away.

definition.definition: to pay money in order to have your name connected with a particular thing, especially in order to help an organization raise money
definition.example: For just $25, you can adopt a word for an entire year.

definition.definition: to agree to be responsible for a road being maintained (= kept in good condition)
definition.example: The council said the road was never adopted and so it is not obliged to repair it.

definition.definition: to take another person’s child legally into your own family to raise as your own child
definition.example: [T] They adopted Raphael last September.

definition.definition: to accept or begin to use something
definition.example: The new law means companies will adopt energy-saving measures.

definition.definition: If an organization adopts a rule, it votes to accept it
definition.example: The motion to increase fees was adopted.

definition.definition: to start to use a new method, system, law, etc.
definition.example:
Many European businesses are now adopting a management style closer to that of the US.
adopt an approach/strategy/policy According to the inspector-general's report, the airline industry needs to adopt a more consistent approach.
adopt a measure/system/plan Companies involved in public takeovers should adopt more stringent measures to investigate information leaks.
adopt a resolution/regulation/solution The Security Council adopted a resolution promising economic aid to the region.

definition.definition: to start to use a new product or service
definition.example: Large firms lead small firms in terms of adopting e-commerce.

definition.definition: An adopted child has been legally taken by another family to be taken care of as their own child
definition.example: They've got two adopted children and one of their own.

definition.definition: An adopted country is one where someone chooses to live although they were not born there
definition.example: Spain is my adopted country.

definition.definition: (of a road, etc.) owned and maintained (= kept in good condition) by a local government
definition.example: An adopted highway is maintained at public expense.

definition.definition: the act of legally taking a child to be taken care of as your own
definition.example:
put someone up for adoption She was homeless and had to put her child up for adoption (= ask for the child to be taken by someone else as their own).
The last ten years have seen a dramatic fall in the number of adoptions.

definition.definition: accepting or starting to use something new
definition.example: Several suggestions have been offered for adoption by the panel.

definition.definition: choosing or taking something as your own
definition.example:
England was Conrad's country of adoption (= the country where he had chosen to live).
The adoption of a woman candidate was seen as controversial.

definition.definition: the act of taking another person's child legally into your family to raise as your own child
definition.example: [C] The agency handles about a hundred adoptions a year.

definition.definition: the act of accepting or beginning to use something
definition.example: The adoption of a different insurance company caused a lot of confusion.

definition.definition: the process of starting to use a new method, system, law, etc.
definition.example: The adoption of tougher credit standards by mortgage lenders is making it hard for borrowers to qualify for new loans.

definition.definition: the process of starting to use a new product or service
definition.example:
Mass adoption of broadband and social networking have made finding customers easier.
Misunderstanding of how these health plans work is preventing widespread adoption.
There has been a huge adoption rate for self-service check-in in the airline industry.
internet/e-commerce/technology adoption

definition.definition: An adoptive parent is one who has adopted a child.
related, esp. as parents of someone, through adoption
definition.example: Her adoptive parents were farmers.

definition.definition: used to describe someone or something that makes you love or like them, usually because they are attractive and often small
definition.example:
She has the most adorable two-year-old girl.
These snowflake-shaped picture frames are just adorable.
I think it's adorable that your parents still hold hands.

definition.definition: charming, attractive, and easily loved
definition.example: He was an absolutely adorable child.

definition.definition: very strong love or worship for someone
definition.example:
her complete adoration of her brother
The painting depicts the Three Wise Men kneeling in adoration of the baby Jesus.

definition.definition: to love someone very much, especially in a way that shows a lot of admiration or respect, or to like something very much
definition.example:
She has one son and she adores him.
I absolutely adore chocolate.
[+ -ing verb] Don't you just adore lying in a hot bath?

definition.definition: to worship
definition.example: Let us adore God for all his works.

definition.definition: to love and respect someone very much, or to like something very much
definition.example:
Both girls adored their father.
I adore those shoes!
His adoration of his wife is obvious.

definition.definition: showing very strong love for someone
definition.example: I refuse to play the part of the adoring wife.

definition.definition: to add something decorative to a person or thing
definition.example: The bride's hair was adorned with white flowers.

definition.definition: to make something more attractive by putting something on it
definition.example: The bride’s hair was adorned with fresh flowers.
[C] Her only adornment was a ruby necklace.

definition.definition: past simple and past participle of adorn
to add something decorative to a person or thing
definition.example: The bride's hair was adorned with white flowers.

definition.definition: something decorative, or the act of decorating something or someone
used to refer to two glands situated above the kidneys (the adrenal glands)
a hormone (= chemical substance) produced by the body when a person is frightened, angry, or excited, which makes the heart beat faster and prepares the body to react to danger
If a boat is adrift, it is moving on the water but is not controlled by anyone because of a problem
definition.example: He spent three days adrift on his yacht.

definition.definition: If a person is adrift, they do not have a clear purpose in life or know what they want to do
definition.example: Da Silva plays a bright, lonely student from New York, adrift in small-town Arizona.

definition.definition: to become loose
definition.example: The hem of my skirt's come adrift again.

definition.definition: If plans go adrift, they fail or do not produce the correct results
definition.example: Something seems to have gone adrift in our calculations.

definition.definition: (of a boat) not fastened and moving with the sea and wind, or fig. not controlled and living without a clear purpose or direction
definition.example: fig. Hopeful actors from small towns are often adrift in New York.

definition.definition: very skilful and quick in the way you think or move
definition.example:
an adroit reaction/answer/movement of the hand
She became adroit at dealing with difficult questions.

definition.definition: very skillful and quick in the way you think or move
definition.example: She became adroit at dealing with difficult people.
He adroitly slid the money into his pocket.

definition.definition: very great admiration or praise for someone, especially when it is more than is deserved
definition.example: As a born performer, she loves the excitement and she loves the adulation.

definition.definition: too much admiration or praise for someone
definition.example: He couldn’t deal with the adulation of his fans.

definition.definition: a person or animal that has grown to full size and strength
definition.example:
An adult under English law is someone over 18 years old.
Adults pay an admission charge but children get in free.

definition.definition: grown to full size and strength
definition.example:
an adult male/elephant
adult life She spent most of her adult life in Spain.

definition.definition: typical of or suitable for adults
definition.example: Let's try to be adult about this.

definition.definition: Adult films, magazines, and books show naked people and sexual acts and are not for children.
grown to full size and strength
definition.example: More than half of adult Americans are considered overweight.

definition.definition: Adult also means suitable for grown people and not children
definition.example: It’s a kids’ show, but they sneak in some adult humor.

definition.definition: Adult movies, magazines, shows, and books include content that is intended for adults only.

definition.example: We invited only adults to the wedding.

definition.definition: classes for people who have finished their school education, usually taken in order to learn things they failed to learn in school
to make food or drink weaker or to lower its quality, by adding something else
definition.example: There were complaints that the beer had been adulterated with water.

definition.definition: to make something weaker or of worse quality by adding something else to it
definition.example: Saffron is very expensive, and is often adulterated with other plants.

definition.definition: Adulterated foods or drugs have been made weaker or worse in quality, especially by having something added to the them
definition.example:
There has been a government crackdown on adulterated animal feed.
The company was accused of distributing adulterated food.

definition.definition: the act of making food or drugs worse in quality by adding something to them
definition.example:
The adulteration of poultry is considered a serious problem.
The presence of low levels of melamine in milk is not necessarily due to adulteration.

definition.definition: sex between a married man or woman and someone he or she is not married to
definition.example: Many people in public life have committed adultery.

definition.definition: sex between a married person and someone who is not that person’s wife or husband

definition.example: an adulterous relationship

definition.definition: the part of someone's life when they are an adult

People in England legally reach adulthood at 18.

definition.definition: the state of being an adult
definition.example: When she reached adulthood, she moved away from home.

definition.definition: to give only the main facts and not the details about something, especially something that will happen in the future
definition.example: The project's objectives were adumbrated in the report.

definition.definition: the act of giving the main facts and not the details about something, or something that gives these main facts

definition.definition: to go or move something forward, or to develop or improve something

The fire advanced steadily through the forest.
We have advanced greatly in our knowledge of the universe.

advance the cause Her study has considerably advanced (= helped) the cause of equal rights.

definition.definition: to pay someone some money before the regular time
definition.example: [+ two objects] Could you advance me £500 until Tuesday?

definition.definition: to suggest an idea or theory
definition.example: the theory advanced in this article

definition.definition: If something such as a share price advances, it increases in value
definition.example: On the New York Stock Exchange, 1,228 issues advanced and 1,157 declined.

definition.definition: the forward movement of something, or an improvement or development in something

Nothing could stop the advance of the floodwaters.

definition.definition: money paid to someone before the regular time

definition.definition: an attempt to start a sexual or romantic relationship with someone
definition.example:
sexual advances She claimed that he made sexual advances towards her.

definition.definition: something such as a share price that increases in value
definition.example: Declining stocks easily defeated advances 413 to 302.

definition.definition: happening, done, or ready before an event
definition.example:

advance payment/booking

definition.definition: to go or move something forward, or to develop or improve something

definition.definition: happening before an event

definition.definition: money paid before something happens

definition.definition: an act of moving something forward or improving something

definition.definition: money that is paid to a person or organization before the usual time or before a piece of work is finished

definition.definition: before something else happens or is done

definition.definition: to develop and become successful, or to make something do this

definition.definition: to increase in value

On the New York Stock Exchange 1,128 issues advanced and 1,057 declined .
advance 5.5 cents/8p/10.9 points, etc. The general stock index advanced 1.94 points, or 0.04%, to 5291.45.
advance against sth The dollar advanced against the Japanese yen.

definition.definition: to increase in number, amount, or value

definition.definition: to suggest a new idea or plan to a group of people

definition.definition: modern and well developed

definition.definition: at a higher, more difficult level

definition.definition: the development or improvement of something

definition.definition: If you talk about someone's advancing age, you mean that they are getting older

definition.definition: a condition giving a greater chance of success
definition.example:
advantage of doing sth The advantage of booking tickets in advance is that you get better seats.
advantages of sth Despite the twin advantages of wealth and beauty, she did not have a happy life.
[+ to infinitive] It would be to your advantage (= it would improve the situation for you) to agree to his demands.

definition.definition: to use the good things in a situation

definition.definition: to treat someone badly in order to get something good from them

definition.definition: the word used in tennis when a player has won the point after deuce

definition.definition: In games such as football, if a referee plays advantage, they do not stop the game when there is a foul because allowing play to continue gives an advantage to the team that has been fouled
definition.example: The ref should have played advantage because Rooney would have been through on goal.

definition.definition: to make someone or something more likely to be successful by creating a situation that helps them

definition.definition: a condition that helps you or gives you a greater chance of success

[U] Her teacher likes her very much, which works to her advantage (= helps her) if she has trouble in class.

definition.definition: a good feature that makes something better than similar things

definition.definition: an enemy

to give someone advice

definition.example:
a painting after Titian
a concerto after Mozart

definition.definition: used when giving someone or something the same name as another person or thing
definition.example: He was named Mark after his grandfather.

definition.definition: later than someone or something else
definition.example:
soon after Hilary got here at midday and Nick arrived soon after.
I can't go next week - how about the week after (= the following week)?
not standard She got back at 4.30 and went to see Emilie after (= after she got back).

definition.definition: at a time that is later than another event
definition.example:
Three months after they moved out, the house was still empty.
soon after He was captured in 1940 soon after the fighting began.
shortly after Shortly after we set off, the car started to make a strange noise.
immediately after I went to the post office immediately after I left you.

definition.definition: coming after
definition.example:
an after-dinner speech
an after-hours club
after-sales service

definition.definition: following in time, place, or order
definition.example:
What do you want to do after breakfast?
I expect to return to work after the baby comes.
Repeat these words after me.
I’ll see you the day after tomorrow.
It’s ten minutes after four.
Week after week (= For many weeks), he’s been too busy to help.

definition.definition: as a result of; because
definition.example:
After what she did to me, I’ll never trust her again.
She’s named after her aunt (= given the same name in her honor).

definition.definition: despite
definition.example: Even after everything that’s happened here, his behavior seems odd.

definition.definition: wanting to find or have
definition.example:
The police are after him.
He’s after Jane’s job.
The house was empty for three months after they moved out.
Hilary drove up and Nick arrived soon after.

definition.definition: the life, for example in heaven, that some people believe begins after death
definition.example: They'll be reunited in the afterlife.

definition.definition: the life that some people believe begins after death, esp. in heaven
the period that follows an unpleasant event or accident, and the effects that it causes
definition.example: Many more people died in the aftermath of the explosion.

definition.definition: the period following an event, such as an accident or war, and the effects caused by the event
definition.example: We all worked together in the aftermath of the earthquake.

definition.definition: the period that starts at about twelve o'clock or after the meal in the middle of the day and ends at about six o'clock or when the sun goes down
definition.example:
It was a sunny afternoon.
She works three afternoons a week at the library.
It was on a Saturday afternoon.
My baby usually sleeps in the afternoon.
Let's go to the park this afternoon.
I spoke to her yesterday afternoon.
I'll meet you tomorrow afternoon at about 3.30.
She's coming round on Wednesday afternoon.
He's been in a bad mood all afternoon.
She likes to have an afternoon nap.
We got an early-/mid-/late-afternoon flight.

definition.definition: a friendly way of greeting someone when you meet them in the afternoon
definition.example: Afternoon, Bob!

definition.definition: the period that starts at about twelve o’clock or after the meal in the middle of the day and ends at about six o’clock or when the sun goes down
definition.example:
[C] She works three afternoons a week at the library.
[U] My baby usually sleeps in the afternoon.
[U] I spoke to her yesterday afternoon.

definition.definition: an idea, thought, or plan that was not originally intended but is thought of at a later time
definition.example:
She only asked me to her party as an afterthought.
The pillars seem to have been added to the entrance as an afterthought.

definition.definition: an idea or plan that was not originally intended
definition.example: Pine included the song almost as an afterthought on his last album.

definition.definition: after the time mentioned
definition.example:
We had tea, and afterward we sat in the garden for a while.
They separated, and soon/shortly afterward Jane left the country.

definition.definition: after the time mentioned; later
definition.example: We had a swim and afterward we lay on the beach for a while.

definition.definition: after the time mentioned
definition.example:
We had tea, and afterwards we sat in the garden for a while.
They separated, and soon/shortly afterwards Jane left the country.

definition.definition: abbreviation for Aktiengesellschaft: in Germany, a company that is similar to a limited company in other countries:
definition.example: Bayersiche Motoren Werke AG is the name of the German company more commonly known as BMW.

definition.definition: one more time
definition.example:
Could you spell your name again, please?
If he does it again I'll have to tell him.
Deborah's late again.
Throw it away and start again.

definition.definition: back to the original place or condition
definition.example:
We went to Edinburgh and back again all in one day.
Get some rest and you'll soon be well again.

definition.definition: If something happens once again, it has already happened several times before
definition.example: You are reminded once again of the author's love of the sea.

definition.definition: said after an unpleasant experience to show that you do not intend to do it again
definition.example: He drove me back home last night. Never again!

definition.definition: If something happens yet again, it has already happened many times before
definition.example: I'm afraid it's been delayed yet again.

definition.definition: repeatedly
definition.example: I've told you again and again not to do that.

definition.definition: If you do something all over again, you start again from the beginning
definition.example: It's already taken me two hours - I don't want to have to do it all over again.

definition.definition: in addition to the amount we know about or have mentioned already
definition.example: They are paid half as much again as we are.

definition.definition: once more, or as before
definition.example:
Could you spell your name again please?
Get some rest and you’ll soon be well again.
Don’t be late again (= another time).

definition.definition: many times
definition.example: I’ve told you again and again that I don’t know anything about it.

definition.definition: disagreeing with a plan or activity
definition.example:
She spoke against the decision to close the college.
50 people voted against the new proposal.
I'm very much against the idea that it is the woman's job to bring up the child.
Germany are playing against Brazil in the cup final tonight.
She's always rebelled against authority.
She sold the house even though it was against his wishes.
They called a demonstration to protest against proposed job cuts.
Are you for or against my proposal?
Sanctions against the country should be lifted.
Stricter controls will help in the fight against inflation.
Criminal charges will be brought against the driver.
They decided not to take legal action against him.
They were up against a powerful pressure group.
We came up against a lot of problems in the course of building our extension.
The chances/odds against you winning such a competition are enormous.
It's against the law (= illegal) to leave children under a certain age alone in the house.
It's against my beliefs/principles to be nice to someone I dislike just because they're in a senior position.
Against all probability (= although it was extremely unlikely) we found ourselves in the same hotel.
I wouldn't dare say anything against him (= criticize him) to his mother!

definition.definition: If you have something against someone, you dislike them for a reason
definition.example: I've nothing against him - I just don't have much in common with him.

definition.definition: If something counts/goes/works against you, it gives you a disadvantage
definition.example: Lack of experience will generally count against you in an interview.

definition.definition: next to and touching or being supported by (something)
definition.example:
Why don't we put the bed against the wall?
He loved the feel of her soft hair against his skin.
The rain beat against her face as she struggled through the wind.
The police officer had him up against the wall, both arms behind his back.
She leaned against the door.

definition.definition: in front of or compared to
definition.example: Paintings look best against a simple white wall.

definition.definition: in the opposite direction to
definition.example:
The last part of the course was hard because I was running against the wind.
Commuting is not so bad when you are travelling against the traffic.

definition.definition: as a protection or defence from the bad effects of
definition.example:
We've insured the car against fire, theft, and accident.
The police have to arm themselves against attack.

definition.definition: in opposition to; opposed to
definition.example:
I know you’d like to get a more expensive car, but I’m against it.
It’s against the law to throw your trash there (= It’s illegal).
She voted against the tax increase.
He warned them against repeating (= not to repeat) the mistakes of the former administration.

definition.definition: Against also means in competition with
definition.example: He would have to run against O’Toole for county treasurer.

definition.definition: To go against something means to go in the opposite direction to it
definition.example: swimming against the current

definition.definition: directed at or toward
definition.example:
Among the charges leveled against them were bribery and tax evasion.
There's a process for filing claims against the city.

definition.definition: next to and touching or being supported by something
definition.example:
It would save space if we put the bed against the wall.
He leaned his head against the back of his chair.

definition.definition: (of a person) with the mouth wide open, especially showing surprise or shock; (of the mouth) wide open, especially in surprise or shock
definition.example:
We watched, our mouths agape in excitement.
Audience members were staring at each other agape as if to say "Did you hear what I just heard?"

definition.definition: a type of love that is not sexual and is not concerned with yourself; used especially in Christianity to refer to Christian love
definition.example:
Agape is a giving love, entirely unselfish.
A central lesson of The Marriage Of Figaro is that eros can mature into agape, sexual attraction into mature love.

definition.definition: the period of time someone has been alive or something has existed
definition.example:
Do you know the age of that building?

I'd guess she's about my age (= she is about as old as I am).
She was 74 years of age when she wrote her first novel.
He left home at the age of 16.
I was married with four children at your age.
She's starting to show/look her age (= to look as old as she is).
I'm really beginning to feel my age (= feel old).
His girlfriend's twice his age (= twice as old as he is).

definition.definition: said to someone to tell them to stop behaving like someone who is much younger
definition.example: Boys, act your age, please!

definition.definition: the age at which someone is considered by the law to be old enough to agree to have sex with someone
definition.example: This state finally raised the age of consent to 16 last year.

definition.definition: a particular period in time
definition.example:
the Victorian age
the modern age
the nuclear age

definition.definition: a very long time
definition.example: It takes ages to cook.

definition.definition: the fact of being or getting older
definition.example:
Her back was bent with age.
This cheese/wine improves with age.
Her temper hasn't improved with age!

definition.definition: If someone ages or something ages them, they look older
definition.example: She's aged since the last time we met.

definition.definition: to develop in flavour or leave something to do this
definition.example: The brandy is aged in oak for ten years.

definition.definition: used to form nouns that refer to the action or result of something
definition.example:
blockage
shrinkage
wastage

definition.definition: used to form nouns that refer to a state or condition
definition.example:
bondage
marriage
shortage

definition.definition: used to form nouns that are names of places
definition.example:
orphanage
vicarage

definition.definition: the length of time someone has been alive or something has existed
definition.example:
[C] At age 24 he won a starring role in his first movie.
[U] She was 74 years of age when she wrote her first novel.
The program is aimed at viewers in the 18-to-30 age group.

definition.definition: a particular period in time
definition.example: the modern/industrial/Victorian age

definition.definition: to become or appear old, or to cause someone to appear old
definition.example: [I] She’s aged a lot since the last time we met.

definition.definition: To age food or drink is to give it time to become ripe or develop a full flavor
definition.example: [T] The cheese is aged for three to six months.

definition.definition: people of a similar age, considered as a group
definition.example: 51 percent of enquiries were from those in the 25 to 40 age group.

definition.definition: a group of people who are the same age or a similar age
definition.example:
in/of the same age group According to the study, childless women between 25 and 35 earn about 90 cents for every dollar earned by men in the same age group.
11-14/25-35/50-65, etc age group The new radio station is aimed at the 15-24 age group.
older/younger age group Insurance premiums for the oldest age group should be around $30 a month.
across/for/in all age groups The average debt across all age groups at the end of September was £24,063.

definition.definition: old people when considered as a group

definition.definition: old people

the Central Intelligence Agency

definition.definition: the ability to take action or to choose what action to take

The protest gave us a sense of agency, a sense of our own power to make a difference.

an advertising/employment agency

definition.definition: An agency is also a government organization

definition.definition: a business that provides a service to other people or organizations

definition.definition: a government department that is responsible for a particular activity
definition.example:
Scottish Natural Heritage, the conservation agency, has finally managed to get approval for the project.
security/intelligence/immigration, etc. agency In a lengthy response to the report, the immigration agency stated that it will follow the recommendations.
a government/federal/state agency

definition.definition: a list of matters to be discussed at a meeting
definition.example:
There were several important items on the agenda.
The question of security is high on the agenda for this afternoon's meeting.

definition.definition: a list of aims or possible future achievements
definition.example:
Women's rights have been put back on the agenda (= are being discussed publicly again).
The subject of safety needs to be placed high on/at the top of the agenda (= must be discussed because it is very important).

definition.definition: a secret aim or reason for doing something
definition.example:
She felt that some of the group had an agenda.
There's no hidden agenda - I'm just trying to help.

definition.definition: a list of matters to be discussed at a meeting
definition.example: Among the items on the agenda were next year’s budget and raising the membership dues.

definition.definition: An agenda can also refer to any matters that have to be dealt with
definition.example: Finding a job is at the top of my agenda.

definition.definition: esp. disapproving An agenda is also a particular program of action, often one that is not directly expressed
definition.example: She has a political agenda.

definition.definition: the things that a person or organization considers to be important and wants to solve or achieve, or their reasons for wanting to do something
definition.example:
Agendas change with the times, as every CEO knows.
economic/environmental/political agenda The Senator's environmental agenda is negative for traditional energy producers, but positive for alternative energy producers.
be at the top of/be high on the agenda The plight of poorer countries is high on the WTO's agenda.
Like any businessman he has an agenda, and that should not be forgotten.
set/lay out/establish an agenda Company directors are attempting to lay out an agenda for reducing future financial risks.
I strongly suspect that the author has a hidden agenda.

definition.definition: a list of things to be discussed during a meeting
definition.example:
If you don't have a structured agenda, people will bring up side issues that aren't relevant to solving the problem.
The next item on the agenda is a special report from the Advisory Committee.
be at the top of/be high on the agenda At a meeting of finance ministers in St Petersburg, security of energy supply was at the top of the agenda.

definition.definition: a person who acts for or represents another
definition.example: Please contact our agent in Spain for further information.

definition.definition: a person who represents an actor, artist, or writer
someone who works secretly for the government or other organization

definition.definition: a person or thing that produces a particular effect or change
definition.example:
a powerful cleaning agent
a raising agent for cakes
a clotting agent
literary He was the agent of their destruction.

definition.definition: a person who acts for or represents another
definition.example:
a travel agent

definition.definition: An agent is also someone who works secretly for a government or other organization
definition.example:
a secret agent
an undercover agent

definition.definition: a person or thing that produces a particular effect or change
definition.example: a cleaning agent

definition.definition: An agent is also a chemical substance, organism, or natural force that produces a particular effect by its action.
a person who is paid to buy or sell products or provide a service for a company, but who is not a regular employee
definition.example: Following the recent insurance scam, legislation is being put in place to ensure all agents protect their customers' best interests.

definition.definition: someone who represents an actor, musician, etc. in order to find work for them
definition.example: a talent/sports/theatrical agent

definition.definition: someone who represents a company in dealing with customers, especially on the phone
definition.example: To speak with one of our agents, please call us Monday - Friday between 8:30am and 5:00pm.

definition.definition: someone who does secret work for a government department
definition.example: a federal/undercover/secret agent

definition.definition: a substance that produces a particular effect
definition.example: Bioterrorism involves the use of biological agents such as viruses and bacteria as weapons of terror.

definition.definition: very old
definition.example: an age-old story of love and betrayal

definition.definition: very old, or having existed for a long time
definition.example: It’s an age-old story of love and betrayal.

definition.definition: to join or stick together to form a larger mass or group, or to cause something to do this
definition.example:
Tiny carbon particles can cause damage in the lungs since they can agglomerate there.
Throughout this time, political leaders have been steadily agglomerating powers.

definition.definition: to combine different companies to form one organization
definition.example:
Management experts warn that mergers often do not work well, so why are CEOs so eager to agglomerate?
Most of these small companies are in the process of being agglomerated with other financial institutions.

definition.definition: rock or material consisting of different pieces that are bonded (= joined and held) together
definition.example:
Volcanic agglomerate is one type of pyroclastic rock (rock formed from fragments of lava ejected from a volcano).
To meet the increasing demand for detergents to be able to release oxygen at lower temperatures, a totally new agglomerate has been invented.

definition.definition: a mass or collection of things
definition.example:
Galaxies are huge agglomerates of stars, gas, and dust.
Small businesses are being consolidated into large agglomerates.

definition.definition: a large group of many different things collected or brought together
definition.example: an agglomeration of various ethnic and religious groupings

definition.definition: to make someone more powerful or important
to make a bad situation worse
definition.example: Attempts to restrict parking in the city centre have further aggravated the problem of traffic congestion.

definition.definition: to make a disease worse
definition.example: The treatment only aggravated the condition.

definition.definition: to annoy someone
definition.example: Stop aggravating me, will you!

definition.definition: to make something bad worse
definition.example: Road repair work has aggravated the problem of traffic congestion.

definition.definition: to make someone feel very annoyed and upset
definition.example: It really aggravates me when the car won’t start, after all the money we put into it.
It’s so aggravating to have an injury like that, when you can’t lift anything or bend down and tie your shoelaces.
I won’t bother returning it – it isn’t worth the aggravation.

definition.definition: past simple and past participle of aggravate
to make a bad situation worse
definition.example: Attempts to restrict parking in the city centre have further aggravated the problem of traffic congestion.

definition.definition: to make a disease worse
definition.example: The treatment only aggravated the condition.

definition.definition: to annoy someone
definition.example: Stop aggravating me, will you!

definition.definition: annoying
definition.example: I find him really aggravating.

definition.definition: making something worse, such as a crime
definition.example: Aggravating factors can affect the sentence set by the court.

definition.info: [C or U] (UK also informal aggro [ U ])
definition.definition: trouble or difficulty
definition.example:
I've been getting a lot of aggravation at work recently.
I don't need any more aggravation today.
I'd complain to the manager but it's not worth the aggravation.

definition.definition: the act of making something such as a problem or injury worse
definition.example: Rest the affected limb to avoid further aggravation of the condition.

definition.definition: something formed by adding together several amounts or things
definition.example:
aggregate of They purchased an aggregate of 3,000 shares in the company.
Snowflakes are loose aggregates of ice crystals.

definition.definition: If one team beats another on aggregate, it wins after adding together the goals in two or more matches
definition.example: Arsenal lost the second game, but got through to the final on aggregate.

definition.definition: small stones used in building
definition.example: Volumes of aggregates, cement, and concrete used in the UK will rise this year.

definition.definition: total
definition.example: The seven companies have an aggregate turnover of £5.2 million.

definition.definition: to combine into a single group or total
formed by adding together several amounts or things; total
definition.example: The seven companies made an aggregate profit of $10.2 million.
The family owned over 2 million shares in the aggregate.
the aggregation of the companies into one organization

definition.definition: to bring different things together
definition.example: The company aggregates news and information from a number of sources on its website.

definition.definition: a total that is calculated by adding together different prices, amounts, etc.
definition.example: an aggregate of sth An aggregate of 18,003 shares of Series B Convertible Preferred Stock will remain outstanding.

definition.definition: a measurement used in calculating the amount of money in an economy at a particular time
definition.example: From its peak, the aggregate money supply has declined 18.5%.

definition.definition: small stones used in building
definition.example: Volumes of aggregates, cement, and concrete used in Britain will rise this year.

definition.definition: in total, after different prices, amounts, etc. have been added together
definition.example: In aggregate, the top 30 listed companies tend to get more money back from the government than they pay in tax.

definition.definition: added together to make a total amount, price, etc.
definition.example:
The report scores each health plan for dozens of individual measures, and makes state and regional aggregate data available to the media.
aggregate amount/figure/value Aggregate figures for the euro mask big differences among member states.
aggregate demand/supply/sales Pre-tax profits fell 17% on falling aggregate sales.

definition.definition: to add different prices, amounts, etc. in order to get a total
definition.example: The company did $15.6 million in business with the federal government last year, according to data aggregated by OMB Watch.

definition.definition: to combine different products or services and sell them together
definition.example: Mobile and satellite communications systems aggregate a range of services such as telephony, data transmission, and internet distribution.

d_list: 20000+; ACT; GRE; IELTS; MCAT; SAT; TOEFL

definition.definition: the process of combining things or amounts into a single group or total
definition.example:
Installation art - the aggregation of objects in a space - has long dominated the visual arts.
Some animals avoid being eaten by aggregation in groups, such as schools of fish.

definition.definition: the process of collecting information from several different websites, newspapers, databases (= large amounts of information stored in a computer system ), etc. and combining it in one place, or the result of this process
definition.example:
This news aggregation site grabs headlines from over 30 daily news sources and provides a link to the host site.
You can view aggregations of polling data at the site.

definition.definition: a total calculated by adding different amounts, prices, etc.
definition.example: The single profit figure is an aggregation of many, earned from completely different markets.

definition.definition: a combination of products or services that are sold together
the process of collecting and examining detailed information about people or organizations in order to decide how to market a product, who to lend money to, etc.
definition.example: With our data aggregation service, market research companies and government organizations can rely on a single source for their operations.

definition.definition: spoken or physical behaviour that is threatening or involves harm to someone or something
definition.example:
Some types of dog are bred for aggression.
an act of aggression

definition.definition: forceful playing in sport that is intended to win points
actions or behavior that use threats or force against others
definition.example: We regard the presence of troops on our border as an act of aggression.

definition.definition: showing anger and a willingness to attack other people
definition.example:
The stereotype is that men tend to be more aggressive than women.
If I criticize him, he gets aggressive and starts shouting.
Aggressive behaviour will not be tolerated in the classroom.

definition.definition: determined to win or succeed and using forceful action to do this
definition.example:
an aggressive election campaign
aggressive marketing tactics
Both players won their first-round matches in aggressive style.

definition.definition: An aggressive condition is one that is serious and quickly spreads in the body or gets worse
definition.example: The more aggressive the cancer, the further and faster it spreads.

definition.definition: Aggressive treatment is strong treatment that could itself cause harm, used when someone has a serious condition
definition.example: Brain cancer requires aggressive treatment such as surgery.

definition.definition: using strong, forceful methods esp. to sell or persuade
definition.example:
The company mounted an aggressive marketing campaign.
You have to be aggressive if you want to succeed in this business.
The company is aggressively pursuing new business opportunities.

definition.definition: done in a very forceful and competitive way in order to gain an advantage
definition.example:
aggressive marketing/expansion/recruiting Through aggressive marketing in Europe and Asia, the company pulled in an extra $4.5 billion and doubled its share prices.
aggressive campaigns/strategies/tactics Britain’s second largest water company is planning an aggressive campaign to win industrial and business customers from rivals.

definition.definition: forceful, competitive, and determined to win or get what you want
definition.example:
Many banks have become more aggressive in making loans to boost revenue growth.
The company has been losing market share for five years, primarily to aggressive competitors that have undercut the company on price.

definition.definition: used to describe investments that involve some risk or investors that take risks in order to gain the best results
definition.example:
aggressive funds/investments/trades He moved his money into more aggressive investments, including hedge funds and publicly traded stocks.
aggressive buyers/sellers

definition.definition: in an angry and violent way
definition.example:
Small children often behave aggressively.
Many drivers behave aggressively on the road at some point.

definition.definition: in a determined and forceful way in order to achieve success or win
definition.example:
They played more aggressively in the second half.
The company is aggressively pursuing new business opportunities.

definition.definition: in a way that develops very quickly
definition.example:
