In recent years, the disease has aggressively attacked her voice and memory.

definition.definition: in a way that uses a very strong treatment in order to cure a disease
definition.example:
We may have to treat the seizures aggressively to prevent developmental delays.
For how long and how aggressively should treatment be applied?

definition.definition: the quality of being likely to attack other people or animals, or to behave in a violent or angry way towards them
definition.example:
There were concerns about the child's disruptiveness and aggressiveness.
These dogs are bred for aggressiveness.

definition.definition: determination to win or succeed, and the use of forceful action to do this
definition.example: Her talent and aggressiveness make her a tennis star of the future.

definition.definition: the quality in a disease of spreading quickly and being difficult to cure
definition.example: A biopsy is the most effective means of determining the aggressiveness of the cancer.

definition.definition: the quality in a treatment of being very strong and possibly harmful, because a condition is serious and difficult to cure
definition.example: A classification system is essential for making decisions about aggressiveness of treatment.

definition.definition: a person or country that starts an argument, fight, or war by attacking first
a person, group, or country that starts an argument, fight, or war by attacking first
definition.example: He claimed that he was just defending himself, and that the other guy was the aggressor.

definition.definition: to make someone unhappy and angry
definition.example: Years later, this unfairness still aggrieves him.

definition.definition: suddenly filled with strong feelings of shock and worry
definition.example: He looked at her aghast.

definition.definition: shocked or surprised in an unpleasant way
definition.example: Workers and union officials were aghast at the layoffs.

definition.definition: able to move your body quickly and easily
definition.example:
Monkeys are very agile climbers.
You need to have agile fingers to do this kind of work.

definition.definition: able to think quickly and clearly
definition.example: For a man of 80, he has a remarkably agile mind.

definition.definition: used for describing ways of planning and doing work in which it is understood that making changes as they are needed is an important part of the job
able to move about quickly and easily
definition.example:
Years of ballet and modern dance had made her strong and agile.
fig. He has an agile mind (= He can think quickly).

definition.definition: able to deal with new situations or changes quickly and successfully
definition.example: agile company/corporation/organization Most agile corporations have flexible management systems that can quickly accommodate global change and exploit opportunities.
Confronting rapid change requires agility and flexibility along with the ability to implement strategies quickly.

definition.definition: the ability to move your body quickly and easily
definition.example:
He has the agility of a mountain goat.
The acrobats display jawdropping feats of strength, agility, and control.

definition.definition: the ability to think quickly and clearly
definition.example:
This job requires considerable mental agility.
We underestimate the agility of a child's mind.

definition.definition: ways of planning and doing work in which it is understood that making changes as they are needed is an important part of the job
definition.example:
Business agility means a company is always in a position to take account of market changes.
Constant change is the new dynamic of the global economy, and makes agility even more necessary than ever.

definition.definition: the ability to move about quickly and easily
definition.example:
A top-rated football player, he combines speed and agility.
fig. Her voice has the lightness and agility that Handel’s music demands.

definition.definition: US spelling of ageing
being or appearing old
definition.example: Oil companies are particularly concerned about their aging fleet of deep-water rigs.

definition.definition: a way of organizing a company's accounts to show the length of time its customers have owed the company money
definition.example: Financial analysts often use aging to assess a company’s risk from overdue debtors.

definition.definition: becoming older, and not as modern or powerful as before
definition.example:
an aging market/customer/population
The agency is showing all the signs of an ageing company whose growth is too dependent on buying market size.

definition.definition: to make someone feel worried or angry
definition.example: I didn't want to agitate her by telling her.

definition.definition: to argue forcefully, especially in public, in order to achieve a particular type of change
definition.example:
The unions continue to agitate for higher pay.
As a young man, he had agitated against the Vietnam war.

definition.definition: to shake a liquid
definition.example: Pour the powder into the solution and agitate it until the powder has dissolved.

definition.definition: to argue energetically, esp. in public, in order to achieve a particular type of change
definition.example: Telephone companies began to agitate for permission to compete in long distance services.

definition.definition: to make someone become nervous because of worry or fear that is difficult to control
definition.example: Any mention of his son agitated him.
He arrived home in a state of agitation.
They blamed the protest on political agitators.

definition.definition: worried or angry
definition.example:
She became very agitated when her son failed to return home.
There was a long delay, and people became increasingly agitated as they waited for the train.

definition.definition: nervous because of worry or fear that is difficult to control
definition.example:
Gordon became visibly agitated when asked about the minimum wage issue.
Many times the private hospitals transfer their terribly aggressive, agitated patients to us because they cannot handle them.

definition.definition: worry and anxiety
definition.example: He arrived home in a state of agitation.

definition.definition: the situation in which people protest or argue, especially in public, in order to achieve a particular type of change
definition.example: The anti-war agitation is beginning to worry the government.

definition.definition: someone who does not know, or believes that it is impossible to know, if a god exists
definition.example:
Although he was raised a Catholic, he was an agnostic for most of his adult life.
The group includes atheists and agnostics as well as religious believers.

definition.definition: someone who does not know or does not have an opinion about whether something is true, good, correct, etc.
definition.example:
He claims to be an agnostic on the question of man-made global warming.
I am an agnostic when it comes to his art and its merits.

definition.definition: having the belief that it is not possible to know whether god exists
definition.example:
Whether we are religious, atheist, or agnostic, there are some moral values we all share.
He is agnostic on the existence of God.

definition.definition: not knowing or not having an opinion about whether something is true, good, correct, etc.
definition.example:
She remained agnostic on the question of whether to join the war.
We could never be agnostic about the virtues of political freedom.

definition.definition: relating to hardware or software that can be used with many different types of platform (= system)
someone who believes that it is impossible to know whether or not God exists
back in time from the present
definition.example:
He left the house over an hour ago.
The dinosaurs died out 65 million years ago.
Long ago/A long time ago, there lived a girl called Cinderella.

definition.definition: back in the past; back in time from the present
definition.example:
That was a few years ago.
Your mother called about an hour ago.
Some time ago I read a book about that.
Are you still seeing Vivian? No, we stopped seeing each other a long time ago.

definition.definition: excited and eager to know or see more
definition.example: We waited agog for news.

definition.definition: causing extreme physical or mental pain
definition.example: an agonizing death

definition.definition: causing extreme worry
definition.example:
She went through an agonizing few weeks waiting for the test results.
We are faced with an agonizing choice/decision/dilemma.

definition.definition: extreme physical or mental pain or suffering
definition.example:
She lay there screaming in agony.
I was in an agony of suspense.
We've both suffered agonies of guilt over what happened.
It must be agony for them to say goodbye.

definition.definition: extreme physical or mental pain or suffering, or a period of such suffering
definition.example: [U] They put her on painkillers, but they didn’t do enough, and she was in agony.

definition.definition: relating to the land, especially the use of land for farming
definition.example: This is prime agrarian land.

definition.definition: An agrarian place or country makes its money from farming rather than industry
definition.example: This part of the country is mainly agrarian.

definition.definition: relating to farming or farmers
definition.example:
The central government was urged to adopt a massive public investment programme in the agrarian sector to enhance grain production.
an agrarian economy/society/lifestyle
agrarian reform/laws/revolution

definition.definition: to have the same opinion
definition.example:
Ann and I never seem to agree.
agree with I agree with you on this issue.
agree about My father and I don't agree about very much.
agree on My father and I don't agree on very much.
[+ that] I agree that he should be invited.
[+ question word] Experts seem unable to agree whether the drug is safe or not.
[+ speech] "You're absolutely right," agreed Jake.

definition.definition: to decide something together
definition.example:
They agreed not to tell anyone about what had happened.
We couldn't agree on what to buy.
UK We finally agreed a deal.

definition.definition: to accept a suggestion or idea
definition.example:
I suggested that we should meet, and they agreed (= said yes).
[+ to infinitive] The bank has agreed (= is willing) to lend me £5,000.

definition.definition: If two or more statements, ideas, sets of numbers, etc. agree, they are the same or very similar
definition.example: We have five accounts of what happened and none of them agree.

definition.definition: When two words agree, or one word agrees with another word, they have the same grammatical form. For example, the words may both be singular or plural, masculine or feminine, etc.
to have the same opinion, or to accept a suggestion or idea
definition.example:
[I] I agree with you.
[I] We all agree on that point.
[+ to infinitive] In settling the dispute, he agreed to pay $60,000 in damages.
[+ that clause] Most economists agree that it would be unwise to cut taxes right now.
[I] Both sides agreed to the terms of the peace treaty.
[I] I agree with letting children learn at their own pace.

definition.definition: If two sets of information agree, they are generally the same
definition.example: [I] Since their stories did not agree at all, he knew one of them was lying.

definition.definition: to accept someone else’s plan, suggestion, etc.
definition.example:
agree to do sth Federal regulators and US lenders agreed to freeze interest rates on subprime mortgages for five years.
be agreed by/between sb/sth Any change to branch rules must be agreed by two thirds of members at the branch meeting.
agree sth UK The union's national executive committee will meet on Thursday to agree the new strategy.

definition.definition: to have the same opinion, or to approve of someone else’s ideas and opinions
definition.example:
agree that The credit card company agreed that we'd been overcharged and will credit the amount in our next bill.
agree with sb on sth Although we like his plan in general, we don't agree with him on every issue.

definition.definition: pleasant or pleasing
definition.example: We spent a most agreeable evening by the river.

definition.definition: able to be accepted by everyone
definition.example:
The talks are aimed at finding a mutually agreeable solution.
We need to find a compromise that is agreeable to both sides of the party.

definition.definition: willing to do or accept something
definition.example: If Bridget is agreeable to the proposal, we'll start the project in June.

definition.definition: pleasant; pleasing
definition.example: She has an agreeable personality.

definition.definition: acceptable or satisfactory
definition.example: We prefer to reach a solution agreeable to all interested parties.

definition.definition: Someone who is agreeable to doing something is willing to do it
definition.example: We can close the deal tomorrow if your client is agreeable.

definition.definition: accepted
definition.example:
We have to stick to the agreed price.
"So we'll meet at 5.30, shall we?" "Agreed (= yes)."

definition.definition: If two or more people are agreed, they have the same opinion
definition.example: Are we all agreed (on that)?

definition.definition: accepted or approved
definition.example:
The agreed deal also marks a new record in foreign take-overs of US banks.
an agreed price/time/date

definition.definition: the situation in which people have the same opinion, or in which they approve of or accept something
definition.example:
The whole family was in agreement with her about/on what they should do.
If the three parties cannot reach agreement now, there will be a civil war.
I don't think you'll ever get Tony's agreement to these proposals.
[+ that] There's widespread agreement that the law should be changed.

definition.definition: a decision or arrangement, often formal and written, between two or more groups or people
definition.example:
The dispute was settled by an agreement that satisfied both sides.
The government has entered into/signed an international arms control agreement.
They have broken (the terms of) the agreement on human rights.
Finally the two sides have reached an agreement.

definition.definition: the situation in which two words have the same grammatical form. For example, the words are both singular or plural, masculine or feminine, etc.
the condition of having the same opinion, or a decision or arrangement between two or more people or groups to do something or to obey the same rules
definition.example:
[C] a new trade agreement
[U] Both sides were in agreement on the basic terms, but many details still had to be worked out.
[C] Leaders of both countries signed an agreement to exchange diplomats.
[U] Let us help you to reach agreement.

definition.definition: a decision or arrangement that has been made and accepted by two or more people, groups, organizations, etc.
definition.example:
agreement between sb and sb Based on the rental agreement between the landlord and the tenant, either party must give 30 days notice to terminate the agreement.
agreement with sb The group has licensing agreements with 170 retail customers in the US.
an agreement on sth Negotiations will continue for an ambitious agreement on trade and other matters.
arrive at/come to/reach an agreement Despite recent discussions between the two companies, they failed to reach an agreement on the terms of a possible merger.
enter into/sign an agreement Developers have signed an agreement with the commission and the EPA to use the land for commercial and residential property.
a formal/legal/binding agreement
a verbal/written/unwritten agreement

definition.definition: the act of approving or accepting something, or the fact of having the same opinion about something
definition.example:
be in agreement with sb/sth Most of the county's lawmakers are in agreement with administration officials on the proposal.
complete/total/widespread agreement There is widespread agreement that changes need to be made, but there is disagreement about how it should be conducted.
be in agreement that All area superintendents are in agreement that both constitutional reform and tax reform are necessary now.

definition.definition: used for farming or relating to farming

The world's supply of agricultural land is shrinking fast.
She's studying agricultural science.
The country's economy is mainly agricultural (= based on farming).

definition.definition: relating to or used in farming
definition.example:
agricultural exports/commodities/products Over the past ten years, their agricultural exports to the United States grew by 133%.
agricultural machinery/equipment/land
the agricultural industry/sector/economy

definition.definition: farming

Agriculture is still largely based on traditional methods in some countries.
The area depends on agriculture for most of its income.
70 percent of the country's population practises subsistence agriculture.

definition.definition: the practice or work of farming
definition.example: Agriculture and tourism are both important to the region’s economy.
Chicago was an important shipping point for agricultural products and livestock.

definition.definition: the business, science, or activity of farming
definition.example:
Recent floods have devastated the state’s agriculture, with sharp declines in its production of corn, soy, and wheat crops.
Over the past ten years the area’s labour force has shifted from agriculture to manufacturing.

definition.definition: a scientist who works in agronomy (= the science of farming)
definition.example: Agronomists were working on new ways to create healthier food while managing the environmental impact of agriculture.

definition.definition: used to express understanding, pleasure, pain, surprise, or the fact that you have noticed something
definition.example:
Ah, I see.
Why has the train stopped? Ah, now we're off again.
Ah, Jessica, how wonderful to see you!
Ah, what a lovely baby!

definition.definition: used to show a sudden feeling, such as one of surprise, pleasure, or understanding
definition.example: Ah, so that’s what the problem was!

definition.definition: used when you suddenly understand or find something
definition.example:
Aha, now I see what you mean!
Aha, that's where I put my keys!

definition.definition: abbreviation for alpha-hydroxy acid: a type of organic acid that is used in some products intended to remove dead skin cells and to make the skin look healthy, attractive, and young:
definition.example:
AHAs (acids derived from milk and fruit sugars) are added to prescription skin creams and cosmetics.

definition.definition: used to express pleasure at suddenly understanding or learning the truth about something
definition.example: Aha! We've found the solution!

definition.definition: in front
definition.example:
The road ahead is very busy.
Turn left at the traffic lights, and you'll see the hospital straight ahead.

definition.definition: having more points, votes, etc. than someone else in a competition, election, etc.
definition.example: Barcelona was ahead after ten minutes.

definition.definition: making more progress than someone else
definition.example: All the children in the class are doing well, but Sophie is way (= far) ahead.

definition.definition: in or into the future
definition.example: He couldn't bear to think of the lonely year ahead.

definition.definition: earlier than or before someone or something
definition.example: It was already 10 AM in Moscow when the news broke in London that morning, because Moscow is three hours ahead.

definition.definition: directly in front
definition.example: She only had a few things in her shopping cart, so I told her she could go ahead of me in the checkout line.

definition.definition: Ahead also means further along in development or achievement
definition.example: Sophie is way ahead of the rest of her class.

definition.definition: in or into the future
definition.example:
We have a lot of hard work ahead of us.
You have to plan ahead when you’re thinking of going to graduate school.

definition.definition: at a better, higher, or greater level than before
definition.example:
be ahead by sth First-half figures showed that pre-tax profits were ahead by 8% to £94.8m.
Full-year profits jumped 25% to £106m pre-tax, which was ahead of expectations.

definition.definition: more developed, advanced, or able to succeed
definition.example:
keep/get/stay ahead To get ahead in the industry you need the right tools and the right connections.
ahead of sb/sth After showing signs of slowing sales growth, the group cut its prices to stay ahead of its rivals.

definition.definition: earlier than a particular moment
definition.example:
Let's meet for lunch. I'll call you ahead of time to decide exactly when and where.

Make the dish a few hours ahead of time to let the flavours develop.

She always planned our meals ahead of time.

definition.definition: having new ideas, opinions, or ways of living long before most other people do
definition.example:
The documentary shows a modern woman years ahead of her time.

UK A feminist and an environmentalist, she was way before her time.

definition.definition: in advance
definition.example: We had a date for lunch, and I said I’d call her ahead of time to decide where.

definition.definition: having very modern ideas
definition.example: He was way ahead of his time in realizing the importance of being able to record sound.

definition.definition: abbreviation for artificial intelligence : the use or study of computer systems or machines that have some of the qualities that the human brain has, such as the ability to interpret and produce language in a way that seems human, recognize or create images, solve problems, and learn from data supplied to them:
definition.example:
The highly realistic "photograph" was actually fake, generated by AI.
AI has helped to create a new antibiotic to combat a deadly superbug.
They called for a pause in the creation of giant AI systems, so that the risks can be properly understood.

definition.definition: abbreviation for artificial intelligence : a particular computer system or machine that has some of the qualities that the human brain has, such as the ability to interpret and produce language in a way that seems human, recognize or create images, solve problems, and learn from data supplied to it:
definition.example:
Would it be possible for an AI to build artificial life forms?
Some people believe that we will soon be able to create sentient AIs.

definition.definition: abbreviation for artificial insemination: the process of putting sperm into a female using methods that do not involve sexual activity between a male and female:
definition.example: The surrogate was impregnated through AI (artificial insemination), thus donating her genetic material as well as carrying the pregnancy herself.

definition.definition: the study of how to make computers that have some of the qualities of the human mind, for example the ability to understand language, recognize pictures, solve problems, and learn
definition.example: Telecommunication and medical industries are harnessing AI developments to improve speech recognition technologies.

definition.definition: computer technology that allows something to be done in a way that is similar to the way a human would do it
definition.example: The techniques of AI are becoming more important, both in industry (eg in robotics ) and in pure research.

definition.definition: help or support
definition.example:
He gets about with the aid of a walking stick.

definition.definition: a piece of equipment that helps you to do something
definition.example:
teaching aids, such as books and videos

definition.definition: help in the form of food, money, medical supplies, or weapons that is given by a richer country to a poorer country
definition.example:

About a fifth of the country's income is in the form of foreign/overseas aid.

definition.definition: in order to collect money for a group of people who need it
definition.example: a concert in aid of famine relief

definition.definition: to help
definition.example:
Huge projects designed to aid poorer countries can sometimes do more harm than good.
His excuse for drinking brandy is that it's said to aid digestion.

definition.definition: to help someone to do something illegal or wrong
definition.example: Three auditors were accused of aiding and abetting the men charged with fraud.

definition.definition: help or support, or something that provides it
definition.example:
[U] He gets around with the aid of a cane.
[U] She went to the aid of a man trapped in his car.
[C] A good dictionary can be a useful aid to understanding a new language.

definition.definition: Aid is often used to refer to help given in the form of food, money, medical supplies, etc., to a country or group of people that is in need or because of an emergency
definition.example:
[U] foreign aid
[U] Aid for the flood victims was on the way.

definition.definition: money, food, medicine, or other supplies that are sent to people or countries who need them because of a difficult situation
definition.example:
appeal for/ask for/seek aid The government has already appealed for 800,000 tonnes of food aid to feed its starving population.
economic/emergency/humanitarian aid
get/receive/accept aid Victims of the flood can receive aid at one of the 19 emergency aid stations set up by the state.
foreign/international/overseas aid

definition.definition: help or support
definition.example:
give/provide/send aid to sb Lawmakers say the plan will create 1 million jobs and provide comfort and aid to the poor.
come to the aid of sb The Bureau will come to the aid of any homeowners pursuing an insurance claim.
government/public/state aid Under the plan, state aid to local businesses would drop by $6.6 million.

definition.definition: to help or support someone or something
definition.example:
Better training policies and new technologies are aiding disabled people in the workplace.
aid in (doing) sth An additional team of contractors was hired to aid in the plant's construction.

definition.definition: to help someone do something that is illegal
definition.example: Prosecutors argued that he aided and abetted in illegal drug cultivation and sale.

definition.definition: a person whose job is to help someone important, such as a member of a government or a military officer of high rank
definition.example:
a senior government aide
an aide to the prime minister

definition.definition: a person whose job is to help someone important, such as a member of a government or a military officer of high rank
definition.example: The senator asked an aide to distribute copies of his speech.

definition.definition: past simple and past participle of aid
to help
definition.example:
Huge projects designed to aid poorer countries can sometimes do more harm than good.
His excuse for drinking brandy is that it's said to aid digestion.

definition.definition: to help someone to do something illegal or wrong
definition.example: Three auditors were accused of aiding and abetting the men charged with fraud.

definition.definition: a military or naval officer who helps an officer of higher rank
definition.example: He became Napoleon's aide-de-camp in 1804.

definition.definition: abbreviation for Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome: a serious disease caused by a virus that destroys the body's natural protection from infection:
definition.example:
Don had full-blown AIDS for over a year before he died.
people living with AIDS

definition.definition: abbreviation for acquired immune deficiency syndrome (= serious disease caused by a virus that destroys the body’s natural protection from infection and can result in death)
to cause difficulty and problems for someone or something
definition.example: The government seems to have no understanding of what ails the country.

definition.definition: to be ill, or to cause to be ill
definition.example: She had been ailing for years before she died.

definition.definition: to feel or cause someone to feel ill, unhealthy, or weak
definition.example: [T] I don’t know what’s ailing her.

definition.definition: experiencing difficulty and problems
definition.example:
the country's ailing economy
Ted asked me if I could help him fix his ailing car.

definition.definition: weak and suffering from illness
definition.example: He's visiting his ailing father.

definition.definition: unhealthy or weak, and not getting any better
definition.example: The plan was supposed to give a boost to our ailing economy.

definition.definition: experiencing financial problems
definition.example: ailing company/economy/industry The ailing company shut down two of its smaller plants in an attempt to trim costs.

definition.definition: an illness
definition.example: Treat minor ailments yourself.

definition.definition: an illness or health problem
definition.example: a respiratory/stomach ailment

definition.definition: a result that your plans or actions are intended to achieve
definition.example:
My main aim in life is to be a good husband and father.
Our short-term aim is to deal with our current financial difficulties, but our long-term aim is to improve the company's profitability.
The leaflet has been produced with the aim of increasing public awareness of the disease.

definition.definition: the act of pointing a weapon towards something
definition.example:
He fired six shots at the target, but his aim was terrible, and he missed all of them.
She raised her gun, took aim and fired.

definition.definition: to intend
definition.example:
[+ to infinitive] I aim to be a millionaire by the time I'm 35.

definition.definition: to point or direct a weapon towards someone or something that you want to hit
definition.example:
Aim (the arrow) a little above the target.
Aim at the yellow circle.
There are hundreds of nuclear missiles aimed at the main cities.

Let's aim for (= go in the direction of) Coventry first, and then we'll have a look at the map.

definition.definition: to point or direct a weapon or other object toward someone or something
definition.example: [T] I turned and saw a big man aiming a camera at me.

definition.definition: To aim something is also to direct it toward someone whom you want to influence or toward achieving something
definition.example: [T] These ads are aimed at young people.

definition.definition: to plan for a specific purpose; intend
definition.example:
The measures aimed at preserving family life.
This book aims at attracting the serious reader.

definition.definition: a result that your plans or actions are intended to achieve
definition.example: The commission’s aim was to convince workers of their extreme importance in ship production.

definition.definition: the act of pointing a weapon toward something
definition.example: She raised her bow, took aim, and hit the bull’s-eye.

definition.definition: abbreviation for Alternative Investment Market: a stock market for small companies that is part of the London Stock Exchange:
definition.example: Originally an AIM share, SFI now has a full listing on the main stock market.

definition.definition: something that you plan or hope to achieve
definition.example:
Our aim is customer satisfaction.
with the aim of doing sth Environmentalists designed the project with the aim of increasing awareness of industrial pollution.

definition.definition: to plan or hope to achieve something
definition.example:
aim to do sth A spokesman for the company says they are aiming to increase sales by 25% next year.
aim for sth The former Senator now aims for a political appointment in Washington.

definition.definition: the mixture of gases that surrounds the earth and that we breathe
definition.example:
I went outside to get some fresh air.

definition.definition: the space above the ground, especially high above the ground
definition.example:

definition.definition: travel in an aircraft
definition.example:
I don't travel much by air.
an air crash/disaster
air travel

definition.definition: manner or appearance
definition.example: She has an air of confidence about her.

definition.definition: If a programme or a person is on/off (the) air, they are/are not broadcasting on radio or television
definition.example: The radio station is on air from 6 a.m.

definition.definition: a simple tune
definition.example: Bach's Air on a G String

definition.definition: to make opinions or complaints known to other people
definition.example:
Putting a complaint in the suggestions box is one way of airing your grievances.

definition.definition: to become dry and/or fresh, or to cause to become dry and/or fresh
definition.example:
My mother always airs the sheets before she makes the beds.
Leave the windows open to let the room air a bit.

definition.definition: to broadcast something or be broadcast on radio or television
definition.example:
The game will be aired live on CBS at 7.00 tonight.

definition.definition: to intentionally ignore or not answer someone
definition.example:
Why is he airing me?
You asked a question and you got aired.

definition.definition: the mixture of gases that surrounds the earth and that we breathe
definition.example: Let’s go outside for some fresh air.

definition.definition: Air pressure is the force that air produces when it presses against any surface.
the space above, esp. high above, the ground
definition.example: Keith kicked the football high in the air.

definition.definition: flight above the ground, esp. in an aircraft
definition.example:
air travel
You can get there by train, but it’s faster by air.

definition.definition: a manner or appearance
definition.example: She had an air of confidence.

definition.definition: a program or a person on the air is broadcasting on radio or television
definition.example: His show is on the air from 8:00 to 8:30 every Tuesday night.

definition.definition: A program or person that is not broadcasting on radio or television is off the air.
to broadcast something on radio or television
definition.example: [T] The game will be aired at 9 p.m. tomorrow.

definition.definition: to make your opinions or complaints known to other people
definition.example: The meeting gave us a chance to air our complaints.

definition.definition: to let air from outside come in a room or other inside space to make it smell cleaner, or to put something outside in the air to make it smell cleaner
definition.example: [M] Let’s open some windows and air out this place.
The third airing of the miniseries will begin next week.

definition.definition: travelling by or using planes
definition.example:
arrive/travel by air 25% of the state's economy is fueled by tourists who travel by air.
deliver/send/ship sth by air The company adds a surcharge for express packages delivered by air.

definition.definition: if a matter is up in the air, it is uncertain and no final decision has been made about it
definition.example: The future of the company has been up in the air since one of its key shareholders was compelled to sell its stake.

definition.definition: a military airport where aircraft are kept and can land and take off
a place for the storage, operation, and care of military aircraft
a machine that keeps the air in a building cool
a machine that cools a room, building, or vehicle

definition.example: New alignments are being formed within the business community.

definition.definition: If two things or people are in alignment, they are the same as or similar to each other, or agree with each other. If they are out of alignment, they are different, or disagree
definition.example:
in alignment At the moment, it seems to me that we're in alignment.
in alignment with The feedback was in alignment with my own experience.
out of alignment On reflection, I think my priorities were out of alignment.
out of alignment with Many families are living in communities where home prices are way out of alignment with incomes.

definition.definition: similar to each other
definition.example: look alike The children all look very alike.

definition.definition: in a similar way
definition.example:
The twins even dress alike.
My father treated us all alike.

definition.definition: used after referring to two groups of people or things to show that both groups are included
definition.example: Friends and family alike were devastated by the news of her death.

definition.definition: similar; like each other
definition.example: You and your father don’t look very much alike.

definition.definition: equally; both
definition.example: She received hundreds of letters of support from friends and strangers alike.

definition.definition: → alimony
food
the parts of the body that food goes through as it is eaten and digested
definition.example:
I had an abscess in the lower part of my alimentary canal.
There may be an obstruction in the alimentary tract.

definition.definition: a regular amount of money that a law court orders a person to pay to his or her partner after a divorce (= the legal ending of a marriage)
a regular amount of money that a court of law orders a person to pay to his or her partner after a divorce (= marriage that has legally ended) or a legal separation
a regular amount of money that a court of law orders a person to pay to their previous wife or husband after a divorce
definition.example: alimony payments

definition.definition: living, not dead
definition.example:
alive and well She's alive and well and living in New Zealand.
keep someone alive Doctors kept him alive on a life-support machine.
stay alive The lost hikers were able to stay alive by finding shelter in a cave in the side of the mountain.
He must be 90 if he's still alive.

definition.definition: If something is alive, it continues to exist
definition.example: keep something alive Relatives of the missing sailors are struggling to keep their hopes alive.

definition.definition: living; having life; not dead
definition.example: I survived the accident with minor injuries, and I was happy to be alive.

definition.definition: Alive can also mean active and energetic or exciting
definition.example: The club really comes alive on weekends.

definition.definition: a substance that has the opposite effect or chemical behaviour to an acid
a substance that has the opposite effect or chemical behavior of an acid
having an effect or chemical behaviour opposite to an acid
definition.example:
Some plants will not grow in very alkaline soils.
Ocean water today is somewhat alkaline.

definition.definition: every one (of), or the complete amount or number (of), or the whole (of)
definition.example:
all but The judge cleared the court of all but (= everyone except) herself and the witness.
all day I've been trying all day to contact you.
all of Did you really drink all of the milk?
all the time Why do you get so angry with me all the time (= very often)?
all the way It's very kind of you to come all the way to meet me.
all that matters So long as he's happy - that's all that matters.
All animals have to eat in order to live.
She has four children, all under the age of five.
The cast all lined up on stage to take their bow.
Have you drunk it all?
All the eggs got broken.
We left the grill on and used up all (of) the propane.
Now the money's all mine!
All my friends agree.
She had £2,000 under the bed and the thieves took it all.
Remember all that trouble we had with the police last year?
I had to use all my powers of persuasion to get her to agree.

definition.definition: the only thing
definition.example: All I need is a roof over my head and a decent meal.

definition.definition: considering all the different parts of the situation together
definition.example: All in all, I think you've done very well.

definition.definition: used when you make a comment or criticism, so that it seems less severe or is less likely to offend someone
definition.example: All I'm saying is I think the end part could have been a little shorter.

definition.definition: the only and small amount or number of something you have
definition.example: Her parents died when she was a baby, so I was all the family she ever had.

definition.definition: completely
definition.example:
all alone The princess lived all alone in the middle of the forest.
all by yourself Can you believe he built that house all by himself?
all over We had a difficult time but it's all over now.
The baby got food all over her dress.
The cake was all eaten last night.
The downstairs rooms were painted all in greens and blues.
Don't let her get you all upset.
She's been all over town looking for you.
I've been hearing all about your weekend!

definition.definition: used after a number to mean that both teams or players in a game have equal points
definition.example: The score at half-time was still four all.

definition.definition: almost
definition.example: The game was all but over by the time we arrived.

definition.definition: in every way
definition.example: It was a ghastly business all round.

definition.definition: even or much better, stronger, more exciting, etc.
definition.example: She felt all the better for the drink.

definition.definition: used in front of many nouns to form adjectives meaning "every", "every type of", or "the whole of" that particular thing
definition.example: an all-night bar (= a bar that is open for the whole night)

definition.definition: used in front of many adjectives and present participles to mean "everything" or "everyone"
definition.example:
an all-inclusive price
all-conquering armies

definition.definition: used in front of many nouns and adjectives to mean "completely"
definition.example:
all-cotton socks (= socks that are made completely of cotton)
When cooking the sauce, don't forget that all-important (= most or very important) ingredient, fresh basil.
Do you believe in an all-powerful god (= one with unlimited power)?

definition.definition: every one of, or the complete number of
definition.example:
All four of her children are under six.
Not all my friends approved of what I did.
All but the weakest plants survived the hot weather.

definition.definition: the whole
definition.example: I’ve been trying all day to contact you.

definition.definition: completely
definition.example:
This coat is all wool.
Is the milk all gone?
Did you drink it all?
Don’t get all upset.

definition.definition: All is also used after a number to mean that both teams or players in a game have equal points
definition.example: The score at halftime was 10 all.

definition.definition: everywhere in a place or area
definition.example:
Soon the news was all over town.
There were these tiny little blue flowers growing all over.

definition.definition: every one
definition.example: All of her children have graduated from high school.

definition.definition: the one thing
definition.example:
Speed is all that matters.
All I need is a hot shower.

definition.definition: if a situation or place is all go, it is extremely busy
definition.example: It was all go in the office today.

definition.definition: to put all your energy or enthusiasm into what you are doing
definition.example: Investors going all out for growth with some risk might be interested in this new unit trust.

definition.definition: from the very beginning
definition.example: Do you think he's been cheating us all along?

definition.definition: from the beginning of a period of time
definition.example: Do you think he’s been lying to us all along?

definition.definition: suddenly and unexpectedly
definition.example: All at once there was a loud crashing sound.

definition.definition: used to emphasize how much something is true or how much someone can do something
definition.example:
I could eat this cake all day long.
We could go on citing examples all day long.
I can read this kind of stuff all day, thanks for writing it!
You can deny it all day, but it's still true.

definition.definition: in a way that risks all your money in a game such as poker
definition.example:
go all in I bet, he raised me, I raised back and then he went all in.
He took the view that rather than pass he had better raise all-in.

definition.definition: in a way that shows a lot of determination and a willingness to take a big risk in order to achieve something
definition.example:
go all in Rather than take the safer path and keep his day job, Merkley went all in and quit his executive post.
Congress and the President have gone all-in to prop up the economy.

definition.definition: in a way that includes everything in a price or total
definition.example:
I calculated that as long as a new fridge cost less than £360 all in, it would have paid for itself in the first year.
Making this delicious almond and raisin lamb curry takes just an hour, all-in.

definition.definition: including everything in a price or total
definition.example:
The all-in cost was £695, including the first consultation.
His estimate of $12-billion is "all in," and includes costs like site preparation and financing.

definition.definition: risking all your money in a game such as poker
definition.example: There was no betting on the round because the player was all in.

definition.definition: showing a lot of determination and a willingness to take a big risk in order to achieve something
definition.example:
He wants the war to end but he is committed and all in.
The actor is known for his daring, all-in style.

definition.definition: very tired, so you are unable to do anything more
definition.example: I'm going home now - I'm all in.

definition.definition: including the costs for all parts of a service
definition.example: an all-in package/price The all-in price includes a pre-theater cocktail and the best available seats at your chosen show.
At $350 each, all-in, the cost of the trip was extremely reasonable.

definition.definition: in a way that risks all your money in a game such as poker
definition.example:
go all in I bet, he raised me, I raised back and then he went all in.
He took the view that rather than pass he had better raise all-in.

definition.definition: in a way that shows a lot of determination and a willingness to take a big risk in order to achieve something
definition.example:
go all in Rather than take the safer path and keep his day job, Merkley went all in and quit his executive post.
Congress and the President have gone all-in to prop up the economy.

definition.definition: in a way that includes everything in a price or total
definition.example:
I calculated that as long as a new fridge cost less than £360 all in, it would have paid for itself in the first year.
Making this delicious almond and raisin lamb curry takes just an hour, all-in.

definition.definition: including everything in a price or total
definition.example:
The all-in cost was £695, including the first consultation.
His estimate of $12-billion is "all in," and includes costs like site preparation and financing.

definition.definition: risking all your money in a game such as poker
definition.example: There was no betting on the round because the player was all in.

definition.definition: showing a lot of determination and a willingness to take a big risk in order to achieve something
definition.example:
He wants the war to end but he is committed and all in.
The actor is known for his daring, all-in style.

definition.definition: very tired, so you are unable to do anything more
definition.example: I'm going home now - I'm all in.

definition.definition: including the costs for all parts of a service
definition.example: an all-in package/price The all-in price includes a pre-theater cocktail and the best available seats at your chosen show.
At $350 each, all-in, the cost of the trip was extremely reasonable.

definition.definition: very quickly
definition.example: It seemed to happen all of a sudden - I felt dizzy and I just collapsed.

definition.definition: quickly and without warning
definition.example: All of a sudden we heard a loud noise.

definition.definition: using as much effort, as many different methods, etc. as possible in order to achieve something
definition.example:
all-out effort We made an all-out effort to get the project finished on time.
all-out assault The army launched an all-out assault on the city.
The supermarket seems to be embarking on an all out campaign to win customers from rivals.

definition.definition: In cricket, a team is all out when it is no longer able to keep batting (= trying to hit the ball and score) because all of its players have had their turn
definition.example:
England were all out for a mere 42 runs.
An all-out total of 307 meant victory for the West Indies by 134 runs.

definition.definition: in a way that uses as much effort, as many different methods, etc. as possible in order to achieve something
definition.example:
go all out My family really goes all out at Christmas, decorating the entire house inside and out and buying mountains of gifts.
The police were working all-out to find the culprit.

definition.definition: at the time when a cricket team is no longer able to keep batting (= trying to hit the ball and score) because all of its players have had their turn
definition.example: The home side collapsed to 169 all out.

definition.definition: complete and using as much effort as possible
definition.example:
an all-out price war/trade war
an all-out bid/campaign/effort US trade officials are making an all-out effort to promote commercial relations with Brazil.

definition.definition: completely finished
definition.example:
We had a difficult time but it's all over now.
It was all over in 10 or 15 minutes.

definition.definition: everywhere in or on a place or an area
definition.example:
The baby got food all over her dress.
People came from all over to hear her sing.
She spilled milk all over.

definition.definition: (in a way that is) satisfactory or reasonably good
definition.example:
do all right I wouldn't say she's rich, but she's doing all right.
Is everything all right, madam?

definition.definition: only just good enough
definition.example:
"What did you think of the film?" "It was all right. Nothing special."
The food was all right, I suppose, but I've had better.

definition.definition: not unpleasant or bad
definition.example:
This wine's all right, isn't it?
Her mum's really strict, but her dad's all right.

definition.definition: very good
definition.example: You can work at home? That's all right, isn't it?

definition.definition: used to show that you think someone is lucky or has an easy life when the same is not true for you
definition.example: It's all right for you - your mum takes care of the children whenever you want.

definition.definition: safe, well, or not harmed
definition.example:
She was very ill for a while but she's all right now.
Did you get home all right (= safely) last night?

definition.definition: able to manage
definition.example:
Are you managing all right in your new job?
Are you sure you'll be all right on your own?
Are you all right with those cases?

definition.definition: used to refuse the offer of food or drink
definition.example: "Can I get you a drink?" "No, I'm all right, thanks."

definition.definition: used to show that something is agreed, understood, or acceptable
definition.example:
all right with I'd rather not go to Tricia's party if that's all right with you.
perfectly all right She seems to think that it's perfectly all right to break the law.
All right, I'll lend you the money.
All right, that's enough noise!
Tell me if you start to feel sick, all right?
"Are you sure you won't come with us?" "All right then. If you insist."
All right, so I made a mistake (= I accept that I was wrong).
Would it be all right if I came?
[+ to infinitive] Chris wants to know if it'll be all right to come over to see us this evening.

definition.definition: an answer to someone who has just thanked you for something or just said sorry for something they have done
definition.example: "Thank you for the flowers." "It's all right (= there's no need to thank me). I thought they might cheer you up."

definition.definition: certainly or without any doubt
definition.example: "Are you sure it was Gillian with him?" "Oh, it was her all right."

definition.definition: used to greet someone at the same time as asking if they are well
definition.example: "All right, John?" "Not bad thanks, and you?"

definition.definition: said with the main emphasis on "right", expressing approval of what has been said or done
definition.example: "Did you hear I hit that creep who'd been pestering me?" "All right!"

definition.definition: (in a way that is) satisfactory or acceptable
definition.example:
The movie was all right – not great, though.
Are you managing all right in your new job?

definition.definition: safe, well, or not harmed
definition.example: She was really sick for a while but she’s all right now.

definition.definition: certainly or without any doubt
definition.example: "Are you sure he was the guy you saw?” “Oh, he was the guy all right."

definition.definition: used to express praise or happiness over what has been said or done
definition.example: "Did you hear I won that writing contest?" "All right!"

definition.definition: used to show that something is agreed, understood, or acceptable
definition.example: I’d rather not go to Jane’s party if that’s all right with you.

definition.definition: despite what has just been said
definition.example: It rained every day of our holiday - but we had a good time all the same.

definition.definition: continuously
definition.example:
I wish you'd stop criticizing me all the time.
Oh, this happens all the time, don't worry.
The technology is improving all the time.
He complains that he's tired all the time.
I was hungry all the time.
We currently have 350 members and it's growing all the time.
Her dog digs in the yard all the time. She's just gotten used to it.

definition.definition: as much as possible or completely
definition.example: If you want to bring it up with the boss, I'll support you all the way.

definition.definition: as a complete total
definition.example: There were 550 people at the festival all told.

definition.definition: in total
definition.example: There were 550 people there all told.

definition.definition: used before an adjective or adverb to emphasize a negative meaning
definition.example:
The holidays flew by all too quickly.
Sadly, horrific scenes like this are all too familiar to the residents of this city.
All too often, the disease goes undetected until it is too late.
It's all too easy to dismiss complaints like this.
As a firefighter, I'm all too aware of the risks of unattended candles.
This is data that could all too easily fall into the wrong hands.

definition.definition: more than is desirable
definition.example: The week passed all too quickly, and it was time to go back home.

definition.definition: the name of God for Muslims and Arab Christians
the Islamic name for God
considered to be typical of the US, and respected and approved of by Americans
definition.example: He was the perfect image of a clean-cut, all-American boy.

definition.definition: involving people or things from everywhere in the US
definition.example: an all-American talent contest/business consortium

definition.definition: used to refer to an amateur sports person from the US who is considered to be one of the best in their sport
definition.example: an all-American football player

definition.definition: an amateur sports person from the US who is considered to be one of the best amateurs in their sport
definition.example: The team was led by an all-American from Yale.

definition.definition: having or showing the values that are typical of the US, or made up completely of the best American things or people
definition.example: He made the all-American team in his last two years of college.
He was a great athlete, and an academic all-American as well.

definition.definition: all-round
having a good variety of skills or abilities
definition.example: Gretzky was an all-around great hockey player.

definition.definition: If you allay a strong emotion felt by someone, such as fear or worry, you cause them to feel it less or to feel calm again
definition.example: The government is trying to allay public fears/concern about the spread of the disease.

definition.definition: to make a negative emotion less strong or a problem less difficult
definition.example: I was nervous, but seeing her allayed my fears.

definition.definition: during the whole part of a period of 24 hours when it is naturally light
definition.example:
It's been raining all day.
He had been sleeping all day and staying up all night.

definition.definition: during the whole of the time in a day that you usually spend at work or at school
definition.example:
I've been trying all day to contact you.
He would run in the morning, then work all day in a factory.

definition.definition: lasting for the whole day
definition.example: an all-day meeting

definition.definition: available throughout the day
definition.example: The café serves an all-day breakfast costing €4.45.

definition.definition: a statement, made without giving proof, that someone has done something wrong or illegal
definition.example:
Several of her patients have made allegations of professional misconduct about/against her.
[+ that] Allegations that Mr Dwight was receiving money from known criminals have caused a scandal.

definition.definition: a statement, made without giving proof, that someone has done something wrong or illegal
definition.example: The allegations of corruption were not true.

definition.definition: a statement that someone has done something wrong or illegal, but which has not been proved to be true
definition.example:
allegation about sth The chief executive of the company resigned last autumn over allegations about his expenses.
allegation that She rejected the allegation that she had treated her staff unfairly.
make allegations of sth (against sb) He made allegations of unfair dismissal against his former employers.

definition.definition: to say that someone has done something illegal or wrong without giving proof
definition.example:
[+ (that)] The two men allege (that) the police forced them to make false confessions.
[+ to infinitive] She is alleged to have been at the centre of an international drug ring.
[+ that] It was alleged that Johnson had struck Mr Rahim on the head.

definition.definition: to state that something bad is a fact without giving proof
definition.example: School districts are alleging the state has not continued to finance schools adequately.
the alleged crime/incident/wrongdoing
The company is being investigated for allegedly falsifying sales records.

definition.definition: to state that someone has done something illegal or wrong without giving proof
definition.example: It is alleged that he used his influential position to steal thousands of pounds of company profits.

definition.definition: said or thought by some people to be the stated bad or illegal thing, although you have no proof
definition.example: It took 15 years for the alleged criminals (= people thought to be criminals) to prove their innocence.

definition.definition: used when something illegal or wrong is said to have been done, but has not been proved
definition.example:
That's where he allegedly killed his wife.
She was arrested for allegedly stealing a car.

definition.definition: used when something is said to be true but has not been proved
definition.example:
It’s a collection of recipes which allegedly can be prepared in 30 minutes.
Two oil companies allegedly spent $6 million trying to free two surviving grey whales trapped in the Arctic ice.

definition.definition: loyalty and support for a ruler, country, group, or belief
definition.example:
pledge allegiance to In many American schools, the students used to pledge allegiance to the flag at the beginning of the school day.
pledge allegiance They all pledged allegiance by kissing the king's hand.
swear allegiance to Soldiers have to swear allegiance to the Crown/the King.
As an Englishman who'd lived for a long time in France, he felt a certain conflict of allegiances when the two countries played soccer.

definition.definition: support for a leader, country, group, or belief
definition.example: [U] For many here, allegiance to the local community comes first.

definition.definition: in or relating to a story, play, picture, or other work in which the characters and events represent moral, religious, or political qualities or ideas
definition.example:
an allegorical novel/painting/play
My father enjoyed Melville's allegorical seafaring tales.

definition.definition: a story, play, poem, picture, or other work in which the characters and events represent particular qualities or ideas that relate to morals, religion, or politics
definition.example:
The play can be read as allegory.
Augustine's "City of God" is an allegory of the triumph of Good over Evil.

definition.definition: a story, play, poem, picture, or other work in which the characters and events represent particular moral, religious, or political qualities or ideas

definition.example: Apples represent people in this allegorical contest between wilderness and civilization.

definition.definition: having an allergy
definition.example: I'm allergic to cats.

definition.definition: caused by an allergy
definition.example: an allergic reaction

definition.definition: having a strong dislike of something
definition.example: My dad's allergic to pop music.

definition.definition: a condition that makes a person become sick or develop skin or breathing problems because they have eaten certain foods or been near certain substances
definition.example:
an allergy to wheat
a wheat allergy

definition.definition: a condition that causes illness when someone eats certain foods or touches or breathes in certain substances
definition.example: Your rash is caused by an allergy to peanuts.
I’m allergic to cats.

definition.definition: to make something bad such as pain or problems less severe
definition.example: The drugs did nothing to alleviate her pain/suffering.

definition.definition: to make pain or problems less severe
definition.example: The medicine did nothing to alleviate her discomfort.

definition.definition: past simple and past participle of alleviate
to make something bad such as pain or problems less severe
definition.example: The drugs did nothing to alleviate her pain/suffering.

definition.definition: a narrow road or path between buildings
definition.example: She walked quickly down the alley.

definition.definition: a path in a park or garden, especially with trees or bushes on both sides
a narrow road or path between buildings, esp. between the backs of buildings
definition.example: I ran down the alley and up the back stairs.

definition.definition: a group of countries, political parties, or people who have agreed to work together because of shared interests or aims
definition.example:
a military alliance
NATO is sometimes called the Atlantic Alliance.

definition.definition: an agreement to work with someone else to try to achieve the same thing
definition.example:
The three smaller parties have forged/formed an alliance against the government.
Some of us feel that the union is in alliance with management against us.

definition.definition: a group of countries, political parties, or people who work together because of shared interests or aims, or the act of forming such a group
definition.example:
[C] Switzerland does not belong to any military alliance.
[U] Alliance against our common enemy is our only hope for survival.

definition.definition: an agreement to work with another person, organization, etc. to try to achieve the same thing
definition.example:
a business/economic/marketing alliance
forge/form/enter into an alliance with sb/sth The company will forge alliances with other car makers similar to joint manufacturing agreements already established in Europe.
alliance between sb (and sb) Many details of the alliance between the two companies have been left unclear.

definition.definition: a group of countries, companies, organizations, etc. who have agreed to work together because of shared interests
definition.example:
a global/an international alliance
The most likely outcome would be a project managed by an alliance of contractors with an equal interest in building the carrier.

definition.definition: working together with another person, organization, etc.
definition.example: The company will also be able to promote its service in alliance with broadband suppliers in which it has made investments.

definition.definition: connected by a political or military agreement
definition.example:
an allied offensive
allied bombers/forces

definition.definition: similar or related in some way
definition.example: Computer science and allied subjects are not taught here.

definition.definition: combined
definition.example: It takes a lot of enthusiasm, allied with/to a love of children, to make a good teacher.

definition.definition: relating to the Allies (= the countries that fought against Germany and the other Axis countries in the Second World War)
definition.example:
Allied forces
the Allied landings in Normandy

definition.definition: See at ally
connected, esp. by having many things in common
definition.example:
allied forces
It takes a lot of enthusiasm allied with a love of children to make a good teacher.

definition.definition: a large reptile with a hard skin that lives in and near rivers and lakes in the hot, wet parts of America and China. It has a long nose that is slightly wider and shorter than that of a crocodile.

a large, hard-skinned reptile (= type of animal) with a long nose that is shorter and slightly wider than that of a crocodile and which lives in and near rivers and lakes in the parts of the US and China
extremely important
definition.example: It was Johansson who scored the all-important goal shortly before half-time.

definition.definition: more important than anything else
definition.example: For this sauce, fresh basil is the all-important ingredient.

definition.definition: the use, especially in poetry, of the same sound or sounds, especially consonants, at the beginning of several words that are close together
definition.example: "Round the rugged rocks the ragged rascal ran" uses alliteration.

definition.definition: the repetition of consonants at the beginning of two or more words, as in "live and learn"
continuing all night
definition.example: I haven't been to an all-night party since my college days.

definition.definition: to give something to someone as their share of a total amount, to use in a particular way
definition.example:
The government is allocating £10 million for health education.
[+ two objects] As project leader, you will have to allocate people jobs/allocate jobs to people.
It is not the job of the investigating committee to allocate blame for the disaster/to allocate blame to individuals.

definition.definition: to give something as a share of a total amount
definition.example: State funds will not be allocated to the program next year.

definition.definition: to give a particular amount of time, money, etc. to someone or something, so that it can be used in a particular way
definition.example:
allocate sth for sth We have allocated €50,000 for printing and mailings.
allocate sth to sb/sth They allocated 3% of the advertising budget to newspaper ads.
allocate capital/funds/money We need to allocate capital and resources more effectively.
allocate time Salespeople should allocate time for work in each area of their business.

definition.definition: to decide officially that something should be given to a particular person
definition.example:
You will be allocated 4,566 shares at the par value of 20p each.
allocate sth among sb It is his job to decide how the responsibilities should be allocated among the different salespersons within the sales force.
allocate sth to sb Federal agencies are required to set goals for allocating a certain percentage of jobs to small companies.

definition.definition: to decide where to put a particular cost or amount in a company's accounts
definition.example: allocate sth to sth The initial amounts received from customers or subscribers should be allocated to two liability accounts.

d_list: 20000+; ACT; GRE; IELTS; MCAT; SAT; TOEFL; TOEIC

definition.definition: the process of giving someone their part of a total amount of something to use in a particular way
definition.example:
the allocation of resources/funds/time
Allocation of the grants was handled by a charity that provides support and advocacy for disabled children.

definition.definition: the part of a total amount of something that someone is given to use in a particular way
definition.example:
The university is offering moving allocations to anyone who is being displaced from properties it acquires.
Higher budgetary allocations for education mean more teachers can be hired and classes can be smaller.

definition.definition: the act or process of giving out parts of a whole, or a part given out in this way
definition.example: [U] The allocation of space in this office is unusual.

definition.definition: the act of deciding officially which person, company, area of business, etc. something should be given to, or what share of a total amount of something such as money or time should be given to someone to use in a particular way
definition.example:
resource/time allocation
The company is holding a review into the optimal allocation of a salesperson's time.
allocation of capital/funds/resources The move will lead to more efficient pricing and allocation of capital.

definition.definition: the share of a total amount of something given to a person, company, etc.
definition.example: The program is financed with a $5 billion annual allocation.

definition.definition: the number of new shares that are offered to each possible buyer, or the process of offering them
definition.example:
The rules on performance-related share allocations are extremely complex.

definition.definition: a cost or an amount that is put in a particular place in a company's accounts, or the process of putting it there
to give something, especially a share of something available, for a particular purpose
definition.example:
[+ two objects] They allotted everyone a separate desk.
They allotted a separate desk to everyone.
The ministry of culture will be allotted about 15% less this year.
Three hours have been allotted to/for this task.
The museum is planning to increase the amount of space allotted to modern art.

definition.definition: to give a share of something for a particular purpose
definition.example: The board allotted $5000 to the recreation center.
[U] There are huge differences in the allotment of highway funds around the state.
Use only the allotted time.

definition.definition: to give a share of something to someone or something to use for a particular purpose
definition.example: allot sth to sb/sth for sth $150,000 has been allotted to the museum for renovations.

definition.definition: a small piece of ground in or just outside a town that a person rents for growing vegetables, fruits, or flowers
the process of sharing something, or the amount that you get
definition.example:
The allotment of the company's shares to its employees is still to be decided.
We have used up this year's allotment of funds.

definition.definition: the process of sharing something, or the amount or share of something that someone or something is given
definition.example: The trade body labeled as illegal last year's allotment of $3.2 billion in cotton subsidies.

definition.definition: the amount of shares that someone is given when new shares are being made available
definition.example: an allotment of 200 bonus shares

definition.definition: using as much effort, as many different methods, etc. as possible in order to achieve something
definition.example:
all-out effort We made an all-out effort to get the project finished on time.
all-out assault The army launched an all-out assault on the city.
The supermarket seems to be embarking on an all out campaign to win customers from rivals.

definition.definition: In cricket, a team is all out when it is no longer able to keep batting (= trying to hit the ball and score) because all of its players have had their turn
definition.example:
England were all out for a mere 42 runs.
An all-out total of 307 meant victory for the West Indies by 134 runs.

definition.definition: in a way that uses as much effort, as many different methods, etc. as possible in order to achieve something
definition.example:
go all out My family really goes all out at Christmas, decorating the entire house inside and out and buying mountains of gifts.
The police were working all-out to find the culprit.

definition.definition: at the time when a cricket team is no longer able to keep batting (= trying to hit the ball and score) because all of its players have had their turn
definition.example: The home side collapsed to 169 all out.

definition.definition: complete and using as much effort as possible
definition.example:
an all-out price war/trade war
an all-out bid/campaign/effort US trade officials are making an all-out effort to promote commercial relations with Brazil.

definition.definition: to give permission for someone to do something, or to not prevent something from happening
definition.example:
[+ to infinitive] Do you think Dad will allow you to go to Jamie's party?
You're not allowed to talk during the exam.
Her proposals would allow (= make it possible for) more people to stay in full-time education.
The loophole has allowed hundreds of drink-drivers to avoid prosecution.
The government has refused to allow foreign journalists into the area for several weeks.
Prisoners have been moved to allow the demolition of part of the prison.
Pets aren't allowed in this hotel.
[+ -ing verb] Smoking is not allowed in this restaurant.
[+ two objects] He didn't allow us enough time to finish the test.
Red Cross officials were allowed access to the prison for the first time a few days ago.
UK The referee decided to allow (= officially accept) the goal.
At the weekend I allow myself (= I give myself the special pleasure of having) a box of chocolates.
How much time do you allow yourself (= make available to yourself) to get ready in the morning?

definition.definition: a polite expression used when offering to help in some way
definition.example: You can't carry all those bags yourself - please, allow me.

definition.definition: to admit or agree that something is true
definition.example: She allowed that she might have been too suspicious.

definition.definition: to let someone do something or let something happen; permit
definition.example:
You’re not allowed to talk during the exam.
Are you allowed in the building on weekends?
Video links allow rural schoolchildren to be taught by teachers hundreds of miles away.

definition.definition: to make it possible for something to be done or to happen
definition.example:
He didn’t allow enough time to finish the test.
Be sure to allow room in your bags for the souvenirs you’ll want to bring home.
Our well water has nitrates above the allowable level.

definition.definition: to make it possible for someone to do something, or to not prevent something from happening
definition.example:
allow sb/sth to do sth The website allows consumers to compare the prices of all energy and telephone providers.
The extra compensation was allowed, overriding regulations that otherwise would not allow the payouts.
Typing in this code will allow access to the data stored on the hard drive.

definition.definition: to give enough time for something to happen
definition.example:
Allow at least 14 days to receive your policy and cover confirmation.
allow sth for sth You will need to allow up to six weeks for delivery.

definition.definition: to take a cost or an amount off your income or profit before the tax owed is calculated
definition.example: The Australian Taxation Office allows tax deductions for voluntary donations to charity.

definition.definition: to take a certain amount of money from the price of something
definition.example: allow sb sth for sth A dealer will be able to tell you how much you would be allowed in part-exchange for your existing vehicle.

definition.definition: to accept or agree that something is true or correct
definition.example:

allow that When I pressed her, she allowed that a mistake might have been made.

definition.definition: to consider something when you are planning something
definition.example:

[+ -ing verb] You should allow for the plane being delayed.
We have to allow for the possibility that we might not finish on schedule.

definition.definition: to take something into consideration; to plan for something
definition.example: Does your insurance allow for home nursing care?

definition.definition: to consider someone or something when you are planning something
definition.example:
Existing contracts do not allow for any reduction once the pension is being paid.
We have to allow for the possibility of the project being delayed.

definition.definition: allowed according to the rules or laws that control a particular area of activity
definition.example:
A certain level of error is allowable (= permitted to happen).
UK allowable expenses (= expenses on which no taxes are paid)

definition.definition: allowed according to the laws or rules that control a particular area of activity
definition.example: allowable amount/level/limit The amounts of mercury present far exceeded the Japanese government's allowable level.

definition.definition: relating to a cost or an amount that can be taken off your income or profit before the tax owed is calculated
definition.example:
allowable deductions/costs/expenses
Training costs are allowable as a business deduction.

definition.definition: money that you are given regularly, especially to pay for a particular thing

The perks of the job include a company pension and a generous travel allowance.
