Prices have risen by an average of four percent over the past year.
My income's rather variable, but I earn £175 a day on average.

definition.definition: a standard or level that is considered to be typical or usual
definition.example:
The audience figures were lower than average for this sort of film.
In western Europe, a seven to eight-hour working day is about the average.
On average, people who don't smoke are healthier than people who do.
The quality of candidates was (well) below/above average.
I expect to spend an average of $50 to $60 on a meal in a restaurant.

definition.definition: to reach a particular amount as an average
definition.example:
Enquiries to our office average 1,000 calls a month.
Many doctors average (= work an average of) 70 hours a week.
Trainee accountants average (= earn an average of) £32,000 per year.

definition.definition: An average number is the number you get by adding two or more amounts together and dividing the total by the number of amounts
definition.example:
average earnings/income/rainfall
The average age of the US soldiers who fought in the Vietnam War was 19.

definition.definition: typical and usual
definition.example:
The average person on the street is a lot better off than they were 40 years ago.
a student of average ability
The food was fairly average (= not excellent, although not bad).

definition.definition: a standard or level that is considered to be typical or usual
definition.example: The quality of her work is well above average.

definition.definition: the result obtained by adding two or more amounts together and dividing the total by the number of amounts, or by another total
definition.example:
I’m 35 and my brothers are 32 and 26, so the average of our ages is 31.
In his third season on the team, he raised his batting average to .270.
Interest rates rose on average to 10.05% in January.

definition.definition: the result that you get by adding two or more amounts together and dividing this total by the number of amounts
definition.example:
daily/monthly/quarterly average Trading was 297 million shares, down from the three-month daily average of 313 million shares.
The state's unemployment rate remained well below the national average of 5.7 percent.
an average of Its economy has grown at an annual average of 3.6% for the past seven years.
Regulators are careful to stress that the performance figures are only averages - some companies performed better.

definition.definition: a level or standard that is considered to be typical for a particular place, group of people, type of business, etc.
definition.example:
above/below (the) average Our companies' profitability is above the sector average.
Most of these businesses match industry averages in job creation.

definition.definition: → partial loss
an average that is based on a particular group of companies' shares, which is used to represent changes in the stock market or to show which types of businesses are getting the most investors
definition.example: the industrial average

definition.definition: typically or usually
definition.example: On average, only about half of the consumers who qualify for a rebate actually collect it.

definition.definition: used to describe an amount that you get by adding two or more amounts together and then dividing by the number of amounts
definition.example:
average price/cost/value Price rises were strong in Wales, where the average cost of a property jumped by 31.8%.
average age/speed/rate The average age of the 'Times' reader is fairly low at 42.

definition.definition: typical and usual
definition.example: The cost of health insurance has risen above the means of the average worker.

definition.definition: not bad, but not excellent either
definition.example: Despite high expectations, sales levels last quarter were only average.

definition.definition: to equal a particular rate or amount as an average
definition.example: Traffic on its free website averages about 10,000 visitors a month.

definition.definition: to calculate the average amount of something by adding all the amounts together and then dividing this by the number of amounts
definition.example: Each quarter, the magazine polls a group of forecasters and averages their predictions for economic growth.

definition.definition: to calculate the average of a set of numbers or amounts
definition.example: If I average out what I earn a month, it's about £1,500.

definition.definition: to be or become equal in amount or number
definition.example: The highs and lows of life tend to average out in the end.

definition.definition: to become equal or similar over a period of time
definition.example: The highs and lows of life tend to average out.

definition.definition: to calculate the average of a set of numbers or amounts
definition.example:
To calculate any profit, the final level of the index will be averaged out over the past 12 months.
This is the equivalent of 37,000 families paying nearly £3 billion, around £80,000 each if you average it out.

definition.definition: to equal a particular rate or amount, based on an average that is calculated over a period of time
definition.example:
People are usually prepared to accept a spread of investment that covers different risk levels, providing they average out at the level of risk sought.
Annual salaries among its workforce of 6,608 averaged out to around £27,000.

definition.definition: strongly disliking or opposed to
definition.example:
Few people are averse to the idea of a free holiday.
I'm not averse to (= I like) the occasional glass of champagne myself.

definition.definition: strongly disliking or opposed to
definition.example: Few politicians are averse to appearing on television.

definition.definition: (a person or thing that causes) a feeling of strong dislike or of not wishing to do something
definition.example:
I felt an instant aversion to his parents.
She has a deep aversion to getting up in the morning.
Greed is my pet aversion (= the thing I dislike most of all).

definition.definition: a feeling of strong dislike or unwillingness to do something
definition.example:
I felt an instant aversion to his parents.
She has a deep aversion to getting up early.

definition.definition: to prevent something bad from happening
definition.example:
to avert a crisis/conflict/strike/famine
to avert disaster/economic collapse

definition.definition: to turn away your eyes or thoughts
definition.example:
I averted my gaze/eyes while he dressed.
We tried to avert our thoughts from our massive financial problems.

definition.definition: to prevent something bad from happening; avoid
definition.example: The last-minute agreement averted renewed fighting.

definition.definition: to turn away your eyes or thoughts
definition.example: The shy man was standing before me, his eyes averted.

definition.definition: to prevent something bad from happening
definition.example:
avert a crisis/disaster He argued that the way to avert an economic crisis is for individuals to follow their usual spending habits.
avert industrial action/a strike By law, the president may appoint a board to avert a strike that could result in widespread interruption of U.S. rail service.

definition.definition: of or relating to birds
a large cage (= area surrounded by wire or bars) or closed space in which birds are kept as pets
the activity of flying aircraft, or of designing, producing, and keeping them in good condition
definition.example:
the British Civil Aviation Authority
the US Federal Aviation Administration
aviation fuel

definition.definition: the activity of flying aircraft, or of designing, producing, and maintaining them

definition.example: Charles Lindbergh was the first aviator to fly nonstop across the Atlantic Ocean.

definition.definition: the business of designing and manufacturing aircraft
definition.example:
Aviation experts expect authorities to start discussions for $2 billion-worth of business.
the aviation industry/sector

definition.definition: the activity of transporting people and goods by aircraft
definition.example: aviation safety/security The FAA oversees aviation safety.

definition.definition: an aircraft pilot
definition.example: Amy Johnson was a pioneering aviator who made record-breaking flights to Australia and South Africa in the 1930s.

definition.definition: extremely eager or interested
definition.example:
an avid football fan
an avid supporter of the arts
He took an avid interest in the project.
formal She hadn't seen him for six months and was avid for news.

definition.definition: extremely eager or interested
definition.example: Knowles is an avid runner and cross-country skier.
We listened avidly to the news from our secret radios.

definition.definition: the quality of being extremely eager or interested
definition.example:
He studied Indian history with avidity.
It seems I'm an ideal target for advertisers, and I am perplexed by the avidity with which they court me.

definition.info: [C or U] plural avocados (UK also avocado pear)
definition.definition: a tropical fruit with thick, dark green or purple skin, a large, round seed, and soft, pale green flesh that can be eaten
definition.example:
Half an avocado contains about 160 calories.
Guacamole is a dip, spread or salad made with mashed avocado.

definition.definition: a pale green colour like the flesh of an avocado
definition.example:
The walls are painted a pale avocado.
I tried the linen trousers in a shade of avocado green.

definition.definition: of a pale green colour like the flesh of an avocado
definition.example:
The Brussels sprouts turn bright green and then start to fade to a more avocado colour.
The appliances were all avocado green.

definition.definition: a fruit with thick green or black skin, a large round seed at the center, and oily green or yellow flesh, which is often eaten as a vegetable in salads
something that a person does as an interest or hobby and that is not that person's regular job
definition.example:
The last section of the questionnaire has a space for us to list our avocations and interests.
She started painting six years ago as an avocation, and next week her paintings will be displayed in a gallery exhibition for the first time.

definition.definition: work you do in addition to your main job or profession, especially for enjoyment
definition.example: She's a real-estate developer who describes her consultancy business as "a part-time avocation."

definition.definition: to stay away from someone or something
definition.example:
I try to avoid supermarkets on Saturdays - they're always so busy.
I'm anxious to avoid the motorway at rush hour.
Do you think Lukas is avoiding me? I haven't seen him all day.

definition.definition: to prevent something from happening or to not allow yourself to do something
definition.example:
[+ -ing verb] I try to avoid going shopping on Saturdays.
The report studiously avoided any mention of the controversial plan.
The plane narrowly avoided disaster when one of the engines cut out on take-off.
I left the pub to avoid a fight (= prevent a fight from happening).
Unnecessary paperwork should be avoided (= prevented) at all costs.

definition.definition: to stay away from someone or something, or prevent something from happening, or not allow yourself to do something
definition.example:
Do you think Robert is avoiding me? I haven’t seen him for a month.
I try to avoid going shopping on Saturdays because the stores are so crowded.
If you want to lose weight, avoid eating between meals.
The avoidance of injury is more important than winning a game.

definition.definition: to try to prevent something bad from happening
definition.example:
A spokeswoman for the company said it was hoping to avoid industrial action.
Understanding differing viewpoints is a good start toward avoiding conflict in the workplace.

definition.definition: to try not to do something, or to try to stay away from something
definition.example:
The government avoided the mistakes they made in the past.
avoid doing sth Credit cards can be a source of free credit if you can organize payments within the stipulated time limits, so as to avoid paying interest.

definition.definition: the act of avoiding something or someone
definition.example: The avoidance of injury is critical to a professional athlete.

definition.definition: the practice of avoiding something
definition.example:
Health insurance companies who have been showing very healthy profits have engaged in very serious risk avoidance.
avoidance of sth The state requires that employers instruct employees in the recognition and avoidance of unsafe conditions.

definition.definition: an area in southwestern England that was a county (= an area with its own local government) until 1996
definition.example:
The hotel is in Bath, Avon.
A pair of barn owls were bred at a farm in Avon.

definition.definition: to admit something or say something publicly
definition.example:
[+ that] He avowed that he regretted what he had done.
It is a society in which homosexuality is rarely avowed.

definition.definition: a statement in which you say or admit something that you believe, support, or intend to do
definition.example:
They were imprisoned for their avowal of anti-government beliefs.
Her public avowals to reduce crime have yet to be put into effect.

definition.definition: friendly, kind, or helpful, like the expected behaviour of an uncle
definition.example:
an avuncular, quietly spoken man
His avuncular image belies his steely determination.

definition.definition: used to express disappointment or disapproval
definition.example:
He says "Aw, I thought you were somebody else."
If you don't vote, you can't go around saying, "Aw man, everything's all wrong!"
Aw gee, you said you weren't gonna cry!
Aww, you ruined it!

definition.definition: used to express sympathy or love, especially when you find something or someone cute (= attractive and pleasant in the way that babies or baby animals are)
definition.example:
Aw, that poor guy.
All the aunties had that "Aw, isn't he cute?" look on their faces.
Aww, bless their hearts, they did their best.

definition.definition: to wait for or be waiting for something
definition.example:
He's anxiously awaiting his test results.
A marvellous reception awaited me on my first day at work.
The long/eagerly awaited sequel is now available online.

definition.definition: to wait for or be in the future of someone or something
definition.example:
The two men are awaiting trial, scheduled to begin next month.
There are no jobs awaiting those farmers.

definition.definition: past simple and past participle of await
to wait for or be waiting for something
definition.example:
He's anxiously awaiting his test results.
A marvellous reception awaited me on my first day at work.
The long/eagerly awaited sequel is now available online.

definition.definition: not sleeping
definition.example:
"Is Oliver awake yet?" "Yes, he's wide (= completely) awake and running around his bedroom."
I find it so difficult to stay awake during history lessons.
I drink a lot of coffee to keep me awake.
She used to lie awake at night worrying about how to pay the bills.

definition.definition: If you are awake to something, you know about it
definition.example: Businesses need to be awake to the advantages of European integration.

definition.definition: to stop sleeping or to make someone stop sleeping
definition.example:
I awoke at seven o'clock.
She awoke me at seven.

definition.definition: to start to understand or feel something or to make someone start to understand or feel something
definition.example:
The chance meeting awoke the old passion between them.
Young people need to awake to the risks involved in casual sex.

definition.definition: not sleeping
definition.example: If I drink coffee late in the day, I can’t sleep and stay awake all night.

definition.definition: to stop sleeping, or to cause someone to stop sleeping
definition.example: [I] I awoke at 7, as usual.

definition.definition: to stop sleeping or to make someone stop sleeping
definition.example:
They were awakened by the sound of gunfire.
I awakened at dawn to find him beside me.

definition.definition: to stop sleeping, or to cause someone to stop sleeping
definition.example: [T] The family was awakened by a noise.

definition.definition: fig. If interest is awakened, it is made more active
definition.example: [T] His television series awakened popular interest in American architecture.

definition.definition: the act of starting to understand something or feel something
definition.example:
a religious awakening
the awakening of public concern about the environment
He's in for a rude awakening (= will be shocked) when he starts work!

definition.definition: to give money or a prize following an official decision
definition.example:
Carlos was awarded first prize in the essay competition.
The jury awarded libel damages of £100,000.
[+ two objects] The university has awarded her a $500 travel grant.

definition.definition: a prize or an amount of money that is given to someone following an official decision
definition.example:
They have authorized awards of £900 to each of the victims.
the Academy Award for Best Director

definition.definition: to give something valuable, such as money or a prize following an official decision
definition.example:
Her poodle was awarded first prize in the dog show.
Their company was awarded a contract worth $40 million by the federal government.
Marion Jones won the Jesse Owens award as the outstanding athlete of the year.

definition.definition: a prize or a sum of money that a person or organization is given for an achievement
definition.example:
A new digital innovation award is aimed at media that uses the latest technology to make an improvement in delivery of news services.
an award for sth A recently launched advertising agency got an award for best marketing campaign of 2009.
Four finalists shared the top cash award of $160,000.
accept/receive/win an award The airline received an environmental award for work relating to carbon-emissions reduction.
give/make/present an award We have no hesitation in giving an award to this interesting example of large-scale urban regeneration.

definition.definition: a sum of money that a court of law decides is owed by a company, organization, or person to someone they have treated unfairly, injured in an accident, etc.
definition.example:
Justice Andrew Reid confirmed that the award would total $15.5m.
an award of sth The jury made an award of £380,000 in damages.
make/uphold/grant an award An award for continuing cost of care for survivors of the crash was upheld by the Court of Appeal.
compensation/compensatory/damage(s) award The rail company challenged the compensation payout, claiming that the damages award was excessive.

definition.definition: an amount of money paid by a company to an employee as an increase in income or as a special payment for success
definition.example:
an award for sth Awards for all 600 executives have been ruled out as the group struggles to recover from a catastrophic 12-month period.
As head of the bank's US credit business, she got an award of £2.18m.

definition.definition: a sum of money, work, etc. that is officially given to a company or organization
definition.example: Including the Port Authority's $3 million award, the company got a total of $3.93 million in grants.

definition.definition: → award wage
to officially give work, a sum of money, etc. to a company or organization
definition.example:
Firms making big campaign contributions are often awarded lucrative government grants.
award a grant/contract (to sb) The Pentagon has awarded a $520 million contract to the construction company.
award sb sth The company awarded them the concrete subcontract on the five-story parking structure.

definition.definition: if a court awards a sum of money to someone who has been unfairly treated, injured in an accident at work, etc., it orders the person, company, or organization that is responsible to pay it
definition.example:
be awarded $1 million/£250,000, etc. She was awarded £600,000 in damages as part of a libel action.
award sth to sb/award sb sth The jury will award $1.78 million in compensation and more than $99 million in punitive damages to victims.
award sth in damages/compensation/costs

definition.definition: to give an employee an increase in income or a special payment as a reward for success
definition.example:
award sth to sb/award sb sth The Association has just announced that it will be awarding more than $14 million in annual pay rises to staff.
be awarded sth Many of the investment bank's employees have been awarded much smaller performance bonuses than they were led to expect.

definition.definition: to give a prize or a sum of money to a person, company, or organization who has been very successful
definition.example:
be awarded sth The restaurant was one of only three to be awarded four Michelin stars this year.
Nearly $72,000 in scholarships were awarded by about 30 companies.

definition.definition: the act of giving something such as money or a prize following an official decision
definition.example:
We accept no liability for anything related to the contest and the awarding of prizes.
The awarding of these grants to applicants who do not appear to meet the required standard raises serious questions.

definition.definition: knowing that something exists, or having knowledge or experience of a particular thing
definition.example:
[+ that] I wasn't even aware that he was ill.
Were you aware of the risks at the time?
She was well (= very) aware that he was married.
"Has Claude paid the phone bill?" "Not as far as I'm aware." (= I don't think so)
I suddenly became aware of (= started to notice) him looking at me.

definition.definition: having special interest in or experience of something and so knowing what is happening in that subject at the present time
definition.example:
to be ecologically/politically aware
sexually aware

definition.definition: knowing that something exists, or having knowledge or experience of a particular thing
definition.example:
[+ (that) clause] We were just not aware (that) garbage would be a problem, that we ever would need to recycle.
Are you aware of any reason why you cannot act fairly as a juror in this trial?
His tragedy has brought a heightened awareness to the conditions surrounding heatstroke.

definition.definition: knowledge that something exists, or understanding of a situation or subject at the present time based on information or experience
definition.example:
Public awareness of the problem will make politicians take it seriously.
Environmental awareness has increased dramatically over the past decade.

definition.definition: knowledge and understanding of a particular activity, subject, etc.
definition.example:
customer/public/consumer awareness Assessment procedures reveal how effectively the brand translates customer awareness into purchases and retention.
awareness of sth Recent campaigns have led to a dramatic increase in awareness of environmental issues.
build/increase/raise awareness The guidelines are an important tool for raising awareness about current management thinking.
increasing/growing/heightened awareness Employees are using a heightened awareness of work flow and demand to cut waste, eliminate cost, and boost quality.

definition.definition: covered with a liquid, especially water
definition.example: By the time I discovered the problem, the floor was awash.

definition.definition: having an amount of something that is very large or larger than necessary or wanted
definition.example: The city is awash with drugs and the police are powerless to do anything about it.

definition.definition: covered with a liquid, usually water
definition.example: They believe that the red planet was not only awash in water at one time, but also may have supported life.

definition.definition: If someone or some place is awash in something that is not a liquid, there is a large amount of it
definition.example: The reason why I say that is because the country is awash in money.

definition.definition: somewhere else, or to or in a different place, position, or situation
definition.example:
give something away I've given away all my old clothes to charity.
go away Just go away and leave me alone!
keep away Keep away from the fire.
stay away The children were told to stay away from the dog.
Ms Watson is away on holiday until the end of the week.
The sight was so horrible that I had to look/turn away.
The recent flood has swept away the footbridge.
UK Would you like your burger to eat in or take away?

definition.definition: at a distance (of or from here)
definition.example:
How far away is the station?
The office is a half-hour drive away.
We live five kilometres away from each other.
Life's so much quieter away from the city.
miles away informal Oh, it's miles away (= a long distance from here).

definition.definition: in or into the usual or a suitable place, especially one that can be closed
definition.example:
Would you put the ice cream away in the freezer?
My grandparents had £800 hidden away in an old shoe box.

definition.definition: gradually until mostly or completely gone
definition.example:
All the snow had melted away.
The music faded away as the procession moved slowly up the street.
while away We used to while away the weekends at my aunt's house in the country.
We danced the night away (= until the night was over).

definition.definition: in the future
definition.example: My English exam's only a week away and I haven't even started to prepare.

definition.definition: continuously or repeatedly, or in a busy way
definition.example:
I was still writing away when the exam finished.
Chris has been working away in the garden all day.
We were chatting away at the back and didn't hear what he said.

definition.definition: at an opposing team's sports ground
definition.example:
The team was playing away at Old Trafford.
We have won away from home a couple of times this season.

definition.definition: An away match or game is played at an opposing team's sports ground
definition.example:
away game We lost the away game but won both home games.
away strip UK Everton unveiled their new yellow-and-blue away strip.
away kit UK They were wearing their new away kit for the first time at Saturday's game.

definition.definition: somewhere else, or to or in a different place, position, or situation
definition.example:
Barbara is away on vacation until the end of the week.
The Jeffersons went away for the weekend, but they’ll be back on Monday.

definition.definition: at a distance (from this place)
definition.example: How far away is the station?

definition.definition: in the future; from now
definition.example: The wedding is still six months away.

definition.definition: in or into the usual or a suitable place, esp. one that is enclosed
definition.example: Put the groceries away before you go out again.

definition.definition: gradually until mostly or completely gone
definition.example: The music faded away.

definition.definition: continuously or repeatedly, or actively
definition.example: Chris has been working away on the car all day.

definition.definition: a feeling of great respect sometimes mixed with fear or surprise
definition.example:
I've always held musicians in awe.
As children we were rather in awe of our grandfather.
You can't help but stand in awe of (= respect greatly and fear slightly) powerful people.

definition.definition: to cause someone to feel awe
definition.example:
I was awed but not frightened by the huge gorilla.
Her paintings have awed and amazed the public for half a century.
The audience was awed into silence by her stunning performance.

definition.definition: a feeling of great respect, usually mixed with fear or surprise
definition.example: I was too much in awe of him to address him directly.

definition.definition: If something is awe-inspiring, it causes you to admire or respect it a lot
definition.example: Niagara Falls is an awe-inspiring sight.
The school kids were awed when Doug Flutie, the football star, entered the room.

definition.definition: feeling great respect, sometimes mixed with fear or surprise
definition.example:
We stood there in awed silence.
"How does she manage to run so fast at her age?" he asked in awed tones.

definition.definition: causing feelings of great admiration, respect, or fear
definition.example:
An awesome challenge/task lies ahead of them.
awesome scenery

definition.definition: extremely good
definition.example: You look totally awesome in that dress.

definition.definition: causing feelings of great admiration, respect, or fear
definition.example:
an awesome achievement
slang Your new haircut is awesome (= extremely good).

definition.definition: extremely bad or unpleasant
definition.example:
He suffered awful injuries in the crash.
We had awful weather.
She has an awful boss.
What an awful thing to say!
Would life be so awful without a car?
The food was awful.
She'd been ill and she looked awful.

definition.definition: very great
definition.example:
I don't know an awful lot (= very much) about art, but I'm learning.
Fortunately it won't make an awful lot of difference if I don't pass the test.
It was an awful risk to take.

definition.definition: very bad, unpleasant, or of low quality
definition.example:
The weather was awful the whole time – cold and wet.
Fox TV has canceled the truly awful sitcom "Monty" after a short tryout.

definition.definition: Awful also means very great or large
definition.example: We're spending an awful amount of money!

definition.definition: very or extremely, when used before an adjective or adverb
definition.example:
It's an awfully long time since we last saw each other.
I'm awfully sorry, but we've forgotten to reserve you a table.

definition.definition: extremely badly
definition.example: England played awfully throughout the game.

definition.definition: very or extremely
definition.example:
Your fever is awfully high – I think we’d better call a doctor.
I’m awfully sorry, but there are no rooms in the hotel available right now.
We were awfully pleased when our daughter was named the best student in her class.

definition.definition: for a short time
definition.example:
Stay awhile and rest.
I read awhile, then slept.

definition.definition: for a short time
definition.example: I’d like to rest awhile before we continue.

definition.definition: difficult to use, do, or deal with
definition.example:
It's an awkward corner, so take it slowly.
Some of the questions were rather awkward.
It was an awkward ascent, but we reached the top eventually.
[+ to infinitive] My car's quite awkward to drive.
He's an awkward customer (= a difficult person to deal with).

definition.definition: causing problems, worry, or embarrassment
definition.example:
awkward position The government finds itself in a very awkward position.
awkward situation He put us in a very awkward situation by asking us what we thought of his new girlfriend right in front of her.
awkward silence There followed an awkward silence while we all tried to think of something to say.
They'd chosen an awkward time to call as I'd just got into the bath.
awkward question The police asked some awkward questions about where the money had come from.

definition.definition: embarrassed or nervous
definition.example:
feel awkward I always feel awkward when I'm with Chris - he's so difficult to talk to.
He seemed a little awkward when I first met him.

definition.definition: intentionally not helpful
definition.example: Just stop being so awkward and help me push the car, will you!

definition.definition: moving in a way that is not natural, relaxed, or attractive
definition.example: His movements were slow and awkward.

definition.definition: difficult to use, do, or deal with
definition.example: The computer came in a big box that was awkward to carry.

definition.definition: causing inconvenience, anxiety, or embarrassment
definition.example: It was an awkward situation, because the restaurant was too expensive for us but we didn’t want to just get up and walk out.

definition.definition: Someone who feels awkward feels embarrassed or nervous
definition.example: We were the first to arrive at the party and felt a little awkward.

definition.definition: lacking grace or skill when moving
definition.example: He’s too awkward – he’ll never be a good dancer.
His awkwardness with girls disappeared once he got to college.

definition.definition: in a worried or embarrassed way
definition.example: He shifted awkwardly from one foot to the other.

definition.definition: in an embarrassing or worrying way, or a way that causes problems
definition.example: The publication of the economic statistics was awkwardly timed for the government.

definition.definition: moving in a way that is not natural, relaxed, or attractive
definition.example:
She fell awkwardly when she was skiing and twisted her ankle.
He walked awkwardly across the room, aware that they were watching.

definition.definition: in a way that is difficult to deal with, use, or do
definition.example: The car was parked awkwardly across the pavement.

definition.definition: in an intentionally unhelpful way
definition.example: He stood there awkwardly, refusing to move.

definition.definition: so as to make something difficult to deal with
definition.example: The publication of the article was awkwardly timed for the government.

definition.definition: without grace
definition.example: He sat awkwardly on the floor.

definition.definition: embarrassment, or a situation that is difficult and not relaxed
definition.example:
In spite of the divorce, there was no awkwardness between them - in fact they seemed very much at ease.
The internet removes the awkwardness of a face-to-face interaction.

definition.definition: the situation of being difficult to use, do, or deal with
definition.example:
The awkwardness of the shape makes the desk difficult to lift.
the awkwardness of making complex arrangements to suit so many people

definition.definition: a quality of not being natural, relaxed, or attractive
definition.example:
He outgrew his physical awkwardness and became a leading man in school plays.
The world of high fashion has embraced ugliness or awkwardness as a new kind of beauty.

definition.definition: the fact of being deliberately unhelpful
definition.example: Is he really unable to help or is it just awkwardness?

definition.definition: a pointed tool for making small holes in wood or leather
a cloth or plastic cover fastened to a building or structure and supported by a frame that is used to protect someone or something from the sun or rain
definition.example: The gaily striped awnings of the market stalls made an attractive scene.

definition.definition: a piece of material supported by a frame and used to protect part of a building from the sun or rain
not in the intended way
definition.example:
Anything that goes awry (= goes wrong) in the office is blamed on Pete.
The strike has sent the plans for investment seriously awry.

definition.definition: in the wrong position
definition.example: She rushed in, her face red and sweaty and her hat awry.

definition.definition: not in the intended manner, or out of position, or wrong
definition.example: There are too many people involved, and something is bound to go awry.

definition.definition: a tool consisting of a heavy iron or steel blade at the end of a long wooden handle, used for cutting wood
The ax is the order to give up your job or to stop or prevent something from happening
definition.example:
Three staff members got the ax yesterday.
If the budget is cut, educational programs will get the ax.
Everyone is scared to death wondering where the ax will fall next.

definition.definition: to order someone suddenly to give up a job, or to stop or reduce something suddenly
definition.example:
The company has already axed 14 people, and many more may lose their jobs.
Yesterday the airline axed three of its daily flights to Chicago.

definition.definition: a type of jump in figure skating (= the sport of moving on skates making patterns and jumps) in which the skater jumps with knees bent while facing forwards and lands facing backwards, with one or more turns in the air in between
definition.example:
She began her program with a double axel.
Nothing seemed to go right with my routine and I missed the axel.

definition.definition: relating to or around a real or imaginary straight line going through the centre of an object that is spinning, or a line that divides a symmetrical shape into two equal halves
relating to an imaginary line through the centre of the body
relating to the axis (= the second of the small bones in the neck that form the spine and support the skull)
a statement or principle that is generally accepted to be true, but need not be so
definition.example: It is a widely held axiom that governments should not negotiate with terrorists.

definition.definition: a formal statement or principle in mathematics, science, etc., from which other statements can be obtained
definition.example: Euclid's axioms form the foundation of his system of geometry.

definition.definition: a statement or principle that is generally accepted to be true
obviously true and therefore not needing to be proved
definition.example:
It is an axiomatic fact that governments rise and fall on the state of the economy.
It seems axiomatic that everyone would benefit from a better scientific education.

definition.definition: obvious and not needing proof
a real or imaginary straight line going through the centre of an object that is spinning, or a line that divides a symmetrical shape into two equal halves
definition.example:
The earth revolves around the axis that joins the North and South Poles.
The diameter of a circle is also an axis.

definition.definition: a fixed line on a graph used to show the position of a point
definition.example: Plot distance on the vertical y-axis against time on the horizontal x-axis.

definition.definition: the second of the small bones in the neck that form the spine and support the skull
an agreement between governments or politicians to work together to achieve a particular aim
definition.example: the Franco-German axis

definition.definition: the countries, including Germany, Italy, and Japan, that fought against the Allies in the Second World War
definition.example: the Axis powers/nations

definition.definition: a real or imaginary straight line that goes through the center of a spinning object or a line that divides a shape into two equal halves
The earth's axis is an imaginary line that goes through the earth between the North Pole and the South Pole.
An axis is also a line on a graph used to show the position of a point.
one of two or more fixed lines on a graph
definition.example:
horizontal/vertical axis We can label the axes - time is on the horizontal axis, and the amount (or value) of money is shown on the vertical axis.
an axis measures/shows/represents The vertical axis shows the rate of growth in inflation-adjusted GDP.

definition.definition: a bar connected to the centre of a circular object such as a wheel that allows or causes it to turn, especially one connecting two wheels of a vehicle
a bar connected to the center of a circular object such as a wheel that allows or causes it to turn, esp. one connecting two wheels of a vehicle
an important religious leader of Shiite Muslims in Iran

definition.info: old use or Northern English or Scottish English
definition.definition: another word for "yes"
definition.example:
"Would you prefer not to work?" "Oh aye, I'd stop tomorrow if I could."
All those who support this proposal say "Aye".

definition.definition: a word meaning "ever" or "always"
definition.example:
We would gladly preserve his memory for aye.
I have aye wanted to see Edinburgh.

definition.definition: especially in the UK parliament, a vote to support a suggestion, idea, law, etc., or a person who votes "yes"
definition.example:
Points of order are divided into ayes and noes.
The ayes are 57; the nays are 44.

definition.definition: a phrase used in a parliament or meeting to announce that there are more votes to support a suggestion, law, etc. than votes against it, so the "yes" votes have won
definition.example: All those in favour, say aye. The ayes have it. The bill is passed.

definition.definition: (used esp. in voting) yes, or a vote that means yes and supports a suggestion or plan of action
definition.example: The ayes have it, 20 to 12, and the motion is carried.

definition.definition: written abbreviation for the US state of Arizona: used in addresses
a plant or bush with brightly coloured flowers, grown in gardens. Azaleas are a type of rhododendron.
a country in southeastern Europe
a member of an indigenous group of people (= people living originally in a place rather than coming there from somewhere else) from Mexico
definition.example:
Guacamole dates back to the Aztecs, who called it ahuaca-mulli.
He was very knowledgeable about the Aztecs and other ancient Mexican cultures.

definition.definition: the language spoken by Aztecs
definition.example:
Aztec or Nahuatl is still spoken in Mexico by over a million speakers.
The word "mole", meaning a mixture or sauce, comes from a word in Aztec for chilli sauce.

definition.definition: belonging or relating to the Aztec people or their language
definition.example:
I want to learn about my ancestors, the Aztec people.
The Aztec religion in pre-Columbian Mexico was based on the sun god as the source of life.
The name "avocado" comes from an Aztec word.
the Aztec Empire

definition.definition: having the bright blue colour of the sky on a clear day
definition.example:
The once azure skies of Athens have been ruined by atmospheric pollution.
A gauzy azure scarf was twisted in her hair.

definition.definition: the bright blue colour of the sky on a clear day
definition.example:
The only non-green colour in the forest is the deep azure of the sky.
He was captivated by the beautiful azure of the woman's eyes.
